The Remote Manipulator System (RMS) design specification isa part of this document. (Cont.)\n\nA.2.36\nA.2.37\nB.\nC.\n\nD.\nE.\nF.\n\nRMS Dispatcher Compoo1\nRMS Constants Compoo1\nI/O Data Tables\nTraceability Matrix\nInterprocess Variables Definitions\nData Item Descriptors\nData Tables (To Be Provided)\n\nPage v\n\nDate. 10/16/79\nPage 1-1\n\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specificat.on\n1.\n\nINTRODUCTION\n\nSystems Management (SM) software provides the user a means to monitor vehicle\nsubsystems during on-orbit phases. Information related to the vehicle subsystem\nhealth and Btatus is provided to the user through automatic fault, detection, performance data readouts, and configuration status displays. Vehicle subsystem management is accomplished by \'user assessment of information provided by SM and subsequent user actions to affect vehicle configuration. SM also performs special\ncomputations and sequences to provide additional, information and to provide assistance in the maintenance of several vehicle subsystem.\n\'\nData monitored includes Operational Instrumentation (01) data from the PCM\nMaster Unit, data from the Payload MDM\'s (includes midbody MDM\'s), and software\ngenerated data.\nIn addition to the monitoring of the vehicle subsystem, SM software provides\nthe user the capability to update parameters which control SM processing.\nThe purpose of the SM portion of this document is twofold: (a) to define\nthe functions to be performed by the SM application software and (b) to describe\nat a detailed level the design employed to accomplish these functions. To achieve\nthis, the remainder of the SM portion of this document is organized into two\nsections. Bection 2 defines the control structure of the SM application. Section\n3 describes the design of the SM application and is organized as follows:\na.\n\nSection 3.1 - Overview of the SM application\n\nb.\n\nSection 3.2 - Detailed descriptions of the Operational Sequences (OPS)\ncontrol segments and the cyclic processes they control.\n\nc.\n\nSection 3.3 - Detailed descriptions of the SM Specialist Function\n(SPEC) control segments and all the display controlled "on-demand"\nprocesses that are invoked by either an OPS or SPEC control segment\nas a direct result of an item entry to a display.\n\nSections 3.2 and 3.3 describe each processing element (module) in the SM\napplication. Each description consists of text, an input/output table (Module\nData List) and a structured control flow diagram.\nThe text provides a narrative description of the flow through the module\n(paragraph C - process description) and other information pertinent to that\nprocess and its interfaces to other processes.\n\nDate\' 10/16/79\nPage 1-2\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specificatron\n\nControl flows describe the processing flow of a module and reflect the\nlevel of detail as specified in theSM level B CPDS, SM level C FSSR part\nB or RMS level C FSSR Volume 1, as appropriate.\nModule Data Lists provide a tabular list of parameters required.to control\nthe processing flow and provide additional information about those parameters\nas follows:\nItem Number - Items are sequentially numbered for reference purposes.\nItem Name - A generic (English) title for the parameter. This name is\nthe same as that used in the control flow and the various appendixes.\nDescriptor - A reference to a full description of the parameter in an\nappendix. If the parameter is table resident in an SM compool,it is\nfurther described in Appendix A. If it is locally declared or a CALL\nLIST parameter, it is further described in Appendix E. Additionally,\ninterprocess variables are further described in Appendix D.\nActivity\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\nme\n\n- denotes usage of parameter\n\nI - Input\nOutput\nL - Locally declared variables\nC - Locally declared constants\n\no-\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\nCompool Constant\nInput interprocess or\nhardware parameter\nW - Output interprocess or\nhardware parameter\nZ\n\nR\n\nSource/Destination - Specifies the external moduies which reference the\ndata. The three character ID\'s (see Table 1-1) of all modules supplying\n(inputs) or receiving the parameters are specified. Additionally, Downlist (DL) or CRT Display (CRT) may be specified as a destination in this\ncolumn to indicate the parameters are available for Downlist and/or CRT\ndisplay. Uplink Processor (SUL) and I-Load (ILD) :may be specified as a source\nin this column.\n.\nHAL Name - The HAL name/Assembly Language name assigned to the parameter\n(include Assembly Language aliases, if applicable). Naming standard are\nspecified in the Space Shuttle Orbiter Avionics Software Programming Standards Document. The third character of non-local (functional) data has a\nunique identifier for each functional area within an FSW application. The\nfunctional IDs for the SM application (excluding RMS) are listed in Table 1-2.\nThe Programming Standards document does not define a convention for local data.\nHowever, SM adheres to the following local data standard:\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\nLocally DECLARE\'d data will begin with the three character ID of\nthe module using the data (i.e., data local to PM control will be\nof the form SPM_X .... X).\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\nLocal TEMPORARY data will have no standard convention, but should\nhave a name descriptive of its use.\n\n/0\n\n/-~\n\nDate: 10/16/79\nPage 1-3\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\nMML -\'The Master Measurement List number specified in the Level B or C requirement for the parameter. If no MML is specified., the column is blank.\nRequirement Symbol - The symbol used in the Level C requirements to denote\nthe parameter. If none is specified, the colUJlln is blank.\nAppendixes A - E provide the following information:\nA - Data Base Definitions - a description of the tables contained in the SM\ncompools.\nB - I/O Data Tables - Description of data tables for non mission:"\'dependent I/O.\nC - Traceability Matrix - A two-way cross reference (requirements to SDS\nsection, SDS section to requirements).\nD - Interprocess Variables Definition - Lists variables which are referenced\nat two or more priority levels and the three character ID\'s (see Table\n1-1) of the modules which update or reference them. If the module\nlisted is assuming the priority of some other process, the threecharaeter ID of that process is listed in parentheses \'following the ID\nof the module. Where control over how the variables are updated and\nreferenced is necessary, e.g., to maintain time homogeneity, this control\nis di:3cussed.\nIf two or more variables share the same table locations, references, and\ncontrols, these variables are listed as one group. A reference to the\nappendix describing the variable is listed with each location.\nNo attempt is made to list all variables which are asynchronously referenced by the cyclic display processor.\nE - Data Item Descriptor - Variables in the Module Data Lists that are not\nlisted in Appendix A. (;t. e., not SM Compool resident). This appendix\nis organized by SDS section number. The item # in Appendix E corresponds to the item # for that entry in the respective section\'s Module\nData List.\nThe follow\'ing documents were used in preparation of this version of the\nSystem (multi-area)\n\nZ\n\nTable 1-2\n\n1&\n\n/-\n\n"\n\n\\\n\nDate I iO/16/19\nPage 2-1\ni\n\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design\n\nSpecificat~on\n\n2.\n\nFUNCTIONAL DESCRIPTION\n\nThe Systems Management\xc2\xb7 structure consists of three major functions: Basic\nSM Processes, Special Processes, and Display and Uplink Controlled Processes. The\nfunctions and the major processes included in each are shown in the hierarchy\ndiagram in\xc2\xb7 Figure 2-1.\nBasic 8M Pr;cesses acquire data from the various\' vehicle s)\\tbsystems and\nmonitor this data to provide fault detection and\'warning in the event of a vehicle subsystem failure. Data Acquisition acquires the data and makes it available for further processing. Performance Monitoring provides the control for\nFault Detect:Lon and Annunciation (FDA), and Precondition Processing (dynamic\nlimit select:Lon for FDA processing).\nSpecial Processes, under the control of a Special Processes Executive, provides specialized computations and processing sequ.ences to determine and control\nthe status and performance of various vehicle sUbsystems. Vehicle subsystems\ndata necessary for Special Processes is acquired by Special Processes Data\nAcquisition and made available to Basic SM Processes. Error conditions determined as a part of computations or sequences are a.nnunciated from the Special\nProcesses.\nDisplay and Uplink Controlled Processes provide functions which can be used to\ninitiate, alter, or terminate certain processing within Basic SM Processes and\nSpecial Processes. Some of these functions provide the onboard capability to\nmodify certain tables used by SM Processes. Display and Uplink Controlled Processes\nconsists of Table Maintenance, Subsystem Configuration Management\xc2\xb7, Conununications\nInstrumentation, Antenna Management, Mass Memory Patch, Payload Bay Doors, Payload\nControl, the Remote Manipulator System, and the Uplink Processor.\nA more thorough functional description of Systems Management may be found\nin the Design Overview, Section 3.1.\n\naJ\n\n0\n0\n\nSystems\nManagement\n\n~\n\n0\n\n"\'T1\n\n-f\n\nen\n3:\n0\n\nftI\n....\n\n!!.\n\nCii\n\nQ.\n\nBasic SM\nProcesses\n\n.Display And\nUplink Controlled Pro- .\ncesses\n\nSpecial\nProcesses\n\n0\n\ni\ncC\'\n:l\n\nen\n\n"0\n\n...\nftI\n\n~.\n\n-~\n\n1\n\nI\nSpecial\nProcesses\nExecutive\n\nData\nAcquisition\n\nPerformance\nMonitoring\nFig. 3.2.1.4\n\nSr\n\nFig. 3.2.1.3\n\nSpecialist\nFunctions\n\nFig. 3.2.1.9\n\nFig 3.3.1 Thru 3.3.3\n3.3]\n\nFig3.:tS Thru\n\no\xc2\xb7\n\n1\nItem Entry\nProcessors\n\nUplink\nprocessor\n\nFig 3.3.4\nFig 3.3.5\n\n:l\n\nF!!J.3~~1.23\n\n1\nFault\nDetection\nAnd\nAnnunciation\n\nPrecondition\nProcessing\nFig. 3.2.1.5\n\nSpecial\nProcesses\nData\nAcquisition\n\nFig. 3.2.1.6\n\nSpecial Processes\nSequences And\n.computations\nFig. 3.2.1.1 i fhr=-u\'\n.\n3.2.1.22\n\nFig. 3.2.1.1 0\n\nSpecial Processes\nData Output\n\'l:Jt::I\n\nFig. 3.2.1".11\n\n&i~\nCD CD\n\nI\\)j--J\n\n10\n1\\)"\nj--J\n\n0\\\n\n,\n~igure\n"\n\n\\\n\n"\n\n- . .!\n\n.....:j\n\n2-1; Systems Management Hierarchy Diagram\n\n\\0\n\n\\\n\n\\\nj\n\nDate\nPage\n\nlO/161\'T9\n3-1\n\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\n3.\n\nSOFTWARE DESIGN\n\nThis section describes the SM software processing elements. The emphasis\nin the presentation is on describing the design of the SM application processing\nelements, the tables used, and the control and interface relationships. As such,\na major part of this section is a series of structured control flow diagrams.\nEach diagram has descriptions which detail the process and tables which list\nprocess inputs and outputs. Prior to presenting the processing elements, high\nlevel design consideration, assumptions, and structure (tables and processing\nelements) are discussed.\n3.1\n3.1.1\n\nDESIGN OVERVIEW\nDesign Consideration\n\nThe Systems Management software is designed to operate within the framework of the overall Orbiter Flight Program design. The SM design is influenced\nand constrained by the System Software designs to ensure accurate and efficient\ninterfaces with the system services. The FCOS provides the services for all\nI/O operations and supervises the timing and execution of SM software components.\nThe User Interface software provides the servic:e functions by which the user communicates with the SM software. System Control software initializes the APlOl\nGPC software to a point where the SM software can be activated.\nThe SM software design is also influenced by organization of processes\ninto Operational Sequences (OPS) and Specialist Functions (SPEC). Control segments, the software implementation of OPS and SPEC, centralize the structure of\nthe software at a high and visible level. The segment design is determined by\nwhich functions are valid for a particular OPS or SPEC. The control segment\ndetermines the sequencing of functions wi thin the OPS or SPEC based on user input, time or events. The SM OPS and SPEC structure is described in Section\n3.1.4.\nAnother consideration influencing the SM design is the decision to divide\nthe processing into Basic SM Processes, Special Processes, and Display and Uplink\nControlled Processes. This decision allows the OFT design of the Basic SM Processes to resemble the ALT design so that minimal changes are required to reflect\nadditional OFT requirements and so that new code for Special Processes and Display\nControlled Processes may be developed independently from modifications to existing\ncode. This decision also leads to easier CPU load balancing of the cyclic processes included in SM (Basic SM Processes and Special Processes). Figures 3.1.1-1\nand 3.1.1-2 are an example representation of how this load balancing could be\naccompli:3hed. The actual process ordering and. offsets are determined using performance data obtained from executing the actual code.\n\nDate\nPage\n\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\n,\n\n\'"\n\n-\'" \'"\n\'"\n.- u\nu \'"\n\n+\nI\n\n\'" ...\n0. 0\n\ncnc..\n\n~\n\n10/16/79\n3-2\n\n....\n\nu\n.- \'"\n\'"\n\'" \'"\nalfl\n\n~~\n\ncnc..\nA,\n\n",I\nN\xc2\xa7I\n~I\n\n~\no\n\n.....\n\n0\nN\n\n1e\n\n(Xl\n\n0\n\n::2E\n\n(/)\n\n).\n\nr\n\nen\n\nc\n\'u\nc\nctI\n\n16\n\nIII\n"C\n\nctI\n\n0\n..J\n\nQ)\n\nis.\n\nE\n\nctI\n\n(/)\n\n\'7\n\n.....\n....\n\nM\n\n...\n\nQ)\n\n:::I\n\nen\n\nu:\n\nM\n\nV>\n\n"0\n\nc:\n\n00\n\n~\n\n/\n\n\'\\,\n\nDate\nPage\n\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\n-~\n\'"\n\nIII\n\n0-\n\n.,\n\n(J\n\n(J\n\n., 0\n\nc. ...\n\nr--------.\n(1)0..\n\nJ.\n\nf\n\nIII\n\n"t:l\n\nc::\n\n00\n\nJl\n\nOJ\n\n>\n\n\'\';:;\n\nV)\n\n:J .,\nCJ_\nOJ (J\n\na.. x>\n\n(l)UJU\n\n10/16/79\n3-3\n\nDate\nPage\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\nA final consideration which influenced the SM design is the utilization of\na table driven approach. This approach is employed for two reasons. First,\nBasic SM Processes consist of cyclic processing of input parameters utilizing\nrepeti ti ve logic with parameter unique processing control data . With! the table\ndriven design, generalized processing routines can be coded which process many\nparameters based on the table resident control information for each parameter.\nThis method prevents coding similar logic for each parameter to be processed,\nthereby reducing memory requirements. The second reason for adopting the table\ndriven design is to accommodate the requirement to allow the changing of the\nprocessing control data on a parameter basis inflight via keyboard and on a\nsystem basis during ground turnaround operations.\n3.1.2\n\nDesign Assumptions\n\nThis section lists assumptions made in the SM design. The purpose in listing the assumptions is to make visible specific items which if determined to be\ninvalid would impact the design. Additional assumptions which apply across the\ntotal Orbiter Flight Program are identified in Volume 1.\na.\n\nSM processes use "current values" and do not ensure time homogenous\ndata (except for interprocess data with homogeneity requirements).\n\nb.\n\nAll discretes within an acquired word are acquired at the same\nsample rate; that rate being the highest rate specified for any\none discrete in the word.\n\nc.\n\nAll parameter samples acquired for Basic SM Processes are processed.\n\nd.\n\nChannelization data for parameters used in special processing is not\nmission-dependent.\n\ne.\n\nData is not acquired from serial channels for Basic SM Processes or\nSubsystem Configuration Management (SCM). However, data acquired\nfrom serial channels for Special Processes is available in the SM\nCOMPOOL to Basic SM Processes and to SCM.\n\n(1;\n\n~\xc2\xb7\xc2\xb7D\n\n\\;{ if-\n\nDate\nPage\n\n10/16/79\n3.1. 3-1\n\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\n3.1.3\n\nSM Table Structure Overview\n\nIn a table-driven design, the tables are an integral part of the software\nand key to understanding the design is to understand the tables and how they\n\'control\' the process. Significant table attributes which must be understood\nare function, content, organization and relationships between the tables and\nthe processes. Content relates to whether the table contains control information or data. Organization defines the structure and substructures of entries\nwithin the table. An example organization would be by parameter sample rate\nand then by parameter type. Relationships between the tables relates mainly\nto how reference is made to the tables by the processes.\nAn overview of the SM tables and buffers and their relationships is shown\nin Figures 3.1.3-1 through 3.1.3-3. Tables contained within the dashed blocks\nare associated with the indicated process or function group. Those tables not\nenclosed are common to many processes and cannot be associated with any particular process. Tables connected by solid lines have a direct index or reference relationship. A table pointing to another (as depicted by the arrow) has\nan address or an index into the table being pointed to. Tables, connected by\ndashed lines are similarly organized and thus do not require a direct index.\n\nAppendix A.2 describes each table. Reference should be made to these\ndescriptions as the process descriptions and control flows are studied. Particular attention should be given to the organization of entries within the\ntable. For example, if the first level table organization is by parameter\ntype, the process is controlled accordingly. A secondary organization within\nthe table (i.e., by sample rate) will represent a \'nested\' control loop within\nthe process being described.\nMany of the SM tables contain data that may change from mission to mission.\nThese tables are generated by an offline table preprocessor (refer to the SM\nPreprocessor Detail Design Specification). The Preprocessor initializes certain\nvariable data items to a required state. For example, the parameter I/O status\nbits in the CDA are initialized to ensure that invalid Parameter Status Indicators are initially displayed for all parameters. The Preprocessor also generates certain buffers because the structure of these buffers is determined by\nthe content or organization of the tables.\nLinkages between the tables/buffers (the Preprocessor output) and the SM\nexecutable code are resolved via a \'system build\' process performed in the\nSoftware Development Laboratory (SDL).\n\n.-----\n\nData Acquisition\n\nI\n\nI\nI\nI\n\nL...-.-\n\n-----1\n\n~\nData Acquisition\nRead Table\n(DART)\n\n---.\n\ncg\n\n\xc2\xb70\n\no\n~\n\no\n"T1\n\nI\n\nInput\nBuffer\n(lNB)\n\n1--.\n\n--- ---- ---- ---- ----\n\nInput Buffer To\nPPB/CDA\nXREF (lXP)\n\nrc--\n\nI\n\nScaling XREF\nTable (SXT)\n\n--- - - - - - -\n\n-I\n(I)\n\n~\n\no\n\n~\n\nI\n\n!!!.\n\nCD\nc-\n\n_J\n\nSpecial Process\nTables/Buffers\n(See SPINB,\nSPOB,& DDT\nIn Fig. 3.1.3-2)\n\n- --\n\nr\nParameter\nProcessing\nBuffer (PPB)\n\n\'ii~\n:.,"\'"\n\n~\n\n...\n\n-.I\nI\nI\nI\nI\n\nO\n\nIi\ncC\xc2\xb7\n::I\nen\n~\n~\n\n~\ng.\nr+\n\no\xc2\xb7\n::I\n\n+\n\n....\n\nCurrent Data\nArray (FDA\nCDA)\n\nCurrent Data\nArray (Non-FDA\nCDA)\n\nI\n\nScaling\nTable\n(SAT)\n\nI\nI\n\n.--I\nI\n\nI\nI\n\nI\n---1- I\n\n\' Limit Sense\nTable (LIT)\n\n~\n\nL ___ _\n\nParameter\nInformation\nTable (PIT)\n\n~\n\nPrecondition\nGroup Table\n(PGT)\n\nPerformance Monitoring\n~-.-\n\n-\n\nf.-\n\nPrecondition\nControl Table\n(PCT)\n\nCommunication\nTable (CMT)\n\nI\n\nI\n\n\'l:Jt:::I\n\nJii~\nCD CD\n\nI\n\n---J\n\nW\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\nLegend\n---"Direct Index\n- ....... Special Processes Table/Buffer Relationships\n\n\'l:J t:1\n\nJg\n\n~\n\nLA>\n\nI--\'\n0\n\nCD\n\nCD\n\n.\n\n---I--\'\n\nI\nLA>\n\n-.:]\n\nI--\'\n\nLA>\n\n____\n0\\\n\\0\n\nm\n\no\no\n~\n\n,..-- -\n\nI\n\n-\n\n-\n\n-\n\nSCM Text\nDictionary\n(SCMT)\n\n--\n\n---\n\n-\n\n-\n\nI\n\n~I\n\nL\n\n-\n\nI\n-\n\n---I\n\nI\n\nPayload Control\nDiscrete\nInformation\nTable (DIT)\n\nGeneral XREF\nTable (GXT)\n\nAnalog\nInformation\nTable (AN IT)\n\nJ\n\n.~\n\nI\n\nI\n\nSCM List\n(SCML)\n\nL\n\xc2\xbb\n\n------l\n\nSubs;em Configuration Management\'\n\nChannel\nStatus\nTable (CST)\n-\'-~\n\nCurrent Data\nArray (See\nCDA In\nFig. 3.1.3-1),\n\no\n"\'TI\n\n-f\n(I)\n\n~\n\n~\n\n!!&i"\nSpecial Processes\nTables/Buffers\n(See SPINB,\nSPOB,& DDT\nIn Fig. ,3.1.3-2)\n\ncO\n\na\nlir\n:::l\n\n(I)\n\n~\n:;;\n&l.\no\xc2\xb7\n:::l\n~\n\nI\nI\n\nI\n_---1\n\nCommunications\nTable (CMT)\n\nLegend:\n--.-Direct Index\n----~Indirect\n\nFigure 3.1.3-3. Display Controlled Processes Table/Buffer Relationships\n\nRelationship\n\ni~\nCD CD\nWf-l\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n0\nf-l_\nf-l\nWO\\\n1+=\'""--1\n\'-0\n\n\'\\\n~J\n\n\\\n\nDate\nPage\n\n10/16/79\n3.1. 4-1\n\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n,\n...\n\n3 :1.4\n\nProce::lsing Element Structure\n\nThe SM processing elements are organized into two basic structures:\nOperational Sequences (OPS) and Specialist Functions (SPECs). Each OPS contains certain SM functions which are valid during the time that particular\nOPS is active. In addition, certain functions defined as SPECs are also valid\nduring a particular OPS. These SPECs are initiated only upon user request.\nWithin the OPS/SPEC structure, the SM processing elements are grouped into\nthree basic areas: Basic SM Processes, Special Processes, and Display and Uplink\nControlled Processes. The Basic SM Processes and Special Processes are controlled\nby OPS control segment(s) while the Display Controlled Processes are controlled\nby OPS control segments and/or SPEC control segments. Figure 3.1.4-1 shows the\ncontrol flow from the SM OPS and SPEC control seg~ents to the various SM processes. Also shown in Figure 3.1.4-1 is RMS processing which also executes\nwithin the SM OPS/SPEC structure.\nThe functions which comprise the primary role of Basic SM Processes, Data\nAcquisition and PM Control, are valid in SM OPS 2 and are structured as two\ncyclic processes. Each is scheduled by the OPS control segment. Figure 3.1.4-2\nillustrates the data flow through Basic SM Processes, i.e., the relationship between the two basic processes (Data Acquisition and PM control) and the primary\ndata buffers these processes utilize.\nThe Special Processes execute asynchronously to Basic SM Processes and consists of three groups of functions: Data Acquisition, Computations and Sequences,\nand Data Output. All functions in these groups are invoked by the Special Processes Executive which is scheduled cyclically by the SM OPS 2 control segment.\nThe functions invoked by the Special Processes Executive differ according to\nwhich are valid for the currently executing Mode. Figure 3.1.4-3 illustrates\nthe data flo\'w through the three groups of function.s comprising the Special Processes and the primary data areas used by these functions.\nThe Display and Uplink Controlled Processes are all "on-demand" functions\nwhich are invoked by an OPS or SPEC control segment as a direct result of an entry\nto a display (or in the case of the SM Uplink Processor, a signal from the Systems\nServices Uplink Software). Except for RMS all data flow between the control segments, the Display and Uplink Controlled Processes, and any affected cyclic processes is via the Communications Table (see Appendix A.2).\n\nDate\nPage\n\n10/16/79\n3.1. 4:"\'2\n\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\nThe Subsystem Measurement Management (SMM) Display processing function is\nrelated to SM, but not part of the SM processing structure. SMM Display Processing is performed asynchronously to the SM processes discussed above. The\nUser Interface function, CSDS-Volume II, Part 2), updates the active SMM display(s) by utilizing a set of tables that contain various control information\nand pointers to parameter values and statuses in the SM COMPOOL\'s. These tables\nare built by an offline process, the Display Format Generator (DFG) program.\nInputs to the DFG program are generated by the SMPreprocessor and are discussed\nin the SM Preprocessor Detailed Design Specification - Phase II, Section 6.\nThis design approach allows SMM displays to be defined and generated independently of the SM executable code.\n\n-Basic SM Processes\n\nr-----i\n\nSpecial Processes\n\nr------l\nII\n\nI\n\nI\n\n( Cancel RMS Executive)\nOPS Control\nf"lIment\n\nSPEC\nControl\nSegment(s)\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\nSpecial Process\nExecutive 5 Hz\n\n1\nI\nI\n\nI\n\nI\nI\nI\n\nI\n\nI\n\nI\n\nI\n_____ ..J\n\nI\n\nL~\n\nI\n\nr-I\n\nI\nI\n\nI\nI\n\nI\nL\n\n1- ------ - Special Processes Ovelview\n\nI-\n\nJ\n\nDate 10/16/79\n\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n3.1.5\n\nPage 3.1.5-1\n\nRMS Overview\n\nRMS processing operates as a specialist control function under SM OPS\n2. The system has six internal configurations (Suspend, Temperature, Idle,\nSingle, Manual, Auto). To obtain configuration independence, theRMS\nexecutive modules perform all the configuration control processing. RMS\nprogram module interfa.ce.management has been cemtralized in the executive\nmodules through the use of program dispatcher tables.\nFigure 3.1.5-1 illustrates the RMS external interfaces [Flight Computer\nOperating System (FCOS), SM Table Maintenance (8M TM SPEC), User Interface\n(UI), Downlist (DL) 1. descri:ption of the BM Orbit/Doors (OPS 2) Control Segment is presented.\nF\'unctions acttve throughout this OPS are identified; and Mode processing and\ndisplays are j.dentified. ~rhe displays available within the SM OPS 2 Control\nSegment are shown in Table 3.2-1 with valid SM OPS transitions identified in\n\'rable 3.2-2. No attempt il3 made to identify specif:Lc item entries or unique\nprocessing aSBociated with item entries in the cont:rol segment flows. Item .\nentry processing is more fully discussed in Section 3.3 (Display and Uplink\nControlled Processes).\nValid Specialist Functions (SPECs) within each SM OPS are shown in Table\n3.2-2. Two unique Specialist Functions may be active within each OPS. Descriptions of all SM Specialist Functions valid for SM OPS 2 are in Section 3.3.\nWhen a valid OPS transition, as specified in Table 3.2-2, occurs between\ntwo OPS containing SM processing, certain data is maintained for use by the\nnew OPS. This data includes:\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\nThe parameters maintained by the Communications/Instrumentation\nSPEC function indicating the last 128 KBPS and 64 KBPS format\nIDs entered.\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\nAll values input from the Antenna Management display.\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\nAll values updated by the Table Maintenance SPEC function.\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\nKu-band antenna control dis.cretes updated by uplink.\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\nValues maintained by FDA processes to control their processing.\n\nIf the transition does not involve a memory reconfiguration, no action is required to maintain the data. If the transition involves overlaying the data,\nthe data is saved and restored to the SM tables before the new OPS initiates\nany processing. Since there is only one OPS configuration currently defined\ncontaining SM processing, no valid transitions can occur which involve memory\nreconfigurations, and thus no processes are presented which maintain the above\ndata.\n\nDate/ 10/16/79\nDate 3.2-2\n\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\nTable 3.2-1.\n\nSM OPS Display Content\nOPS\nSEQ\n\nDISPLAY TITLE\n\nOPS\n\nSPEC\n\nDISP\n\nSM Systems Summary 1\n\n2\n\nx\n\nSM Systems Summary 2\n\n2\n\nx\n\n2\n\nx\n\n2\n\nx\n\n2\n\nx\n\nCRYO/Fuel Cell\nEnvironmental\nAPU/HYD\n\n1\n\nl\n\nl\n\nSM Table Maintenance\n\n2\n\nx\n\nSCM\n\n2\n\nx\n\nPCMMU/PL Comm\n\n2\n\nx\n\nCommunications Management\n\n1\n\nx\n\n2\n\nAntenna Management\n\n2\n\nx\n\nPayload Bay Doors\n\n2\n\nx\n\nHYD Thermal\n\n1\n\nx\n\n2\n\nx\n\nPDRS Control\n\n2\n\nPDRS Status\n\n2\n\nx\n\n2\n\nx\n\nElectrical\n\nl\n\nPayload Control SPEC (1-4)\nPayload Parametric\nPropellant Thermal\n\nl\n\nMass Memory Read/Write\n1\n\nx\n\n2\n\nl\n\nx\n\n2\n\n1\n\nAPU/Environmental Thermal\n\n2\n\nx\n\n2\n\nx\n\n2\n\nThese displays may be mass memory resident.\nare main memory resident.\n\n,31\n\nx\nThe remaining displays\n\nDate\nPage\n\n10/16/79\n3.2-3\n\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\nTable 3.2-2.\n\nSM OPS SPEC Function Table\n-:a\'.\n\nSection\nNumber\n\nValid in SM OPS ,\n2\n\n8\n\n9\n\nTable Maintenance\n\n3.3.1\n\nyes\n\nno\n\nno\n\nSubsystem Configuration Management\n\n3.3.2\n\nyes\n\nno\n\nno\n\nCommunications/Instrumentation\n\n3.3.3\n\nyes\n\nno\n\nno\n\nPayload Control (1-4)\n\n3.3.6\n\nyes\n\nno\n\nno\n\nno\n\nno\n\nyes\n\nFirst Sensor Self Test\n\nno\n\nno\n\nyes\n\nSecond Sensor Self Test\n\nno\n\nno\n\nyes\n\nTCS Control\n\nno\n\nno\n\nyes\n\nSystem Services SPECs\n\nyes\n\nyes\n\nyes\n\nSpecialist; When SM OPS 2 is selected the Orbit/Doors Control\nSegment calls the OPS 2 Initialization/Cleanup module to initialize\ndata areas. It then schedules Data Acquisition, Performance Monitor\nControl, the Special Processes Executive, and the Uplink Processor.\nMode 201 - Orbit Mode\nAfter the cyclic processors are scheduled, the OPS 2 Initialization/\nCleanup module is called to perform Mode 201 initialization, the AM\ndisplay is presented and the Control Segment waits for a new OPS, new\nmode or item entry. If an item entry is made, the AM Item Processor\nis called to process the request. If Mode 202 is selected, the OPS 2\nInit~alization/Cleanup module is called to perform mode cleanup and\nthe Mode 202 processing as described below is performed. If a new OPS\nis selected, the OPS2 Initialization/Cleanup module is called to perform mode cleanup, then Data Acquisition, Specia1PTocesses Executive,\nand the RMS Executive are cancelled and the OPS 2 Initialization/Cleanup\nmodule is called to perform OPS cleanup.\n~ode\n\n202 - PBDOperations Mode\n\nAfter the cyclic processors are scheduled, the OPS 2 Initialization/\nCleanup module is called to perform Mode 202 initialization, the PBD\nOperations diBplay is presented and the control segment waits for a\nnew OPS, new mode or item entry. If an item entry is made, the PBD\nItem Processor is called to process the request. If Mode 201 is\nBe1ected, the OPS 2 Initialization/Cleanup module is called to perform mode cleanup and the Mode 201 processing as described above is\nperformed. If a new OPS is selected, the OPS 2 Initalization/Cleanup\nmodule is called to perform mode cleanup, then Data Acquisition,\nSpecial ProceBses Executive, and the R]\'J[S Executive are cancelled and\nthe OPS 2 Initialization/Cleanup module is called to perform OPS cleanup.\n\n10/16/79\n3.2.1-2\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\nd.\n\nOutputs - Outputs from this module are specified in Table 3.2.1-1.\n\ne.\n\nModule References - Process\n\nSection\n\nReference\n\nOPS 2 Initialization/Cleanup\n\n3.2.1.1\n\nCALL\n\nAM Item Processor\n\n3.3.4\n\nCALL\n\nPED Item Processor\n\n3.3.5\n\nCALL\n\nData Acquisition\'\n\n3.2.1.3.1\n\nSCHEDULE/\nCANCEL\n\nPerformance Monitor Control\n\n3.2.1.4\n\nSCHEDULE\n\nSpecial Processes Executive\n\n3.2.1.9\n\nSCHEDULE/\nCANCEL\n\nUplink Processor\n\n3.2.1.23\n\nSCHEDULE\n\nRMS Executive\n\n3.3.8.4\n\nCANCEL\n/-\n\nf.\n\nModule type and Attributes:\nType:\n\nProgram\n\nAttributes:\ng.\n\nN/A\n\nTemplate References\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE\n\nCZl COMMON\n\nSystem Services Common Compool\n\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE\n\nDIS PLAY\n\nUI external procedure used by\nthe grammar macros (D1l?play:::Presentation and Control)\n\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE\n\nDNX EMS\n\nur external procedure used by\ngrammar macros (Application Moding\nand Sequencing)\n\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE\n\nSDA_DATA_ACQ\n\nData Acquisition\n\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE\n\nSPM CONTROL\n\nPerformance Monitor Control\n\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE\n\nSSP EXEC\n\nSpecial Processes Executive\n\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE\n\nSAM ITEM\n\nAM Item Processor\n\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE\n\nSED ITEM\n\nPED Item Processor\n\n10/16/79\n3.2.1-3\n\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\nTemplate References (Cont\'d)\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE S21 CLNUP\n\nOPB 2 Initialization/Cleanup\n\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE SUL UPLINK\n\nUplink Processor\n\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE REX RMSEXEC\n\nRMS Executive\n\nD INCLUDE DAG#RAM\n\nCommon grammar macro set.\n\nD INCLUDE DBG#RAM\n\nOPS Control Segment grammar macro set.\n\nD INCLUDE DDG#RAM\n\nAllows references to MCDs keyboard\ninputs.\n\nD INCLUDE OPSCMACS\n\nContains FCOS OPS Cancel macros.\n\nD INCLUDE ZPRIOTIM\n\nContains REPLACE names for baseline\npriorities, phasing and rates of\nscheduled processes (ref. SM Orbit/Doors (OPS 2) Control Segment\n\nDate:\nPage\n\n10/161\'79\n3.2.1.1-1\n\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed De!iign Specification\n\n3.2.1.1\n\nOPS 2 Initialization/Cleanup (S2I_CLNUP)\n\nThe OPS 2 Initialization/Cleanup module provides for centralized entry and\nexit proceBsing for the SM OPS Control Segment (SM 2).\na.\n\nControl Interface - The OPS 2 Initialization/Cleanup module is CALL\'ed\n;In demand by the Orbit/Doors Control Segment.\nInvocation: CALL S2I_CLNUP (Init/Cleanup Request*, DID No)\n\nb.\n\n.Inputs - InputB to this module are specified in crable 3.2.1.1-1.\n\nc.\n\n:Process DeBcr:i;ption - The control flow for this module is shown in\nFigure 3.2.1.1-1 through 3.2.1.1\xc2\xb7-4. The OPS 2 Initialization/Cleanup\n:module determines which processing to perform and then does OPS initialization, OPS cleanup, mode initialization or mode cleanup. The restore of\ncheckpointed data is done in OPS Initialization if System Services\nindicates to 8M that restore was requested by the user via the DPS Utility\ndisplay. If no I/O error occurs during the restore process, the data is\ndispersed to the SM tables.\n.\n\nd.\n\n.Outputs - Outputs from this module are specified in Table 3.2.1.1-1.\n\ne.\n\nModule References - None\n\nf.\n\nModule\n\n~ld\n\nAttributes\n\nType: External Procedure\nAttributes: Default (serially reusable with no protective mechanism)\ng.\n\nTemplate References\nD Include Template\n\nCGE DISPA\'l\'CHER\n\nHybrid Dispatcher Include\nSegment\n\nD Include Template\n\nSHD HYB DISPATCH\n\nSM Hybrid Dispatch Table\n\nD Include Tem:plate\n\nCSS COT\n\nConstants Table (COT)Values\n\nInclude Template\n\nCSA SM CM\'"l\'\n\nBasic Processes CMT\n\nD Include Template\n\nCSS SP CMT\n\nSpecial Processes CMT\n\nD Include Template\n\nCSB PBD CMT\n\nPayload Bay Doors\nDisplay Parameters\n\nD Include Template\n\nCSS SPOB\n\nSpecial Process Output\nBuffer\n\nD Include\n\nCSAPIT\n\nParameter Information Table (PIT)\n\nD Include\n\nCSAPCT\n\nPrecondition Control Tables (PCT)\n\nD Include\n\nCSALIT\n\nLimit sense Table (LIT)\n\nD Include\n\nCSCOTSRC\n\nConstants Table (COT)\n\nD Include\n\nCST TM CMT\n\nTM Display Parameters Tables\n\nD\n\n11 (,I\n\nDate:\nPage:\n\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\n10/16/19\n3.2.1.1-2\n\nD Include Template\n\nSSB PL BAY DOORS\xc2\xb7\n\nPayload Bay Doors\n\nD Include Template\n\nCZ2 COMMON\n\nUI/FCOS SHARED .Compool\n\nD Include Template\n\n\xc2\xb7CZl COMMON\n\nSystem Services Common Compool\n\nD Include Template\n\nDMAMAC\n\nSystem Services Annunciation\nRoutine\n\nD Include Template.\n\nCDL ANNUN\n\nSystem Services Annunciation\nCompool\n\nD\n\nInclude IOMACS\n\nContains I/O Macro flags\n\nD\n\nInclude MMUMACS\n\nContains MM Read/Write Macros\n\nD\n\nInclude DMA # MACS\n\nSystem Services error\nannunciation macro replace\nstatements\nSM/VU common buffer\n\nD Include CVN MM UTILITY\nh.\n\nError\n\ni.\n\nConstraints and Assumptions\n\nHandlin~\n\n- None\n\n1.\n\nAssume no retry if I/O error on restore read.\n\n2.\n\nWhen a checkpoint write is initiated, 8M writes to whichever\nMM is assigned to us. When requesting a restore, the user needs\nto ensure that he/she is reading from the correct MM.\n\n3.\n\nIf an I/O read error is encountered when initializing in the OP8\n.(whether restore was requested or not), the checkpoint time\nwill be zeroed. If the read completes successfully, the\ncheckpoint time will be updated with what resides on MM (at this\npoint, we have no way of knowing whether the checkpoint unite\ncompleted successfully, so a bad time may be displayed).\n\nl)5\n\nTABLE\n\n3.2.1.1-1"O~S\n\n#\n\n2 Initialization/Cleanup\n\nITEM\n1\n\nDESCRIPTOR\n\nPara,meter processing\n\nMODULE DATA LIST\n\nSOU RCE/DESTI Nt\'.TI\n\nACT\n\nbuffer half indicator\n2\n\nAo2.11\nD.19\n\n\xc2\xb0\n\nSPl~\n\nReady flag\n\nA.2.1l\n\n\xc2\xb0\n\nSPM, SDA\n\nflag\n\nl\n\nand read\n\nD.l\n\n2\n\nm,\n\n-r\nI\n\nHAL N.A.ME\n\nI 831-.33::\'~_BUY..:\'In:=\xc2\xb7\n\nI~:::-~~~~-::~~~~~:~~\n-\n\n-\n\n-\n\nA.2.11\nD.21\n\n\xc2\xb0\n\xc2\xb0\n\nSDA\n\nE\n\nI\n\nSM2\n\nS2I_ID\n\n6\n\nControl Timer\n\nA.2.11\nD.23\n\no\n\nSSS\n\nCSLV_CONTROL_TIMER\n\n7\n\n(deleted)\n\nA.2.11\nD.20\n\n4\n\n~\n\nMonitor\nControl cancel flag\n\nData Acquisition ready\ncycle counter\n\n8\n\nPBD Active/Inactive flag\n\n10\n\nPower on/off items\n\n11\n\nA.2.22\nD.25\n\nI A.2.11\n\nAuto mode select item\n\n. Section 3.2.1. 3.1). The Special Processes\n(SP) Data Acquisition function acquires all data required by Speci~l Processes\nfrom the PCM Master Unit (PMU) and the payload MDM\' s (Ref. Section 3.2.1.11).\nGenera1.Data Acquisition is a function called by both Basic and SP Data\nAcquisition to aequire and screen the data (Ref. Section 3.2.1.3.2).\nFigure 3.2.1. 3-1 f?hows an overview of the control flow from the Basic and\nSP Data Acquisition routines to General Data Acquisition and Forward. Scaling.\nFigure 3.2.1. 3-1 also shows an overview of the data flow and table references for\nGeneral Data Acquisition and Forward Scaling. The General Data Acquisition call\nlist contains address pointers to required tables and a flag identifying the calling routine. For\'Ward Sealing is called to scale and move analog parameters after\nacquisition. It j.B passed pointers to the Scaling Cross-Reference Table (SXT) in\nits call list. Appendix A describes in detail the tables shown in Figure 3.2.1.3-1.\n\nREPRODUCIBILI1Y OF TIIli;\nORIGINAL PACd<~ IS POOH\xc2\xb7\n\nBasic\nData Acq\n(Program)\nIinterprocess\n\nGeneral Data Acq\nCall List\n\nV\n\nI\n\nGENERAL DATA ACO\n(Procedure)\n\nI\n\nI\n\nBasic\nDART\n\n1-----I\n----\n\nI~\n\n1\n\nI\nI\n\nI- - - - -\n\nBasic\nIXP\n\n1- ---------\n\nBasic\nINB\n\n\\\n\nI\n\nI\n\nI\n\nPLMDM Read\n\nI\nI\n\n---f ---------U\n\nS.P.\nINB\n\nr-\n\nS.P.\nlOB\n\nI\n\nI\n\n:r\n\nScreening\n\n0) I\n\n-C?\nPPB &\nNon FDA\'d\nCDA\n\nv\\\n\nS.P.\nDART\n\nI\n\n~\nI\n\n\\J\\\n\n----~\n~ -----1-----,\n\nPMU Read\n\nI\n\nI\n\nI\nI\n\nSpec\nProc\nData\nAcq\n(Procedure)\n\nL\n\n0-\n\n......\n4,/\n\n0-\n\n+\n\n:>\nValue For Others\n\n2. MDM\'s (includes Midbody MDM),\nand Special Processes COMPOOL\'s (Interprocess Data). Data not acquired due to I/O\nfailure is flagged invalid. All subsequent references to Payload MDM data are\nintended to include Midbody MDM data.\na.\n\nControl Interface - Data Acquisition i:3\' SCHEDULE\'d by the SM OPS Control\nSegment to execute 5 times per second.\nInvocation: SCHEDULE SDA DATA ACQ AT :~HASE SDA PRIORITY (PRIO SDA),\nREPEAT EVERY-TIME-SDA\n-\n\nb.\n\nInputs. - There are two types of input data to Data AClluisition\n1.\n\n2.\nc.\n\nExternal data which is acquired from the PMU, Payload MDM\'s, and\nInterprocess em\'WOOLs. Once this data is retrieved and moved to\n\'either the PPB or CDA, it becomes input to the other SM functions.\nInternal tables (structures) which describe the external data or\ncontrol processing (see Table 3.2.1.3.1-1).\n\n!\'rocess Description - The control f10\'w for this module is shown in\nFigures 3.2.1.3.1-1 thru 3.2.1.3.1.-3. Data Acquisition first determines whether that portion of the Parameter Processing Buffer (PPB) for\nthe second of data to be acquired has been freed from processing by the\nPM Control module. If the PPB buffer half is not available, control is\nreturned to the system. Otherwise, the read cycle to be processed (1\nthrough 10) is determined and the appropriate entry in the Data Acquisition Read Table (DART) accessed. The DART section for each read cycle\nhas an entry for each read to be issued. Each entry consists of a device address, device indicator (PCM Master Unit or Payload MDM). INB\ndisplacement and a read length (number of contiguous 16-bit parameter\nwords to be aClluired). All DART entries representing read relluests for\nthe PMU are at the beginning of the section followed bY\' PLMDM and PMU\nBITE. If there is any 5 sample per second data for the Payload MDM a\nflag is set for General AClluisition to read Payload MDM data this cycle.\nThe General Data AClluisition procedure is called to read and screen the\ndata. All Payload MDM data is read at least once per second via FCOS\nFixed BCE Programs, if any Payload MDM data is relluired at 5 sis then\nall Payload MDM data is read at 5 sis. PMU and Payload MDM data is\nmoved from the Input Buffer (By General AClluisition) at the relluired rate.\nAny interprocess data (and their I/O Status) relluired by Precondition\nProcessing and Fault Detection and Annunciation (FDA) is moved from the\nInterprocess COMPOOLs to either the PPB ( for FDA) or the Current Data\nArray (for data input to Precondition Processing only). The interprocess IXP contains a section for each read cycle. Each interprocess data\n\nC 1\'1\n\n"\') \'f\n\n10/16/79\n3 \xe2\x80\xa2. 2.1.3.1-2\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specificatron\n\nword to be processed by SM is represented by an IXP entry. Each IXP\nentry conta~ns information necessary to Inove the data word and its status flag from a Special Process\'s COMPOOL to the PPB/CDA. Since this\ndata is simply moved from a Special Process COMPOOL to either the CDA\nor PPB, no error processing is required.\nAfter all data is acquired the Forward Scaling module is called to\nscale and move the following parameters to the PPB or CDA:\n1.\n2.\n3.\n\nAll analog parameters requiring second\nAll SCM only analog parameters (to non\nAll first order analog parameters with\nto be processed by Fault Detection and\n\nand third order scaling.\nFDA CDA).\nnegative slopes\xc2\xb7 that are\nAnnunciation.\n\nThe read cycle is updated for the next cycle. On the fifth and tenth\nread cycles the Payload MDM read flag is turned on for the next cycle\nand the correct PPB ready indicator is set so that PM Control may begin\nprocessing the data. Also, at the end of the tenth cycle, if no read\nerrors were encountered in cycles one through ten, the error count is\nreset\xc2\xb7 to zero. The error count is used by General Data Acquisition in\nits determination to annunciate PMU failures.\nd.\n\nOutputs - Outputs from this module are specified in Table 3.2.1.3.1-1.\n\ne.\n\nModule Acquire Interprocess Parms\n\n10/16/79\n3.2.1. 3.2-1\nBOOK: OfT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\n3.2.1.3.2\n\nGeneral Data AC9,uisition (SGA_GEN_ACQ)\n\nGeneral Data AC9,uisition (GEN ACQUISITION) acquires\' and screens data from\nthe PCM Master Unit (PMU) and payload MDM\'s (PLMDM) for Basic Data AC9,uisition\nand Special Processes Data AC9,uisition.\na.\n\nControl Inter\xc2\xb7faces - GEN AC9,uisition is CALL\' ed by Basic Data\nAC9,uisition and Special Processes Data AC9,uisition. The specific\ndata to be aC9,uired and screened is controlled by tables passed via\nthe call list. II!JYOCAT~ON: CALL SGA_GEN_ACQ{SGA CALL)\n\nb.\n\nInputs - There are two types of input data to GEN AC9,uisition\n1.\n\n2.\nc.\n\nExternal data which is aC9,uired from the PMU, Payload MDM\'s and\nInterprocess COMPOOLS. Once this data is retrieved, and moved\nif needed, to either the PPB or CDA, it becomes input to the\nother SM functions.\nInternal tables (structures) which describe the external data\nor control processing (see Table 3.2.1.3.2-1).\n\nProcess Description - The control flow for this module is shown in\nFigures 3.2.1.3.2-1 through 3.2.1.3.2-11. Data aC9,uisition is\nseparated into 3 groups of data.\n1.\n\nPMU data is aC9,uired from the PMU and transferred to the INB\n(a temporary staging area for all parameters aC9,uired) by\npointing the FCOS to the PMU DAR\'r entries and issuing the FCOS\nI/O macro (IOMAC). The FCOS uses the DART information to build\nPMU I/O tables prior to initiating data transfer. Since the I/O\ntables are fixed length, FCOS accepts a limited number of entries\n(the maximum number of allowable entries is maintained in the\nCMT). ~rransfer of data is performed at the same priority as the\nGEN AC9,uisition task. GEN AC9,uisition issues the FCOS read\nmacro and waits until control is returned before continuing.\nAfter data transfer is complete, Data Screening interrogates\neach word group in the input buffer to determine if all data was\nsuccessfully transferred. (A word group is defined as being the\nresponse to a read cominand.) If no data transfer error occured\nparameters for Basic Data Acquisi.ti.on that are re9,uired and not\nscaled are moved to the PPB or non-FDA CDA and their I/O status\nflags are set to valid. The current read cycle\'s section of the\nDevice Input Buffer to PPB Cross Reference Table (IXP) is referenced to determine where a parameter is to be moved. Each IXP\nentry .consists of parameter control indicators and either a PPB or CDA.\n\n10/16/79\n-3.2.1. 3.2-2\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\xc2\xb7\n\nindex pointer. The control indicators contain a flag indicating\nwhether or not the parameter is to be limit sensed. Parameters\nthat are to be scaled remain in the input buffer, but a valid\nI/O status is set in the correct table for each parameter\n(forward scaling converts and moves\xc2\xb7the parameter to correct\ntable). Parameters that are to be limit sensed are moved to the\nPPB. Parameters with dual limit sets are moved to two locations\nin the PPB (reference section A.2.2). Parameters that are "display only," SCM oniy, or input to Precondition Processing only\nare moved to the CDA.\nAnalog parameters are 10 bit measurements residing in bits 1\nthrough 10 of the 16 bit field with the first bit indicating\narithemetic sign of the value. A zero bit indicates a positive\nvalue and a 1 bit indicates a negative value. When these\nparameters are moved, they are shifted to bits 7 through 16 of\nthe target field and the vacated bit locations, 1 through 6, are\nfilled with the sign bit.\nParameters successfully acquired for Special Processes remain in\nthe input buffer (SPINB) and their I/O status is placed in the\nI/O status area at the end of the SPINB.\nIf data screening reveals a transfer error, the I/O status\nflags for all parameters within the word group are set to invalid.\nThe PMU I/O error counter is updated and the error is annu:qciated\nif it is the third error.\nThe PMU read chain is modified to skip acquired data (and the\nfailing command if there was an error). This is done by pointing\nthe FCOS _to the next PMU. dart entry after the failing entry.\nThis procedure is repeated if there is more PMU data to be read\nand 2\xc2\xb7 errors have not occured.\n2.\n\nPayload data is acquired from the payload MDM\'s and transferred\nto the input buffer by means of fixed BCE programs. These programs utilize automatic element bypass and error annunciation.\nComfault bits are interrogated and if ON the I/O error log \xc2\xb7ptr in\nthe input buffer is set for use in screening. Comfault bits are\nset by FCOS to indicate I/O errors for reads utilizing fixed BCE\nprograms. Each bit represents one BCE element (i.e., one read\nrequest). See FCOS User\'s Guide paragraph 4.2 for more information.\n\nlO/16/79\n3. 2. 1. 3. 2- 3\n\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed\n\nD~lign\n\nSpecification\n\nParameters are moved from the input buffer in the\nas PMU data. Since error annunciation arid bypass\nFCOS, the I/O status flags for parms not acquired\ninvalid but no annunciation or retry is attempted\nAcquisition.\n3.\n\nsame manner\nis done by\nare flagged\nby General\n\nPLMDM reads are issued for all parms from the first requested\nparm to the last requested parm. within a channel. The extra\n\'Dummy\' parms are not moved from the input buffer. This is\ndone to make the PLMDM reads more efficient.\nIf there is a PMU bite read requested it is done in the same\nmanner as the PMU read except there is no error retry attempted.\n\nd.\n\nOutputs - Outputs from this module are specified in Table 3.2.1.3.2-1.\n\ne.\n\nModule References - Process\nDMAMAC\n\nf.\n\nSection\n\nReferences\n\nA System Software external procedure called when parameter fault\nannunciation is enabled by FMP_STAT\nmacro.\n\nModule Type and Attributes Type: External Procedure\nAttributes: Exclusive\n\ng.\n\nTemplate References D\nD\nD\nD\nD\nD\n\nINCLUDE\nINCLUDE\nINCLUDE\nINCLUDE\nINCLUDE\nINCLUDE\n\nCSAPPB\nCSACDA\nCSAIXP\nSMSTAT\nSGADUMST\nDMA#MACS\n\nParameter Processing Buffer (PPB)\nCurrent Data Array (CDA)\nINB to PPB XREF Table (IXP)\nReplaces for 10 Status\nDummy Structures for Call List\nSystems Services Error Annunciation\nMacro Replace Statements\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE CZl COMMON Systems Services Common Compool\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE CSA SM CMT Communications Table (CMT)\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE DMA MAC\nSystems Services Annunciation Routine\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE CDL ANNUN Systems Services Annunciation Compool\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE ANTMACS\nSystems Services SM PL Fixed Read\nReplace Statements\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE PFMDMACS\nSystems Services SM PL Mission Dependent Read Replace Statements\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE PMUMACS\nSystems Services PMU I/O Parameter Lists\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE IOMACS\nSystem Services I/O Macro Replace\nStatements\nFCOS Compool Containing Error Count\nD INCLUDE \'I\'EMPLATE FCMCOM\n\n10/16/79\n3.2.1.3.2-4\n\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\nh.\n\nError Handling - When an err.or is indicated during a chained read of\nthe PMU two additional attempts are made to acquire untransferred\nparameters. For read errors the chain is temporarily modified to\nskip acquired data and the failing command before the read is retried. This is done by pointing "the FCOS to the next PMU DART\nentry after the failing entry.\n\ni.\n\nConstraints and Assumptions - All discretes within an acquired word\nare acquired at the highest rate required for GPC processing of any\ndiscrete within the word.\n\nTABLE\n\n#\n\n3.2.1.3.2-1\n\nGeneral Data Acquisition\n\nITEM\n\nMODULE DATA LIST\n\nDESCRIPTOR\n\nACT\n\nSOU RCE/DESTI NATION\n\nHAL SP Bad I/O Move.\n\n10/16/19\n3.2.1.4-1\n\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Dt~ign Specification\n\n3.2.1.4\n\nPerformance Monitor Control (SPM_CONTROL)\n\nThe Performance Monitor (PM) Control module directs execution of the following SM functions: Precondition Processing and Fault Detection and Annunciation.\na.\n\nControl Interface - The PM Control module is SCHEDULE\'d by the SM OPS\nControl Segment and runs continuously while the OPS sequence is\nactive.\nInvocation:\n\nSCHEDULE SPM- CONTROL PRIORITY (PRIO- SPM)\n-\n\nb.\n\nInputs - Inputs to this module are specified in Table 3.2.1.4-1.\n\nc.\n\nProcess Description - The control flow for this module is shown in\nFigure 3.2.1.4-1 through 3.2.1.4-6. The PM Control module determines\nwhich Parameter Processing Buffer half to process by checking the\nPPB buffer half indicator. A "WAIT" is then issued on the appropriate\nready flag until Data Acquisition (Section 3.2.1.3.1) completes updating of that buffer half. This re:::ults in an effective execution\nrate of once per second.\nWhen the buffer half is available, the FDA inhibit indicator in the\nCommunications Table is checked. This indicator is set as a result\nof an item entry from the Table Maintenance SPEC function to disable\nFDA processing. When FDA is disablecl, PM Control updates the FDA\nCurrent Data Array (CDA) with th~ latest sample of each measurement\nin the PPB half being processed. If FDA is not suspended, PM Control\ncalls Precondition Processing and Fault Detection and Annunciation\n(FDA) .\nAfter FDA returns control, PM Control resets the appropriate ready flag\nin the Communications Table which indicates that the PPB half has\nbeen processed. This makes it avail~ili1e to Data Acquisition for use.\nThe PPB buffer half indicator is then updated to point to the other\nPPB buffer half. Control then retUTIlS to the top where PM Control\neither begins processing the next PPB buffer half or "WAIT"s for\nData Acquisition to complete its proeessing. This process continues\nin such a fashion until the Performance Monitor (PM) Control- cancel\nflag is set by OPS.c1eanup processing.\n\nd.\n\nOutputs - Outputs from this module are specified in Table 3.2.1.4-1.\n\n10/16/19\n3.2.1. 4-2\n\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\nReference\n\n3.2.1.5\n\nCALL\n\nFault Detection\nand Data Acquisition Indication\n\nDate:\n~age\n\n10/16/79,\n3.2.1. 5.... 1\n\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\n3.2.1.5\n\nPrecondition Processing (SPP_PRECON_PROCESS)\n\nThe Precondition Processing analyzes parameter values and statuses (precondition inputs) to determine which limit set to use for those parameters with\nmultiple limit sets. Limit set selection maybe for a single para~eter or\na group of parameters. ~~he selected limit Bet is used in subsequent FDA processing ..\na.\n\nControl Interface - Precondition Proces13ing is CALL\'ed by the PM\nControl module (SPM_CONTROL) once per second while FDA is enabled.\nINVOCATION:\n\nCALL SPP_PRECON_PROCESS\n\nb.\n\nInputs - Inputs to this module are spec:ified in Table 3.2.1. 5-1.\nInput data are contained principally in the Parameter Information\nTable (PIT), the Precondition Control Table (PCT), the Precondition\nGroup Table (PGT), and the Current Data Array (CDA).\n\nc.\n\nProcess Description - The control flow for this module is shown in\nFigure 3.2.1.5--2. When invoked, Precondition Processing sequentially processes all precondition groups as described below.\nThe warm-up count for each precondition group is initially\nset to the max warm-up value by the SM Preprocessor. When a new\nlimit set is selected, the warm-up count is set to 1. This count\nincremented by 1 each time precondition is called, until the warmup count is equal to the max warm-up value. Then the number of sets\nfor the preconditoin group being processed is calculated and saved.\nThe index to the set solution block is saved. The subject parameters are checked for validity (no input errors) and if they are\ndetermined to be valid, processing continues; otherwise, processing\nof this precondition solution is inhibited. The prime limit set\n(No.1) is selected for the affected group of parameters and a\none is ascribed to the number of limit sets selected. An interpreter\ntechnique is utilized to solve precondition solutions. The final\nl:Lmit set selection is made based on the precondition solutions.\nThis procedure is repeated for all precondition groups.\nThe input parameter validity check (Figure 3.2.1.5-3) records\ninput errors for parameters contained in each set. The number of\nparameters in each set, the parameter type, and CDA index are saved.\nDepending on the parameter type, the appropriate I/O status flag from\nthe CDA is stored in the invalid indicator.\nThe interpreter technique (Figure 3.2.1. 5-4) is utilized to\nperform the actual precondition solution. This technique uses a\ngeneralized routine including predefined parameter and logical\no:f?eration codes found in the PCT to arrive at the precondition\n\nDate:\nPage\n\n10/16/79\n3.2.1.5-2\n\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specificati-on\n\nsolution. For the analog and EU parameter types, the status flag is\nset equal to the combined high and low limit sense flags. For the\ndiscrete type, the status flag is set equal to the discrete value.\nA parameter condition flag is turned on or off depending on the parameter operation code and the status flag (see Figure 3.2.1.5-5). The\nparameter condition flag is set to 1 if the parameter value agrees\nwith the parameter Op Code. Otherwise it is set to a zero. For\ninstance, if the Parameter\' Op Code is in-limit then the parameter condition flag is set to one. The Precondition Grouping (Figure 3.2.1.5--6)\nactually provides the precondition solutions. The Parm Op Code\nindicates which test (=0, =1 in-limits, out-of-limits) should be\nperformed on each input parameter. The logical Combination (COMB)\nOp Code indicates that logical combination (and, or) should be performed on the results of the parameter tests.\nIn the case of precondition expressions of the form, (\'A=l\' or\n\'B=O\') and (\'C=O\' or \'D=l\') where the operators are parenthetically\ngrouped and where solution of the expression would result in a different\nresult were the grouping attribute not recognized, those components of\nthe expression within the groups are solved first, then the entire\nexpression is solved, left to right. The following example demonstrates\nprecondition grouping and the algorithm for obtaining a set solution.\nAssume A and B are discrete parameters, C is an analog parameter, and\nD is an EU parameter. Furthermore, the set solution expression is\n\'A=O\' or (\'B=l\' and \'C=IL\') and \'D=OL\' where IL is in limits and OL\nis out of limits. A=O assumes a value of 1 if discrete A has a value\nof O. Similarly, in-limit value, \'C=IL\' will have a binary value of\n1. The set solution expression will be coded as follows.\nParameter\n\nParm Op\nCode\n\nDefinition\n\nA\n\n1\n\n=0\n\nOr\n\nB\n\n2\n\n=1\n\nOr\n\nFirst\n\nC\n\n3\n\nAnalog, In\nLimit\n\nAnd\n\nLast\n\nD\n\n6\n\nEU, Out of\nLimit\n\nComb of\nCode\n\nPosition in\nParenthesized Group\n\nAnd\n\nThe sequential steps for the above set solution expression follows.\n\nDate:\n~age\n\n10/16/79\n3.2.1.5 .... 3\n\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\nStep 1\nSl=O\nS=l\nS=S or [A=Q]\ns=o or [A=QI\nS= ~=~\nOPSAVE=OR\n\n1\n2\n\n3\nL~\n\nPartial Set Solution\nSet Solution\n\n81= .,B=iJ\n\n5\n6\n7\n\nSl= ~=:!I and @=I~\nS=S OPSAVE Sl\nS=\'A=O\' or (\'B=l\' and \'C=IL\')\nS=S and rP=Ot~\nS= I[i=Qj .or \\ ~~:y and\n\n8\n\nI9=IrJ)\n\nand\n\nW=orJ\n\nSymbology\nSl\nS\n\n(\n\n)\n\n[\n\n]\n\nOR\nAND\nIL\n\nOL\n\nPartial Set Solution\nSet Solution\nGrouping\nParameter Op Code Expressed as a Logical Statement. (Enclosed).\n\'OR\' Combination Op Code\n\'AND\' Combination Op Code\nIn Limits\nOut of Limits\n\nThe final limit set selection is made as shown in Figure 3.2.1.5-7.\nIf the result of the precondition solution for a particular set is\ntrue, an indicator is stored in the PCT indicating the set selected\nfor this precondition group. If the precondition operation indicates\nthat more than one solution was satisfied, the prime limit set is\nselected for the affected group of parameters. Then the Precondition\nGroup Table is referenced so that the limit set selected may be\nchanged for all parameters contained in the affected group.\nIf no limit sets are resolved by the Precondition Process, the\nprime limit set is selected.\nIf the limit set selected from the precondition solution changes\nfrom the last selection and the max warm-up time is ended, the active\nlimit set number in the PIT f0l\' each a:fected analog or EU parameter\nmust be updated. The current noise count is reset to zero and the\nhard fail indicator and FDA bypass indicator are reset to off .\n. If the parameter affected by the precondition solution is a discrete, thec1).rrent noise count is reset to zero, the active limit set\nis updated, and the hard fail indicator and FDA bypass indicator for\n\nDate: 10/16/79\'\n3.2.1. 5-4\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\nthat parameter are reset to Off in the Discrete Measurement Subentry\nTable (DMST - a subset of the discrete parent word PIT). The parent\nword entry for that discrete is then located in the PIT and the \'MASK2\'\nportion of that entry is changed and the parameter count field (if\nthat parameter is currently in a max good or fail state) is updated.\n(Mask 2 contains the limit status of the parent while parameter count\nis an internal indicator used by the limit sense routine to determine\nif it is necessary to perform limit sensing on the discretes.)\nIf the limit set selected from the precondition solution changes\nfrom the last solution for the first time (no warm-up time expired)~\nthe warm-up time is set to one. FDA is disabled for all parameters in\nthe group by setting the FDA bypass flag to ON in the PIT. Also, the\nlimit sense indicators are disabled (set off). Finally the last set\nselected is set to 0, indicating the start of warm-up time.\nd.\n\nOutputs - Outputs from this module are specified in Table 3.2.1.5-1.\nOutputs affected by the Precondition Processing routine consist of\nthe last solution indicator in the PCT and other items contained in\nthe PIT. The PIT fields, as updated by Preconditioning, control later\nprocessing by the FDA routine.\n\ne.\n\nModule References - None\n\nf.\n\nModule Type and Attributes\nType: External Procedure\nAttributes: Default (serially reusable with no protective mechanism)\n\ng.\n\nTemplate References\nD INCLUDE CSAPCT\nD INCLUDE CSAPIT\nD INCLUDE CSACDA\n\nh.\n\nPrecondition Tables (PCT and PGT)\nParameter Information Table (PIT)\nCurrent Data Array (CDA)\n\nError Handling - Precondition Processing performs the following types\nof error detection/processing:\ne\n\ne\n\nIf any parameter input to any set of that precondition\nis found with an invalid parameter validity indicator,\nprocessing of that solution is inhibited and the prime\n(limit set 1) is chosen for all parameters affected by\ntion.\n\nsolution\nfurther\nlimit set\nthat solu-\n\nIf more than one limit set is selected during processing of a\n. particular solution, processing will select the prime limit set\nfor all parameters affected by that solution.\n\nDate:\n\n10/16/79\n\n~e,ge\n\n3.2.1. 5... 5\n\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Desi~ln Specification\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n1.\n\nIf no limit set is selected during processing of a precondition\nsolution, the prime limit set is selected.\n\nConstraints/ Assmnptions\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\nA maximum of three limit sets may be specified for any preconditon\nsolution.\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\nThe prime limit set is always limit set one.\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\nA maximum of four parameters may be specified in a precondition\nsolution to select a limit set.\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\nOnly one level of parenthesis is permitted for a precondition\nsolution. Below are examples of valid and invalid precondition\nequations for a single set. Figure 3.2.1.5-1 shows more example\nprecondition relationships.\nA=l OR B=l AND C=l OR D=OL* Valid\n(A=l OR B=l) AND C=l OR D=OL Valid\n(A=l OR B=l) AND (C=l OR D=OL) Valid\nA=lOR (B=l AND (C=l OR D=OL)) - Invalid, 2 levels of\nparentheses\n*OL = Out of Limits\n\nDate: 10/16/79\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\nPage:\n\n3.2.1.5-6\n\nEXAMPLE PARAMETER RELATIONSHIP IN PRECONDITION PROCESS\nPrecondition\nGrou\xc2\xa3s\n\nPrecondition Set\nSolutions\nGRPA\n\nPredefined Limit Sets\nSet\nLow\nHigh\nLimit\nLimit\n_#1\n\n175\n\n212\n\n2\n\n185\n\n222\n\nV92X0623X=1\n\n3\n\n195\n\n238\n\n(V61S2704E=1 and V61K2711Y=1)\nor V61S2709E=1\n\n1\n\n50\n\n75\n\n(V6152709~=0 and V6152704E=O)\nor (V6152704E=1 and\n. Limit Set Selection\n\nSet FDA By-Pass\nndicator To ON.\nSet Umit Sense High\nand Limit Sense Low\nIndicators to OFF\n(Analog Section) (PIT)\n\nIF Parm\nType=l\n(Analog}\n\nf-\'\n\nSet FDA By-Pass\nIndicator To ON.\nSet Umit Sense High\nAnd Limit Sense Low\nIndicators to Off.\n(EU Section) (PIT)\n\nVl\n\nI\nf-\'\n\nVl\n\nf-\'\n___\n0\n\nf-\'\n0"\\\n\n----<\n\n\\0\n\n10/16/79\n3.2.1. 5-19\n\nConvert DMST\nParent Position\nFrom PGT To\nInteger\n\nConvert Discrete\nPosition In\nParent To\nInteger\n\nIF Current\nNoise Count EQ\nMax \'N\' Count\n\nThen\n\nDecrement\nParent Word\nParameter\nCount (PIT)\n\nUpdate Mask2 (PIT);\nZero Current Noise\nCount (DMST); Set\nHard Fail Indicator\nAnd FDA By-Pass\nIndicator Off (DMST)\nUpdate Active Limit\nSet (DMST)\n\nFigure 3.2.1.5-8. Discrete Limit Update\n\nloS"\n\n10/16/79\n3.2.1.6-1\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\n3.2.1.6\n\nFault Detection and Annunciation (SFD_FAULT_DETECT_ANNUN)\n\nThe Fault Detection and Annunciation (FDA) function executes cyclically,\nwhen enabled, to perform the limit sense and false alarm avoidance functions on\nparameters that have limits defined and to initiate the annunciation process for\nthose which have failed.\na.\n\nControl Interface - FDA is CALL\'ed by the PM Control Module (SPM\nPEHFORM_MON_CONTROL) while FDA is enabled.\nInvocation:\n\nCALL SFD FAULT DETECT ANNUN (Analog PPB Pointer,EU PPB\nPointer,-Discrete Parent PPB Pointer)\n\nb.\n\n~~\n\n- Inputs to FDA are PPB pointers passed in the Call list as\ndiBcussed above and various table entries of information needed to\nperform fault detection and annunciation on each parameter. Parameter\nvalues and corresponding I/O statuses are located in the Para:rp.eter\nProcessing Buffer (PPB). Other information such as noise counts,\nlimit status flags, limit values for discrete parameters~ pointers to\nvarious tables and annunciation information is located in the Parameter Information Table (PIT). Limit values for analog and EU parameters\nreBide in the Limit Sense Table (LIT). All such table information\nreBides in COMPOOL and is further described in Table 3.2.1.6-1.\n\nc.\n\nProcess Descrip~tion - The control flow is presented in Figures 3.2.1.6-1\nthrough 3.2.1.6-:-7. The Fault Detection and Annunciation (FDA) module.\nis a table driven processor. When initiated from PM Control, FDA\naceesses the Parameter Information Table (PIT) and initiates processing\non the first entry in the PIT. Every sample of a parameter is processed.\nParameter samples are buffered by the Data Acquisition module in the\nParameter Processing Buffer (PPB).\nAceess into the PPB is gained through the PIT. This accessing is not\ndone by means of an index in the PIT for each parameter, but rather a\nmapping scheme which relates the location of a parameter in the PIT\nto its location in the PPB. The PIT is organized into 9 sections 3 blocks (a block each for analogs, EU, discretes) of 3 groups each\n(5 sis, 1 sis, .5 sis). The.5 sis group if further subdivided into\ntwo sections - one for those parameter samples acquired in Data Acquisition cycles 1-5 and one for those acquired in Data Acquisition cycles\n6-10. The PPB :t s also organi zed into 9 blocks with the same arrangement;\nhmrever, the PPB is further subdivided such that parameter samples\nacquired in Data Acquisition cycles 1-5 are located in the 1st half of\nthe PPB and samples acquired in Data Acquisition cycles 6-10 are located\nin the 2nd half of the PPB. On any entr.r to FDA, data is processed from\neither the 1st half of the PPB or the 2nd half as determined by PPB\npointers passed to FDA in the CALL list.\n\n10/16/79\n3.2.1.6-2\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\nParameters that have both ALARM CLASS 0,3 or 4 and ALARM CLASS 2\nlimits specified have two PIT entries and respective PPB entries such\nthat the ALARM CLASS 2 limit entry follows the ALARM CLASS 0,3 or 4\nlimit entry. Thus, all FDA processing is performed on both entries,\nas if they were different parameters.\nFDA processing is performed serially on all analog parameters, all EU\nparameters, then all dis crete parent words (Figure 3. 2.1. 6-1) . The\nlogic and control of analog and EU processing is identical and thus\ndiscussed but once. Applicable control flows are Figures 3.2.1.6-2,\n3.2.1.6-3 and 3.2.1.6-4. It should be noted that the processes use a\nunique portion of the tables - PPB, LIT, PIT and CDA. The HAL/S\nNAMECOPY facility is utilized to .manipulate table pointers such that\nportions of both the analog and EU tables (PIT and PPB) mav be referenced by the same identifiers. This allows usage of the same routine\nto process both analog and EU parameters. In some instances, unique\nidentifiers must be used since the table entries are different data\ntypes. For example, analog parameter values in the PPB are integer\nwhereas EU values are scalar.\nDiscrete processing is unique and thus discussed separately. \'Applicable\ncontrol flows are Figures 3.2.1.6-5, 3.2.1.6-6 and 3.2.1.6-7.\nAnalog/EU Processing (Figure 3.2.1.6-2)\nFDA interrogates the "FDA BYPASS" indicator in the PIT entry for each\nparameter to determine if FDA processing is bypassed for that parameter.\nThe "FDA BYPASS" indicator is set on by precondition processing for each\nparameter of a group during group "warmup" and reset by precondition processing when "warmup" is completed (ref. Section 3.2.1.5). In any case,\nparameters with the "FDA BYPASS" flag enabled do not undergo FDA processing; however, the last sample and associated I/O status are moved\nfrom the PPB to the CDA, and the limit status indicators are cleared.\nFDA processes successive PIT entries similarly until a parameter that\nis not bypassed is found. All samples from one second of data are processed for that parameter as follows (see Figure 3.2.1.7-3):\nStatus flags in the PPB are checked to d~termine if the parameter\nsample is valid. If a sample is invalid, further FDA processing\nof that sample is skipped. Limit sense processing is thus performed on all valid samples of that parameter. FDA obtains the\ncurrent sample from the PPB and the\' current limit values from the\nLimit Table (LIT). An indicator of the current limit set is found\nin the PIT entry for this parameter. The current value is compared\nto the high limit, then the low limit. If either of these comparisons results in an indication that the current value is beyond\none of the limits, the parameter is determined to be out of limits.\nNoise filtering is then performed (see Figure 3.2.1.6-4).\n\n10/16/79\n3.2.1. 6-3\n\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\nIf the limit status for this parameter has. changed from in limits\nto out of limits (or vice versa), the current noise (n) count is\nreinitialized and the limit status for this parameter is updated\nin the Analog/EU portion of the PIT. Checks are then made on the\nparameter\'::; n count and the limit status and annunciation status\nto determine if annunciation should be enabled. A limit failure\nis annunciated only if three conditions have been met:\n1.\n\nThis parameter has failed limit sense processing n (maximum\ncount) consecutive times.\n\nno~se\n\n2.\n\nAnnunciation for this parameter is not inhibited (Annunciation Inhibit indicator in PIT is off).\n\n3.\n\nThis parameter is not currently in a "hard fail" state i.e., it has not previously been out of limits or it was\nout of limits and subsequently came into limits In\' consecutive times. (Hard Fail Indicator in PIT)\n\nAnnunciation is enabled by issuing a User Interface Macro. Inputs\nto the Macro are an index to a system Fault Message Parameter Table\n(FMPT) and a limit status indicator. The FMPT index resides in the\nPIT entry of each parameter. Annunciation for ALARM CLASS a parameters causes no alarms or fault messages to be generated.\nWhen the last sample of a parameter has been processed, FDA moves\nthat sample and its associated I/O status to the FDA CDA. Processing continues on all analog/EU parameters (PIT entries) until\nall have been processed.\nDiscrete Parent Processing (Figure 3.2.1.6-5)\nDiscrete FDA processing of parent words is similar to analog/EU processing except there is no "FDA BYPASS" logic with discrete parents.\nA "FDA BYPASS" indicator is associated with each parameter within a\nparent and is discussed later. All samples from one second of data are\nprocessed for each discrete parent as follows\xc2\xb7 (see Figures 3.2.1. 6-5\nand 3.2.1. 6-6):\n\nr/o Status flags in the PPB are checked to determine if the parent\nword sample is valid. If the sample is invalid, further FDA processing of that sample is skipped. Limit sense processing is thus\nperformed only on all valid samples of that parameter (Figure\n3.2.1. 6-6) .\nThe FDA parameters within a parent word are isolated by using MASK I\nin the parent word PIT entry and the parent word is limit sensed.\nIf any parameter within the parent word is out of limits, or the\n\n10/16/79\n3.2.1. 6-4\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\nParameter Count (number of parameters within the parent that\nhave reached max \'n\' count) does not equal the number of\nFDA parameters within the parent, limit sensing is performed on\neach discrete within the parent. The Discrete Measurement Subentry\nTable (DMST) is used to control limit sensing and noise filtering\nfor the discrete parameters. The parent word\'s PIT entry contains\na pointer to the sequential DMST entries for the parent word.\nThe "FDA BYPASS" indicator in the DMST is interrogated to determine if this discrete parameter is to be FDA processed. If the\nparameter is to be FDA processed, Discrete Measurement Limit Sensing and Noise Filter is performed (Figure 3.2.1.6-7). The\ncurrent value of this parameter sample is compared to its "expected"\nlimit in the MASK 2 entry in the PIT to determine the current limit\nstate. The \'expected\' state of MASK 2 can either be set to the\n\'should be\' or \'should not be\' state according to the state of the\ndiscrete described below. ~he SM Offline Preprocessor initializes\ndiscrete limits to the \'should be\' state. If the current limit\nstatus differs from the last sample of this parameter, the \'n\' count\nis reinitialized and the limit status for this parameter is updated\nin the limit status field of the PIT. If this parameter changed\nfrom a maximum good state (has been within limits \'n\' consecutive\ntimes) to a fail state or from a hard fail state to an in limits\nstate, the Parameter Count of this parent word is decremented.\nOnce the parameter\'s current noise count equals the maximum noise\ncount, the \'Parent Word Parameter count\' is incremented. If a fail\nstate has occurred, the User Interface Annunciation Macro is issued\nprovided the \'Annunciation Inhibit Indicator\' and the \'hard fail\nindicator\' are off. The hard fail indicator is then turned on and\nthe \'should be\' state in MASK 2 is changed to the \'should not be\'\nstate. This is done to avoid limit sense processing on individual\ndiscretes once they reach a hard fail state.\nIf the parameter has reached a maximum good state, a check is made\nto see if the hard fail indicator is on. If so, the \'should not be\'\nstate in MASK 2 is changed back to the \'should be\' state and the\nhard fail indicator is reset.\nWhen the last sample of a parent word has been processed, that sample\nand its associated I/O status are moved from the PPB to the CDA. The\nlimit status is moved from the PIT to the CDA. Processing continues on\nall parent words (PIT entries) until all have been processed. When\nDiscrete Parent processing is complete, FDA returns control to the\nCALLing function (PM Control).\n\n10/16/79\n3.2.1. 6-5\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\nd.\n\nOutputs - Outputs from this module are specified in Table 3.2.1.6-1.\n\ne.\n\nModule References - Process\nDMAMAC\n\nf.\n\nSection\n\nReference\n\nA System Software external procedure\ncalled when parameter fault annunciation is enabled by FMP STAT macro.\n\nModule Type and Attributes\nType: External Procedure\nAttri"butes: Default (serially resusable with no protective mechanism).\n\ng.\n\nTemplate References\nD\nD\nD\nD\nD\nD\n\nINCLUDE\nINCLUDE\nINCLUDE\nINCLUDE\nINCLUDE\nINCLUDE\n\nTEMPLATE CDL ANNUN - Systems Serv~ces Annunciation Compool\n- -Current Data Array (CDA)\nCSACDA\nCSAPIT\nParameter Information Table (PIT)\nCSAPPB\n- .Parameter Processing Buffer (PPB)\nCSALIT\nLimit Sense Table (LIT)\nDMA#MACS\nSystems Services error annunciation macro\nreplace statements\nD INCLUDE SMSTAT\nStatus field replace statements\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE DMA MAC\n- Systems Services Annunciation routine\nh.\n\nError Handling - None\n\ni.\n\nConstraints and Assumptions - None\n\n3.2.1.6-1\n\nTA!!LE\n\ntI\n1\n\nFAULT DETECTION AND ANNUNCIATION\n\nITEM\n\nAnalog PPB Pointer\n\nDESCRIPTOR\n\nMODULE DATA LIST\n\nACT\n\nSOURCE/DESTI NATION\n\nHAL NAME\n\nMML\n\nREOT.\n\nSYMBOL\n\n=\n\nI\n\nE\n\nCALL LIST\n\nSFD_PPBA_HALF\n\nQ\nQ\n::l1li:\n.,\n\nSFD_PPBE_HALF\n\nQ\n\nSFDYPBP_HALF\n\n-t\n\n3:\n\n2\n\nEU PPB Pointer\n\nE\n\nI\n\nCALL
