Discrete Measurement Limit Sense And Noise Filter\n\nV1\n\nReset Hard Fail\nIndicator For\n\nThis Parameter\n\n10/16/19\n3.2.1.7-1\n\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Desigl1 Specification\n\n3.2.1.7\n\nForward Scaling (SFS_FOR_SCALE)\n\nThe Forward Scaling function performs the logic necessary to convert parameter values from PCM units to engineering units. Forward Scaling for display\npurposes is performed by UI and not by this function.\na.\n\nControl Interface - The forward scaling module is CALL\'ed by any SM\nfunction which requires first, second or third order forward scaling\nsolutions. Functions which use this conversion routine are SM Data\nAcquisition, Special Processes Data Acquisition, Table Maintenance,\nand Table Maintenance Cyclic Update.\nThe Table Maintenance Cyclic Update routine converts analog parameter\nvalues to engineering units for display. The Table Maintenance process\nconverts limit values (in analog format) to engineering units for display. Special Processes Data Acquisition converts all special processes\nanalog input parameters to engineering units for processing. SM Basic\nData Acquisition converts analog parameters that require 2nd or 3rd\norder scaling and first order analog parameters with negative slopes that\nare to be processed by Fault Detection and Annunciation. Those analog\nparameters (first order non-negative slope) that are processed in analog\n(integer) format throughout basic SM processes are converted to engineering units for display by the System Software Cyclic Display Processor.\nInvocation:\n\nCALL SFS FOR SCALE (address pointer into SXT, number of\nparameters to be scaled);\n\nb.\n\nInputs - Inputs to this module are specified in Table 3.2.1.7-1.\n\nc.\n\nProeess Description - The control flow for this module is shown in\nFigures 3.2.1.7-1 through 3.2.1.7-3. Forward sealing converts multiple\nanalog PCM count parameters to engineering units. The calling routine\nprovides, in the Call List, SXT and SAT, information necessary to scale\neach parameter. This information consists of the nUJl1ber of parameters\nto be scaled, pointers to the PCM value, coefficients, status word,\ncurve order, and output target location. The acquisition status of\neach parameters is checked to determine if offscale checking is to be\nperformed. If acquisition status is good, the off-scale checks are\nmade and the value is scaled. If the value is off-scale high or low,\nan appropriate indicator is set in the status word. The coefficients\nare obtained from the SAT and the parameter is scaled. The solution is\nplaeed in the output target location.\nForward scaling is performed by the follo\xc2\xb7wing equations. X is the value\n(PCM count) to be scaled and AO\' AI\' A2, and A3 are the scale coefficients from the BAT.\n\n10/16/79\n3.2.1. 7.,..2\n\\\n\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\nThird degree:\n\nEU= A3x3 + A2X2 + AIX + Ao\n\nSecond degree:\n\nEU= A2X + AIX + AO\n\nFirst degree:\n\nEU= AIX + Ao\n\n2\n\nd.\n\nOutputs. - Outputs from this module are specified in Table 3.2.1.7-1.\n\ne.\n\nModule References\n\nf.\n\nModule Type and Attributes\n\nNone\n\nType: External Procedure\nAttributes: Reentrant\ng.\n\nTemplate References - None\n\nh.\n\nError Handling. - None\n\ni.\n\nConstraints and Assumptions - None\n\n122,\n\nTA!lLE\n\n3.1.2.7-1 FORWARD SCALING\n\nif\n\nITEM\n\nMODULE DATA LIST\n\nDESCRIPTOR\n\nACT\n\nSOURCE/DESTINATION\n\nHAL NAME\n\nMML\n\nREQT.\nSYMBOL\n\nm\no\n\no\n\n..\n\n~\n\n1\n\nForward Scaling\nCALL LIST\n\nE\n\nI\n\nSDA, SSD\n\n2\n\nAddress Pointer Into SXT\n\nE\n\nI\n\nCALL LIST\n\nSFS_SXT\n\n3\n\nNumber of Parameters\nTo Be Scaled\n\nE\n\nI\n\nCALL LIST\n\nSFS_NUMYARMS\n\n4\n\nPointer to Analog Input\nValue\n\nE\n\nL\n\nPointer to EU Output\n\nE\n\nL\n\nSXT_EU_VAL\n\no\n\n\'...."\n"\n\n(I)\n\n5\n\n!\n\n6\n\nE\n\nL\n\nSXT_SAT_ PTR\n\n7\n\n\\d-\n\nPointer to Coefficients\nPointer to Status Word\n\nE\n\nL\n\nSrr_STATUS\n\n8\n\nCurve Order\n\nE\n\nL\n\nSFS_CO\n\n9\n\nI/O Status Indicator\n\nE\n\nL\n\n10\n\n10\n\nOff-Scale Indicators\n\nE\n\nL\n\nSCALE_HI\nSCALE..J.OW\n\nL\n\nSFS30EF\n\nL\n\nSFS_EU\n\nI\n\n..\n_.\n\na\nCD\n\nSrr_ANA_VAL\n\nLocation\n\n~.\n\n:I:\nI\xc2\xbb\n\na\n_.\nen\n\nCD\nCI.\nCD\n\n11\n\nCoefficients\n\n12\n\nE.U. The analog backward scaling routine uses a call\nlist to obtain the coefficients, status indicator,value to be scaled,\nand output target location. Once the coefficients are obtained the\nvalue is scaled and the PCM result is off-scale checked. If the value\nis off-scale high or low, an indicator :is returned to the calling\nroutine.\nBackward scaling is performed by the following equation.\nare the scale coefficients).\nPCM\n\n(Ao and Al\n\n= ---EU \xc2\xb7-Ao\nAl\n\nd.\n\nOutputs - Outputs from this module are specified in Table 3.2.1. 8-1.\n\ne.\n\nModule References - None\n\nf.\n\nModule Type and Attributes\nType: External Procedure\nAttributes: Reentrant\n\ng.\n\nTemplate References - None\n\nh.\n\nError Handling - None\n\ni.\n\nConstraints and Assumptions - Only first order parameters are backward\nsealed.\n\nTA!\'!LE\n\nII\n\n3.2.l.8~1\n\nBackward Scaling\n\nITEM\n\nDESCRIPTOR\n\nMODULE DATA LIST\n\nACT\n\nSOU RCE/DESTI NATION\n\nHAL NAME\n\nMML\n\n=\n\nREQT.\nSYMBOL\n\no\no\n\n=-=\n..\n\n1\n\nBackward Scaling Call\nList\n\nE\n\nL\n\n2\n\nCoefficient Pointer\n\nE\n\nL\n\nCALL LIST\n\nSBS_SATyTR\nSBS_EU_VAL\n\no\n\n3\n\nEU Value\n\nE\n\nL\n\nCALL LIST\n\n4\n\nOff Scale Flag\n\nE\n\nL\n\nCALL LIST\n\n5\n\nPCM Value\n\nL\n\nCALL LIST\n\nSBS_PCM_VAL\n\n6\n\nCoefficients\n\nE\n\nL\n\nSAT\n\n~\n(I)\n\nSBS_OFF_SCALE\n\nE\n\n"\'1\'1\n\nCOEF\n\n3:\n\n~\n\nt\'D\n\nAI\n\nt\'D\nC.\n\n~\n\nt\'D\n\n(II\n\n=\n=\nen\n\ni\n\nI\n,\'-..\n\n~.\n\n\'C\nCD\n\nn\n\nn\n\n...\n;"\n\n~\n\nI\xc2\xbb\n\n=\n\n"dt:1\n\n~~\n\n\'" \'"\n\'" \'-\n\nW\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n>-\'\n0\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2 >-\'\n>-\' 0\\\n\n\xc2\xb7\n\n\'-\n\nCD--l\n\n\'\'\'\'\n\'"\n\n\\\n..//\n\n\'\\\n\n\'\\\n\n10/16/79\n3.2.1.8-3\n\nset;]\nOffscale\nFlag = ON\n\nSet\n\nOffscale\nFlan = OFF\nPCM Value = PCM\n\nFigure 3.2.1.8-1. Backward Seeilling\n\nDate 10/161\'79\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\n3.2.1.9\n\nPage\n\n3.2.1.9-1\n\n!~ecial Processes Executive (SSP_EXEC)\n\nThe Special Processes Executive controls the acquisition, processing and\noutput of data associated with special computations and sequences.\n\xc2\xb7a.\n\nControl Interface - The Special Processes Executive is SCHEDULE\'d\nat OPS initialization by the OPS control segment at a rate of five\ntimes per second.\nInvocation:\n\nSCHEDULE SSP EXEC AT PHASE SSP PRIORITY (PRIO_SSP),\nREPEAT EVERY TIME~SP;\n\nb.\n\nInputs - Inputs to this module are specified in Table 3.2.1.9-1.\n\nc.\n\nProcess Description - The control flows for the Special Processes\nExecutive is shown in Figures 3.2.1.9-1 through 3.2.1.9-3. The\nprocessing performed during each execution of the Special Processes\nExecutive is governed by the Hybrid Dispatcher and Hybrid Dispatch\nTable. The Hybrid Dispatcher is a HAL/S block of code which\nfacilitates the calling of procedures through the use of a table in\nthis case, the Hybrid Dispatch Table. This table is completely\ndiscussed in Appendix A.2.22. One complete executive cycle consists\nof ten executive executions (two seconds). Data acquisition, special\nprocesses (computations and sequences) and data output are assigned\nto specific cycles to permit load balancing. The current GMT time\nis obtained in cycle 1 for use in the various special processes.\nData Acquisition is called on assigned cycles as required by the special\nprocesses. Based on the phase count, the appropriate special processes are called. On the executive cycles in which fay10ad Bay\nDoors is called, the PBD active/inactive flag (set at Mode initialization)\nis checked to determine if the Payload Bay Doors is to be executed.\nIn executive cycle ten, Antenna Management is called and the Special\nProcesses Data Output module is called to output all special processes commands which are enabled.\n\nd.\n\nOutputs - Outputs to this module are specified in Table 3.2.1.9-1.\n\nDate: ! 10/16/79\nPage: 3.2. 1. 9-2\n\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\ne.\n\nModule References\nProcess\n\nReference\n\nSpecial Processes Data Acquisition\nAPU Fuel Quantity\nFuel Cell Computations\nHydraulic Water Boiler Quantity\nO/N 2 Quantity\n\n3.2.1.10\n3.2.1.12\n3.2.1.13\n3.2.1.14\n3.2.1.15\n\nCALL.\nCALL\nCALL\nCALL\nCALL\n\nH 0 Pump Delta Pressure\n2\nRecorder Position Tape\nFuel Cell Purge\nHydraulic Fluid On-Orbit Temperature\nControl\nPayload Bay Doors (OPS 202 only)\nStandby Water Coolant Loop\nTemperature Control\nAntenna Management\nSpecial Processes Data Out\nf.\n\nSection\n\n3.2.1.16\n\nCALL\n\n3.2.1.17 CALL\n3. 2 . 1. 18 CALL\n3 . 2. 1. 19 . CALL On Case Number\n\n1~5-\n\n10/161\'7?\n3.2~1.10-1\n\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\n3.2.1.10 \xc2\xa72ecia1 Processes Data Acquisition\n\n(SSD_pP_DAT~_ACQ)\n\nThe Special Processes (SP) Data Acquisition module causes the acquisition\nof all data required by Special Processes from the PCM Master Unit (PMU) and/or the\npayload MDM\' s. Data not acquired due to I/O failure is flagged invalid.\na.\n\nControl Interfa.ce - SP Data Acquisition is CALL\'ed by the SP Executive\nonce every second in OPS 201 and every ~\xc2\xb7OO MS in OPS 202.\nInvocation:\n\nb.\n\nInputs - Inputs to this module are specified in Table 3.2.1.10-1.\n\nc.\n\nProcess Description - The control flow for this module is shown in\nFigure 3.2.1.10-1. The full execution flag is first checked. If\noff, then the General Data Acquisition call list is set up with a\nDART header requesting only PLMDM data be acquired and processed\n(# of PMU entries = 0 and the lOB address is set to the first MDM\nentry the IOB). General Data Acquisition is CALLed to read PLMDM\ndata into SP Input Buffer (SPINE), screen for transfer errors, and\nmove the I/O status of each parameter to the end of the. lOB. The\nForwa.rd Scaling module is not called.\nIf the full execution flag is on, then the General Acquisition call\nlist is set up with a DART header requesting both PMU and PLMDM data\nbe acquired and processed and the lOB ad.dress is set to the beginning\nof the lOB. General Data Acquisition iEl called to read PMU and PLMDM\nda.ta. into the SP Input Buffer (SPINB), screen for transfer errors, and\nmove the 10 status of each parameter to the lOB. The foward scaling\nmodule is called to scale all analog parameters acquired and place the\nEU values in the SPINB.\n\nd.\n\nOutputs - Outputs from this module are specified in Table 3.2.1.10"\':1.\n\ne.\n\nModule Referenees Process\n\nSection\n\nGeneral Data Aequisition 3.2.1.3.2\nForward Scaling\n3.2.1. 7\nf.\n\nReference\nCALL(Call List)\nCALL(Call List)\n\nModule Type and Attributes -\n\nType: Extellnal Procedure\nAttributes: Default (serially reusable with no protective mechanism).\n\n- --- --- -- - SP Data Acquisition\n\n: 10/16/79\n3.2.1.11-1\n\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n3.2.1.11\n\nSpecial Processes Data Out (SSO_SP_DATA_OUT)\n\nThe Special Processes (SP) Data Out module writes all SP outputs to the\npayload MDM\' Band performfl all SP annunciation.\n\na.\n\nControl Interfaee - SP Data Out is CALL\' ed by the SP Executive once\nevery two seconds and by the Payload Bay Doors process whenever it\nhas commands to output.\n\nb.\n\n~~\n\nc.\n\nProcess Description - The control flow for this module is shown in\nFigure 3.2.1.11\xc2\xb7-1.\n\n/\n\n- Inputs to this module are specified in Table 3.2.1.11-1.\n\nIf Payload Bay Door (PBD) outputs are indicated, Payload Bay Door\nreset masks are set up for FCOS output processing and an FCOS macro\nis issued twice to output all PBD output parameters in the SP Output\nBuffer twice. Otherwise, reset masks are set up for FCOS output\nprocessing and an FCOS macro is issued to output all non-PBD SP\noutput parameters in the SP Output Buffer. Discrete parents common\nto PBD and the other processes are merged into one word for downlist.\nSP annunciation output processing is then performed. All annunciation\nindicators are scanned. Annunciation is enabled for those indicators\nthat have been set by other SP modules. Once annunciation has been\nenabled for a particular indicator, it is non re-enabled until that\nindicator has been reset (and processed by Special Processes Data Out)\nand subsequently set on again.\nd.\n\no~tEuts\n\ne.\n\nModule References DMAMAC\n\nf.\n\n- Outputs for this module are specified in Table 3.2.1.11..,1.\n\nA System Software external procedure CALL\'ed when\nparameter fault annunciation is enabled by FMP_ENABLE\n\nModule TYEe and Attributes ~rype :\nExternal Procedure\nAttributes: Default (serially reusable with no protective mechanism).\n\ng.\n\n~~emElate\n\nReferences -\n\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE DMA_MAC\nINCLUDE DMA#MACS\n\n:0\n\nD INCLUDE IOMACS\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE CSB_PBD_CMT\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE PFFOMACS\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE CZl COMMON\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE CSS=SPOB\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE CDL-ANNUN\n\nI C{ ()\n\nSystem Services Annunciation Routine\nSystems Services Error Annunciation\nMacro Replaces\nSystems Services 10 Macro Replaces\nPayload Bay Doors Communication Compool\nSYBtems Services SM PF Fixed Output\nReplace Statements\nConnnon Compool\nSpecial Processes Output Buffer\nSystems Services Annunciation Compool\n\n, 19/16/79 _\n3.2.1.11-2\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\nh.ErrorHandling - SPEC Processes Data Out\n\nj,-______\n\nL-_____\n\n~\n\nIssue UI Annunciation macro to\n\nenable Annunciation Of Error\n\n\xc2\xb710/16/79\n"3.2.1.12-1\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Desig" Specification\n\n3.2.1.12\n\nAPU Fuel Quantity (SSA- APU- FUEL- QTY)\n\n. The APU Fuel Quantity module executes cyclically to determine the\nquantity of fuel remaining in the APU fuel tanks .\n. a.\n\nControl Interface - The APU Fuel Quantity module is CALLed once\nevery two seconds by the Special Proc:esses Executive.\n\nb.\n\nInputs - Inputs to this module are specified in Table 3.2.1.12-1.\n\nc.\n\nProcess Description - The control flow for this module is shown\nin Figure 3.2.1.12-1. When called, the APU Fuel Quantity module\nperforms the following processing for each of the three APU fuel\ntanks. The denominator in the computation is computed first. If\nthe denominator is zero, the fuel tank quantity is set to zero.\nOtherwise, the fuel tank quantity is computed and a check is made\nto determine if the computed value lies in the range 0 to 100\ninclusive. If the value is less than 0, it is set to 0 and if\ngreater than 100, it is set to 100. The status of the input\nparameters are then checked. If any status is invalid, the output\nstatus is set to invalid. Otherwise:. it is set to valid. The\ncomputed value and .its status are then stored in the Display/\nDownlist table for display. The value is converted to PCM counts\nand stored in Special Processes Output Buffer (SPOB) for output\nto the meter and downlist.\n\nd.\n\nOutputs - Outputs from this module are specified in Table 3.2.1.12-1.\n\ne.\n\nModule References - None\n\nf.\n\nModule Type and Attributes\nType: External Procedure\nAttributes: Default (serially reusable with no protective\nmechanism) .\n\ng.\n\nTemplate References\nD\nD\nD\nD\nD\xc2\xb7\n\nINCLUDE T!~LATE CSS_COT_CONSTANTS TABLE (COT) - Values\nINCLUDE TI~LATE CSS_SPINB - Special Processes Input Buffer\nINCLUDE TEMPLATE CSS SPOB - Special Processes APU Fuel Quantity\n\n--<\n--\\0\n\n10/1617~\n\n3.2.1.13-1\n\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\n3.2.1.13\n\nFuel Cell Computation (SSF-YUEL_CELL)\n\nThe Fuel Cell Computation module executes to determine the total current and\npower of the fuel cells and. to set discretes to braeket the power level for each\nfuel cell.\na.\n\nControl Interface. - The Fuel Cell Computation module is CALLed once every\ntwo seconds by the Special Processes Executive.\nINVOCATION:\n\nb.\n\nInputs - Inputs to this module are specified in Table 3.2.1.13-1.\n\nc.\n\nProcess Description - The control flow for this module is shown in Figure\n3.2.1.13-1. When CALLed, the Fuel Cell Computation module checks the\nstatuses\xc2\xb7ofthe .input parameters\' for the fuel cell. .\xc2\xb7.If any are invalid,\nthe output status for the precondition dielcretes is set to invalid. Otherwise, the power level for the fuel cell is computed in kilowatts and compared\nagainst two power levels which define the break points between three ranges.\nPrecondition discretes,are set indicating the range the computed value lies\nin. The two power levels can be changed by Table Maintenance. The above\nis repeated for each of the other fuel cells.\nA check is then made to determine if any output status has been set to invalid by the previous computation. If so~, the output status for the total\nfuel cell power is set to invalid. OthervTise, the total fuel cell power\nis computed by summing the power levels from each individual. fuel cell and\nthe output status is set to valid. A status check is then performed on\nthe parameter used to compute the total current. If any are invalid, the\noutput status for total current is set to invalid. Otherwise, the total\ncurrent is computed by summing the individual currents from each fuel cell\nand the output status is set to valid.\n\nd.\n\nOutputs - Outputs from this module are specified in Table 3.2.1.13-1.\n\ne.\n\nModule References - None\n\nf.\n\nModule TYpe and Attributes\nType:\n\nExternal Procedure\n\nAttributes:\n\nDefault (serially reusable with no protective mechanism).\n\n10/16/79\n3.2.1.15-2\n\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\ng.\n\nTemplate References D INCLUDE\nD INCLUDE\nD INCLUDE\nD INCLUDE\n\nTEMPLATE CSS COT\nTEMPLATE CSS SPINB\nTEMPLATE CSS DDT\nSMSTAT\xc2\xb7\n\nCONSTANTS TABLE\nSPECIAL PROCESSES INPUT BUFFER\nDISPLAY/DOWNLIST TABLE\nSTATUS FIELD REPLACE STATEMENTS\n\n-\n\nh.\n\nError Hand1ipg - Power Level Discretes\n\n10/16/79\n3.2.1.14-1\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\n3.2.1.14\n\nHydraulic Water Boiler Quantity (SSH_HYD_H20_QTY)\n\nThe Hydraulic Water Boiler Quantity calculations module computes the amount\nof water remaining in the three storage tanks.\na.\n\nControl Interface - This module is CALI.\'ed by the. Special Processes\nExecutive (SS~_EXEC) once every two seconds \xe2\x80\xa2.\nINVOCATION:\n\nCALI. SSH_HYD_H20_QTY\n\nb.\n\n~1puts\n\nc.\n\nProcess Descri~ - The control flow for this module is shown in\nFigure 3.2.1.14-1. If the inputs needed for the hydraulic water boiler\nquantity computation for water tank 1 are valid, the hydraulic water\nboiler quantity remaining is computed using a pressure - volume - temperature (PVT) equation. The GN2 outlet pressure is analyzed to see if\nit is zero. If so, the hydraulic water boiler quantity is set to zero.\nOtherwise, the quantity of GN2 is calculated and that quantity is used\nin calculating the hydraulic water boiler quantity. A check is\nmade to determine if the computed value lies in the range 0 to 100 inclusive. If the value is less than zero, it is set toO and if greater\nthan 100, it is set to 100. The computed value and status are then stored\nin the I Display/Downlist table for display. The value is converted to PCM\ncounts and stored in the Special Processes Output Buffer (SPOB) for output to the meter and down1ist. If any input parameter for water tank 1\nhas an invalid parameter status, then the hydraulic water boiler quantity\niB set to invalid and the computation is bypassed. This same procedure is\nfollowed for computing the hydraulic water boiler quantities for water\ntank 2 and water tank 3. There is no OPS initialization or clean-up\nprocessing.\n\nd.\n\nOutputs - Outputs from this module are specified in Table 3.2.1.14-1.\n\ne.\n\nModule References - None\n\nf.\n\nModule Type and Attributes -\n\n- Inputs to this module are specified in Table 3.2.1.14-1\n\nType: External Procedure\nAttributes: Default (serially reusable with no protective mechanism).\ng.\n\nTemplate References D\nD\nD\nD\n\nINCLUDE\nINCLUDE\nINCLUDE\nINCLUDE\n\nTEMPLATE\nTEMPLATE\nTEMPLATE\nTEMPLATE\n\nCSA .COT\nCSA DDT\nCSA SPINB\nSPOB\n\nh.\n\nError Handling - None\n\ni.\n\nConstraints and Assumptions - None\n\nConstant Table (COT) - Values\nDisplay/Downlist Table\nSpecial frocesses Input Buffer (SPINB)\nSpecial Processes Output Buffer\n\n3.2.1.14-1 Hydraulic Water Boiler quantity\n\nTABLE\n\nMODULE F\n(V,\'IIid)\n\nThen\n\nSet Loop 2 Pump\nDelta Pressure\nStatus To ON\n(Invalid)\n\nif Loop 2\nPump Inlet Or\nOutlet Pressure\nStatus = ON\n(Invalid)\nElse\n\nCompute Loop 2\nPump Delta Pressure\nUsing Loop 2 Pump\nInlHt And Outlet\nPressures:\nP2 := Po2 - Pi2\n\n[t\n\nI\nLoop 2 Pump\n\nDelta Pressure\nStatus To OFF\n(Valid)\n\n(\n\nReturn\n\n~\n\nFigure 3.2.1.16-1. H20 Pump Deltill Pressure\n\nDate: 1/15/79\nRage3.2.l.l7~1\n\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\nThe Recorder Tape Position module computes the tape position for each of\nthese operational recorders (OPSl, OPS2, a~d payload),- and updates a three-deep\ndownlist buffer pushdown list if a new fault message has been generated by\nSystem Software annunciation. Each entry in this list contains the tape position\nand active track parameters for OPSI and OPS2 recorders and a current time.\na.\n\nControl Interface - The Recorder Tape Position module is called by\nthe Special Processes Executive (SSP_EXEC) once every two seconds.\n\nb.\n\nInputs - Inputs to this module are specified in Table 3.2.1.17-1.\n\nc.\n\nProcess Description - The control flow for this module is shown in\nfigure 3.2.1.17-1. The recorder tape position is computed consecutively\nfor all three recorders. If any input parameter status indicator for\na recorder is invalid, the status associated with that recorder tape\nposition output is set to invalid and the computation is bypassed.\nOtherwise, the recorder tape position is computed by isolating the\nfive bits in the input data word and con:verting them to integer format.\n\'rhis value is used as an index (one is added to preclude using a zero\nindex) into a 32 entry table. The values in this table represent the\ntape position output - 100/31 X rounded to the nearest integer. The\nstatus associated with the recorder tape position is set to valid and\n\xc2\xb7both the status and computation value are stored in the Display/Downlist\ntable (DDT).\n\'l\'he current time and percent tape and act.ive .track parameters from t.he\ntwo OPS recorders shall be logged every two seconds if the fault summary\nmessage (FSM) indicator has been set by Bystem software/annunciation. The\nl.ast three sets of these logged parameters will be maintained in a push\ndown list. The contents of the push down list will be made available for\nd.isplay and downlist. Once the recorder parameters and time tag for the\nICSM indicator have been logged the FSM indicator shall be reset. The FSM\nindicator will be initialized to off during OPS initialization.\n\nd.\n\n.Qutput - Outputs from this module are specified in Table 3.2.1.17-1.\n\ne.\n\nModule References - None\n\nf.\n\nModule Type and Attributes\n~lype:\n\nExternal Procedure\n\nAttributes:\ng.\n\nDefault (serially reuseable with no protective mechanism).\n\n\'l\'emplate Reference D INCLUDE TEMP:LATE CSS SPINB\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE CSS DDT\n\nSpecial Processes Input Buffer (SPINB)\nDisplay/Downlist Table\n\nh.\n\nError Handling - None\n\ni.\n\nConstraints and Assumptions - None.\n\nI\n\nt.c Five ffinput Bits Are Right Justifi~d.\n\nTo On\nIF Input Status\nIndicator is Set\niTo 1 For This Re-\n\n/\n\n/\n\n8\n\n~\no\n\n~\n\n~\n\n/\n\ncorder\n\nt:I\n\n(l)\n\nct\'\n\nIsolate 5 Input\nBits in Input\nWord Store In\nInteger Format\n\n....\n\'"\n\nObtain Tape Position From\nTape Position (POS) Table\nUsing Integer Value Of\nInput Bits (Plus 1) As\nAn Index\n\nf-\'\n\n(l)\n\n\'"\n\n\xc2\xa5\n\n"\n~.\n\n.g\'\n,IF Fault Summary\nMessage Indicator\nIs Set to 1\n\nMove OPS Downlists Buffer\n(2) To OPS Downlists Buffer (3) Move OPS Downlist\nBuffer (1) to OPS DOwn-\'\nlist Buffer (2)\n\n~\n\n~\n\nMove OPSI Active Track Input Value\nto OPS Downlist Buffer (1) Move\nOPSI Recorder Input Value to OPS\nDownlist Buffer (1) Move OPS2\nActive Track Input Value to OPS\nDownlist Buffer (1) Move OPS2 Recorder Input Value to OPS Downlist\nBuffer\' (1) Move GMT Time Tag To\nOPS Downlist Buffer (1)\n\nN\n\\\n\n"\n\n(l)\n\n....\n"\n;:i\n"\n~\n\n\\\n\n\\\n\\\n\\\n\\\n\\\n\n....\no\n\n"\n\nL\n\nFormat For 5\nInput Parameter Bits\n\note: One is Added To Pre,clude Using A Zero Index.\nValues Obtained From Tape\niPosi tion Table Correspond\nTo The Raw Data Value X\nTimes 100/31 rd. to neares\n\n~SB\noWO\n\nfu"lJ:i Parm Blt0> "\nInput\n1\n\'"\n\nInput\nInput\nInput\nInput\n\nFigure 3.2.1.17-1\n\nParm\nParm\nParm\nParm\n\n.\n\nBit\nBit\nBit\nBit\n\n45 67\n\n2\n3\n\n~SB\n\n1\'i\'1\'["\n\nB >4 "\n\n4\n5\n\nRecorder Tape Position\nW\n\nf-\'\n\n0\n\n\'" ""\n\'"\n~\n\n....\n....\n-0\nI\n\n\'"\n\n\\\n\n\'\\\n\n\'I\n\n~\n\n-<\n\nDate:\nPage\n\n10/16/79\n3.2.l.l~-l\n\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\nThe Fuel Cell Purge module provides automatie purging of the three fuel\ncells to maintain fuel cell operating efficiency.\na.\n\nControl Interface - The Fuel Cell Purge module is CALL\'ed by the\nSpecial Processes Executive once every two seconds.\nInvocation: CALL SSC_FUEL_CELL_PURGE;\n\nb.\n\nInputs - Inputs to this module are specified in Table 3.2.1.18-1.\n\nc.\n\nProcess Description - The control flows for this module a.re shown\nin Figures 3.2.1.18-1 through 3.2.1.18-9.\nThe I/O status of eaCh.\nswitch position measurement is first checked for validity. If valld,\nthat measurement value is moved to a save area -otherwise the save\narea is not overlayed. All subsequent references to these measurement\nvalues are from the save area, thereby insuring that only valid values\nare used.\nThe Fuel Cell Purge (FCP) module determines whether or not the FCP\nsequence is already in progress. If it is in progress, discrete parameters are checked to determine if the sequence should continue or\nterminate. If the sequence is to continue (FCP ON discrete is on),\nthe logic associated with the currently active timer is executed. There\nare five timers within theFCP sequence---the \'open\' W timer, the \'close\'\nW timer, the X timer, the y timer and the Z timer. After the purge valves\nare commanded open (closed), the \'open\' W ~imer and the \'close\'\nW timer areiused to provide a W-second delay prior to performing the\nvalve open (close) verification computation. The X timer is used to\ncontrol the time allocated (X minute delay time) for the purge lines\nto reach predefined temperatures. If the temperatures are not reached\nwithin the allotted time, annunication of that condition is enabled.\nThe Y timer i8 used to initiate the closing of a purge valve Y minutes\nafter the valve-open verification check was performed. The Z timer is\nused to delay commanding the purge line heaters off for Z minutes after\nthe last selected FCP valve is verified closed or fails to open (close)\n\xc2\xb7when commanded open (closed). Only one of these timers can be active at\nanyone time. The Y minute time is the only constant changeable by\nthe Table Maintenance Specialist Function.\nIf the FCP mod.ule determines that the FCP sequence is not in progress,\ndiscrete parameters are checked to see if conditions exist for initiating\nthe FCP sequence. Depending on these conditions, the Fuel Cell Purge\nInodule either initiates the Fuel Cell Purge sequence or exits. There\nis no OPS initialization or clean-up processing.\n\nd.\n\n9ut puts - Outputs from this module are specified in Table 3.21.18-1.\n\ne.\n\nModule References - None\n\nDate:\n\n\'R,a.ge\n\n10/161\'(9\n.3.2.1.18 ... 2\n\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\nf.\n\nModule Type and Attributes\nType: External Procedure\nAttributes: Default (serially reusable with no protective mechanism).\n\ng.\n\nTemplate Terminate FGP Sequence\n\nIS 7\n\nI\n\nDate\nPa~e\n\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\n3.2.1.19\n\nltx:draulic Fluid Temperature Contr,ol\n\n10/16/79\n3.2.1.19-1\n\n(SST_HYD_FLD~l\'EMP)\n\nThe Hydraulic Fluid Temperature Control module turns the three hydraulic\nf1uidpwnPB on and off in sequence, based on the monitoring of fluid temperature\nsensors in each of the three hydraulic systems.\na.\n\n_90ntrol Interfaces - his module is CALL\'d by the Special Processes\nExecutive (SSP~XEC) once every two seconds.\nInvocation:\n\nCALL SST HYD FLD TEMP\n\n\'b.\n\n,~nputs\n\nc.\n\nProcess Des-.\xc2\xa3!.:i12tion - The control flmTs for this module are shown in\nFigures 3.2.1.19-1 through 3.2.1.19-4. When this module is first called\nafter an OPS transition, the \'hyd fluid init flag\' is ON (set by OPS\ninitialization/cleanup module). This flag and the annunciation indicator\nare both turned off. AJ,so, the total priorities assigned, the priority\n#1 pump and all system priorities are set to 0 and allaN/OFF command\nindicators are set to off.\n\n- Inputs to this module are specified in Table 3.2.1.19-1.\n\nFor all subsequent calls to this module, the I/O status of each switch\nposition measurement is checked. If valid, that measurement value\nis moved to a save area; otherwise the save area is not overlayed. All\nsubsequent references to these sw\'itch measurement values are from the\nsave area, thereby ensuring that only valid (no I/O error) values are\nused. Each hydraulic system is consecutively processed in order to\nestablish which system, is any, is a candidate for having its circuJ,ation pum.p turned on or off. If the circulation pump switch is in the\nGPC positioll and a priority is not aBsigned to this system, temperature\nsensors are monitored for an out-of-limits low condition. The next\navailable priority is assigned to this system if one or more of its\ntemperature sensors is below limits. If the circulation pump switch\nis not in the GPC position and the system being processed has an\nassigned priority, the circulation pump turn off function is performed.\nThe position of the circulation pump switch is indicated by redundant\nmeasurements.\nAfter all hydraulic systems have been processed as described above, the\nsystem with priQrity 1 is checked for pump status.\nIf the pump has been commanded on, and if all of its temperature sensors\nare out-of-limits high, or the minim\'urn allowable continous run time for\nthe operating circulation pump is exceeded and another system is assigned\na priority, then the circulation pump turn off function is performed.\nIf the pump for this system has not been commanded on, the circulation\npump turn on process is performed.\n\nDate; 10/16/79\nPage\n\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\n3. 2 .1.l9~2\n\nThe circulation pump turn off function removes the priority for system,\nupdates priorities for all other systems, sets the hydraulic circulation\nannunciation indicator to off, and sets the circulation pump ON/OFF\ncommand indicators to OFF. The ON/OFF command indicators are redundant\noutputs and are subse~uently processed by the Special Process Data Out\n(section 3.2.1.11) to command the circulation pumps on or off.\n\'l\'he circulation pump turn on process is as follows:\nIf the delay time (Z minute time) has elapsed, check to see if any\npump, other than the Priority No. 1 pump, is on (use the pump pressure\ntest). If no other pump is on, command the Priority No.1 pump on and\nset\xc2\xb7the X timer to the earliest pump turn off time. Also set the\nhydraulic circulation pump annunciation indicator to OFF. If another\npump is on, set the hydraulic circulation pump annuniciation indicator\nto ON.\nd.\n\nOutputs - Outputs from this module are specified in Table 3.2.1.19-1.\n\ne.\n\nModule References - None\n\nf.\n\nModule TYEe and Attributes\nType:\n\nExternal Procedure\n\nAttributes:\ng.\n\nDefault (serially reusable with no protective mechanism).\n\nTemplate References\nD Include Template CSS SPINB\n\nSpecial Processes Input Buffer\n\nD Include Template CSS SPOB\n\nSpecial Processes Output Buffer\n\nD Include Template CSS COT\n\nConstants Table - values\n\nD Include Template CSS SP CMT\n\nSpecial Processes CMT\n\nh.\n\nError\n\ni.\n\nConstraints and AssumEtions - None\n\nHandlip~\n\n- None\n\nTABLE 3.2.1.19-1\n\n#\n\nHydraulic Fluid Temperature C\')ntrol\n\nITEM\n\nMODULE DATA LIST\n\nDESCRIPTOR\n\nI\n\nI\n\nMML\n\nHAL NAME\n\nSOU RCE/DESTI NAT! 3\n\nIF\nHydraulic\nFluid lnit Flag /\nOff\n\nThen\n\nSet Hydraulic\nCirc Pump\nAnnun Ind\nOff\n\nSet Hydraulic\nCirc Pump\nAnnun Ind\nOn\n\n~\n\nThen\n\n--\n\nIF\nSystem J Pump\nPressure> System\nJ Pressure Low\nLimit\n\nSet Hydraulic Sys I\neirc Pump On/Off\nCommand Ind A &\nHydr Sys I Circ\nPump On/Off\nCommand Ind B To\nOn\n\nSet Hydraulic\nFluid Init\nFlag Off\n\nFigure 3.2.1.19-3. eire Pump Turn ON\n\n\'7 {\\ L\n\'/\n\n(Iv\n\nJ\n\nThen\n\nSet Hydraulic\nFluid Init\nFlag On\n\nSet X-Timer\nEqual To Hydr\nSys I X Minute Timl\n+ SP Current Time\n\n10/16/79\n3.2.1.19-18\n\nObtain Number Of\nInput Temp Sensors\nFor System I From\nTemp Sensor Count\n\nDO FOR\nAll Input Temp\nSensors For Sys I\nWhile Hydr Fluid\nInit Flag Is Off\n\nif\nHydr Sys I Temp\n\nThen\n\n~-----I Sensor < Hydr Sys ) - - - - - i\n\nI Temp Lo Lim\n\nSet Hydr\nFluid Init\nFlag To On\n\nIncrement\nTotal Prior\nAssign By 1\n\nSet Hydr\nFluid Init\nFlag To Off\n\nSet Sys I Pri or\nNo. Equal To,\nTotal Prior\nAssign\n\nIF\nSys I\nPrior No.\n\'" 1\n\nThen\n\nSet Prior\nNo.1 Pump\nTo I\n\nI\nFigure 3.2.1.19-4. Priority Assignment Check.\n\nSet Z-Timer\nTo SP Current\nTime + Z-Minute\nTime\n\n/-\n\n-"\n\n10/16/79\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\n3.2.1.20-1\n\nThe Payload Bay Doors (PBD) module executes cyclically to open and close the\npayload bay doors and their associated latches.\na.\n\nControl Interface - The Payload Bay Doors module is CALL\'ed by the Special\nProcesses Executive once every 400 milliseconds while operating in SM OPS 202.\nInvocation:\n\nCALL SSB PL BAY DOORS\n\n- Inputs to this module are specified in Table 3.2.1.20-1.\n\nb.\nc.\n\n:t\n\n~euts\n\nProcess Description - The control flows for this module are shown in\nFigures 3.2.1.20-1 through 3.2.1.20-25. The Payload Bay Doors module\noperates in two basic modes, "auto" and "manual". The "auto" mode executes all the steps necessary to fully open or close the payload bay\ndoors. In the "manual" mode, desired latch group (s) or door (s) are\nspecified individually to be opened or closed. The above sequences are\ncontrolled from the PBD display and the three position PBD control\nswitch ("open", "stop" and "close").\nThe Payload Bay Doors module first determines if the power to drive the\nmotors for the latch groups and doors should be turned on or off. If so,\ncommands are enabled to turn the power on or off as desired. In addition,\nif the request is power off, an indicator is set to cause the PBD cyclic\nto turn off the reset masks for the power enable/disable \'B\' commands\nduring the next execution cycle. The position of the hardware PBD control\nswitch is then determined and made available for display. A capability is\nprovided to override the hardware PBD control switch position by item entry\non the PBD display. If this option is in effect, the hardware switch position will be overlayed by the item entry switch position. The above processing is performed on each execution. Here a check is made to determine\nif a full PBD execution is needed. This is done in the following manner.\nIf the full execute flag is on or the position of the PBD control switch\nhas changed since the last execution, then the remainder of this module\nis executed. Otherwise, it is bypassed and the end of program is\nexecuted. If the remainder of this module needs to be executed, then\nthe feedback status of each latch group and door is computed and made\navailable for display. Then the position of the PBD control switch is\nexamined. If the switch is in the "stop" position, a process is executed to determine if a new sequence has been selected. Sequence selection is done by the Payload Bay Doors Item Processor (Section 3.3.5)\nand executes asynchronously to the Payload Bay Doors cyclic processor.\nThe "auto" mode flag is .turned on if a manual sequence is selected. If\nthe switch position is "open" or "close", the mode flags are tested to\ndetermine the type of processing to be performed. The auto sequence\nenables the commands to open or close the payload bay doors and latches\nin a predefined order. Certain pairs of\' latch groups are opened or\nclosed concurrently. If feedback signals indicating open or close completion are not received before a predefined length of time, a fail in-\n\n10/161\'T9\nBOOK: OfT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\n3.2.1.20-2\n\ndicator is set and annunciation is performed. If the "manual" mode flag\nis on, cownands are enabled to open or close individual latch groups or\ndoors specified by items entered from the PBD display. The initial item\nmust be entered when the PBD control switch is in the "stop" position.\nSubsequent manual items can be entered with the switch in any position.\nAfter the commands are issued, no monitoring of them is done and no fail\nindications are given.\nIf the PBD control switch is returned to the "stop" position during an\n"auto" sequence, the sequence is considered suspended. Alli commands.:which have\nnot been verified shall be\xc2\xb7terminated. The sequence shall continue. from this\npoint whEm the PBD control switch is returned to the original "open" or\n"close" position. The terminated commands shall be reenabled and the\ntimer for fail indication shall be reset. If the PBD control switch is\nreturned to a different position other than the original, e.g. during an\n"auto" open sequence, the PBD control switch is turned to "stop" then\nreturned to the "close" position, the appropriate commands shall be enabled to perform the "new" sequence and the timer for fail indication is\nreset. In manual mode, return of the PBD control switch to the "stop"\nposition terminates all commands enabled for the selected options. A\nreturn to the "open" or "close" position for the "stop" position will\ncauSe the terminated commands to be reenabled provided the corresponding\noptions are still selected.\nWhen open or close commands are enabled or disabled during an auto sequence,\nentries are set or reset in an internal array called the commands enabled\narray to maintain the status of all the commands issued. This internal\narray facilitates the check to determine if commands have been issued for\nthe current latch group or door~\nWhen the PBD contro switch is in the "open" or "close" position, an\nEvent is set in the User Interface Compool Table CZl_COMMON to inhibit\nOPS/Mode termination. Any request to terminate will be rejected\nand a class 5 error message will be output. When the control switch is in\nthe "STOP" position, the event is reset in CZl COMMON to enable normal OPS/\nMode transition.\nWhen the Payload Bay doors module has completed, it checks an indicator to\ndetermine if it has commands to output. If so, the special process data\nOut Module is CALLED to perform this task.\nOnly parameters with valid input status are used in the sequence and made\navailable for display and downlist.\nThe following chart is a matrix that shows what events cause PBD processing indicators and flags to be reset:\n\n/\n\n\'\\\n\n10/16/79\n3.2; i. 20-3\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\n,\n\n-..::::::::::\n\nAffected~t\n\nIndicator\n\nNew\nPBD Sequence\nIs Selected\n\nSM OPS 202\nIs Entered\n\nRESET\n\nPBD Latch/Door\nFail Indicators\n\nPmrer On Item\n\nSM OPS 202\nIs Terminated\nRESET\n\nRESET\n\nRESET\n\nSET\n\nSET\n\n-\n\nPower Off Item\n\nRESET\n\nPBD Open/Close\nComplete Indicator\n\nAut\'o And Manual\nMode Ite:ms\nAuto and. Manual\nMod.e Flags\n\nRESET\n\nRESET\n\nRESET\n\nRESET\n\nCommon PBD Fail\nIndicator\n\ni\n\n!\n\nRESET\n\nDate 110/16/79\nPage\n\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\n3.2.1.20-4\xc2\xb7\n\nd.\n\nOutputs - Outputs from this module are specified in Table 3.2.1.20-1.\n\ne.\n\nModule References\nProcess\n\nReference\n\nSpecial Processes Data Out\nf.\n\nSection\n3.2.1.11\n\nCALL\n\nModule Type and Attributes:\nType: External Procedure\nAttributes : Default (serially reusable with no protective mechanism).\n\ng.\n\nTemplate References\nD\nD\nD\nD\nD\nD\nD\n\nh..\n\nINCLUDE\nINCLUDE\nINCLUDE\nINCLUDE\nINCLUDE\nINCLUDE\nINCLUDE\n\nTEMPLATE\nTEMPLATE\nTEMPLATE\nTEMPLATE\nTEMPLATE\nOPSTMACS\nTEMPLATE\n\nConstants Table (COT) - Value\nSpecial Processes Input Buffer (SFINB)\nSpecial Processes Output Buffer (SPOB)\nSpecial Processes CMT\nPayload Bay Doors CMT\nOPS Transition Macros\nsSO_SPyATA_OUT. The Standby Water Coolant Loop Control module\nfirst determines if the control timer has expired (current time is\ngreater than or equal to the control timer). If i t has expired, the\npump indicator is checked to determine whether to turn the pumps on\nor off. If the pump indicator is on, the pump indicator is turned\noff, the pump ON/OFF connnand indicatorB are set to turn off the pumps\nand the control timer is updated with the time to turn on the pumps.\nIf the pump indicator is off, the pump indicator is turned on, the\npump ON/OFF connnand indicators are set to turn on the pumps and the\ncontrol timer is updated with the time to turn off the pumps. At OPS\ninitialization (Section 3.2.1.1) the control timer is set to zero\nand the pump indicator is turned off. This causes the commands to\nturn on the plnnps to be enabled on the first execution of this module.\n\'l\'here is no OPS cleanup processing.\n\'I\'he elapsed time for the pumps to remain on (y time constant) and\nthe elapsed time for the pumps to remain off (x time constant) are\nchangeable by Table Maintenance.\n~\n\nd.\n\nOutputs - Outputs from this module are specified in Table 3.2.1.21-1.\n\ne.\n\nModule References - None\n\nf.\n\nModule Type and Attributes\n\'l\'ype: External Procedure\nAttributes: Default (serially reusable with no protective mechanism).\n\ng.\n\n\'l\'emplate References\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE CSS COT\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE CSS SPOB\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE CSS SP CMT\n\nConstants Table (COT) - values\nSpecial Processes Output Standby Water Coolant Loop Control\n\'J "):\'~(I\n\nc.>< \\, I\n\n10/16/79\n3.2.1. 22-1\n\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\n3.2.1.22\n\nAntenna Management (SSM--ANT_MGMT)\n\nThe Antenna Management (AM) module provides functions to select the appropriate S-band quad and hemi antennas and to steer the Ku-band antenna based on\nthe selected targets and target positions.\na.\n\nControl Interface - The AM module is CALL\'ed by the Special Processes\nExeeutive once every two seconds.\n\nb.\n\nInputs - Inputs to this module are specified in Table 3.2.1.22-1.\n\nc.\n\nProeess Description - The control flows for this module are shown in\nFigures 3.2.1.22-\xc2\xb71 through 3.2.1.22-20. The AM module consists of\nthree primary functions: Tracking and Data Relay Satellite (TDRS)\nComputations, S-band Antenna Management, and Ku-band Antenna Management.\nWithin these functions are several references to a set of data acquired\nfrom GNC via ICC. This data is moved from the ICC buffer to a local.\narea before it is used for any AM processing. While the data is being\nmoved, the ICC Router is inhibited from updating the input buffer.\nThis, ensures the time homogeneity of the ICC data.\nThe I/O status of each AM discrete input iB\ndiscrete is moved to a save area; otherwise\nlayed.\nAll subsequent references to these\nsave area, thereby ensuring that only valid\nare used.\n\nchecked. If valid, that\nthe save area is not overdiscretes are from the\n(no I/O errors) values\n\nThe first primary function, TDRS Computations, performs the following\ncomputations:\n1.\n\nThe position of each TDRS is computed.\n\n2.\n\nThe visibility of each TDRS from the orbiter is determined and\nstored for later use.\n\n3.\n\nThe roll and pitch look angles to each TDRS are computed.\n\nThe next primary function to execute is S-band Antenna Management.\nThis function performs the following proceEises:\n1.\n\nThe quad antenna selected and the hemi antenna selected at the\nRF switches are determined. If\' any input parameter f\'or either\nof these computations has an invalid parameter status indicator,\nthat computation is bypassed. In this case, or if no antenna\nis selected by either of the computati.ons, the previous output\nfrom that computation iB retai.ned and given an invalid parameter\nstatus indicator.\n\n2.\n\nThe current ground Bite is determined based on the ground site\nselect item entry from the AM display and on the ground site\ntable.\n\n10/16/79\n3.2.1.22-2\n\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\n3.\n\nThe TDRS to be .used by S-band antennas is selected based on\nthe S-band TDRS select item from the AM display and on the\nTDRS visibility results from the TDRS computations.\n\n4.\n\nThe S-band quad and hemi antennas selectedby the AM module\non its last previous execution are compared to the S-band\nquad and hemi antennas currently selected at the RF switches.\nWhich, if any, of these comparisons to be performed is determined by checking the state of the "Auto S-Band Antenna Select:\'\nItem" and the positions of the "S-band PM Antenna Switch", the\n"S-band Mode Switch", and the "S-band FM Antenna Switch".\n\n5.\n\nThe target to be used by S-band (ground site, east TDRS, or\nwest TDRS) is determined based on the position of the S-band\nmode switch and on the results of the determinations of the\ncurrent ground site and the TDRS used by the S-band antennas.\n\n6.\n\nDepending on Ithe target selected, either the S-band quad antenna\nor the S-band quad and hemi antennas which point at that target\nare determined and commands are set to cause the selection of\nthese antennas at the RF switches.\n\nThe last primary function to execute is Ku-band Antenna Management.\nThis function performs the following processes:\n1.\n\nThe TDRS to be used by the Ku-band antenna is selected based on\nthe Ku-band TDRS select item from the AM display and on the TDRS\nvisibil\'ity results from the TDRS computations.\n\n2.\n\nThe target at which the\nTDRS, west TDRS, or GNC\npointing flag (acquired\nmination of the TDRS to\n\n3.\n\nThe roll and pitch look angles to the selected target are computed in the Ku-band antenna\'s coordinate system and made\navailable for output to the antenna.\n\n4.\n\nDepending on the position of the Ku-band antenna steering switch,\nthe Ku-band acquisition sequence is initiated and controlled by\nthe Ku-band antenna management function when a new target is\nselected.\n\nKu-band antenna is to be pointed (east\ntarget*) is determined based on the GNC\nvia ICC) and the results of the deterbe used by the Ku-band antenna.\n\nExcept where otherwise stated, all of the functions within AM use the\nlatest good update of the input parameters without making any attempt\nto ascertain their current validity.\nThere is no OPS initialization or cleanup processing.\n*Rendevous radar is not supported until OFT 3.\n\n10/16/79\n3.2.1. 22-3\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\nd.\n\nOutputs - Outputs from this module are specified in Table 3.2.1.22-1;\n\ne.\n\nModule References - None\n\nf.\n\nModule Type and Attributes\nType:\n\nExternal Procedure\n\nAttributes:\ng.\n\nDefault (serially reusable with no protective mechanism).\n\nTemplate References The Uplink Processor is,SCHEDULE\'d by the OPS 2\nControl Segment.,\nSCHEDULE SUL_UPLINK PRIORITY (PRIO_SUL)\n\nb.\n\n~nputs\n\n- Inputs to this module are specified in Table 3,,2.1.23-1.\n\nc.\n\n\'process Des~ription - The control flows for this module are shown\nin Figures 3.2.1.23-1 through 3.2.1.23-6. The Uplink Processor\nWAIT\'s either for\xc2\xb7UI to signal that an uplink load is available for\nprocessing or for the OPS control segment to signal that the OPS\nhas been terminated. In the latter case, this module exits.\nOtherwise, the uplink load is moved to a local area and the UI area\nis freed for further UI use. Then the Uplink Processor performs the\nnecessary processing for the uplinked OP code. In most cases this\nprocessing consists of moving the correct number of words from t,he\nuplink buffer to the affect~d function\'s COMPOot for later use by\nthat function. In the case of a Table Maintenance Block Update load,\nthe processing consists of various error checking coupled with invocations of the Table Maintenance Process to perform updates to SM\ntables.\nAt OPS initialization the Uplink Cancel Flag must be turned Off.\nOPS cleanup the Uplink Cancel Flag must be turned ON.\n\nd.\n\nOutputs - Outputs from this module are specified in Table\n\ne.\n\n3.2.1.23~1.\n\nModule References Process\nTable Maintenance Process\n\nf.\n\nModule Type and Attributes Type: Program\nAttributes: N/A\n\nSection\n-\n\nReference\nSCHEDULE\n\nAt\n\n\\10/16/79\n3.2.1. 23-2\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\ng.\n\nTemplate "References D INCLUDE TEMPLATE STM- TABLE- MAIN - The display controlled processes are "ondemand" proeesses that are. involved by either an OPS or SPEC control segment as\na direct\xc2\xb7 result of an item entry to a display. Valid Specialist Functions within\neach OPS are shown in Table 3.2-2. Two unique Specialist Functions may be active\nwithin each OPS. An entry of a new SPEC or RESUME from the controlling CRT causes\ntermination of the SPEC in process.\nThere is a generic capability to cyclically display analog, EU and discrete\nparameter values and statuses on the displays pertaining to this sect"ion. This\ncapability (SMM) is discussed in Section 3.1.4.\n\nThe Table Maintenance Function allows the crew limited control over limit\nsensing and selected computation and sequences. SM Checkpoint/Restore is control.led by Table Maintenance.\n3.3.1.1\n\nTable Maintenance Specialist Function Control Segment (STS_SPEC)\n\nThe Table Maintenance Specialist Function Control Segment presents the Table\nMaintenance Display and controls execution of the Table Maintenance Process. The\nControl Segment acts as the interface between the crew and the Table Maintenance\nProcess.\na.\n\nControl Interface - The Table Maintenance Control Segment is SCHEDULE\'d\nby the User Interface Sequence Request Processor upon user request.\nINVOCATION:\n\nSCHEDULE STS_SPEC PRIORITY (PRIO-STS)\n\nb.\n\nInputs - Inputa to this module are specified in Table 3.3.1.1-1.\n\nc.\n\nProcess Description - The control flow for this mo.dule is shown in\nFigure 3.3.1.1--1. Upon initialization of the Table Maintenace Specialist Function, the TM display is initialized by blanking out all the\nvariable data fields in the TM display, except the FDA Enable/Inhibit\nand the checkpoint time tag. These two parameters are left unchanged.\nThe parameter display flag is\xc2\xb7 set OFF and the TM SPEC active flag is\nset ON. The cyclic parameter update is then scheduled. This function\nallows the CRT buffer to be cyclically updated once a parameter ID has\nbeen selected as an input item entry. rrhe Table Maintenance Display\ni~i t;hen presented and the system waits for the selection\xc2\xb7 of a new OPS,\nnew SPEC, Resume, or an item entry. In the event there is an item\nentry, and the TM Uplink active flag is OFF, then the Table Maintenance\nprocess is SCHEDULE\'d and passed the item entries indicating the processing to be performed. If the TM Uplink active flag is ON, a class 5 error\nmessage is issued.\nThe cyclic parameter update is cancelled when a new OPS, new SPEC, or\nResume is selected. The TM Spec Active Flag is turned OFF after the\ncancellation of the cyclic parameter update program.\n\n,10/16/79\n3.3-2\n\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\nd.\n\nOutputs - Outputs from this module are specified in Table 3.3.1.1-1.\n\ne.\n\nModule Reference - Process\n\nSection\n\nTable Maintenance Process\nCyclic Parameter Update\nf.\n\n3.3.1.2\n3.3.3.3\n\nSchedule\nSchedule\n\nModule Type and Attributes\nType:\n\nProgram\n\nAttributes:\ng.\n\nReference\n\nN/A\n\nTemplate References Systems Services Common Compool\nTM TM Entry Processing\n\nDate: 110/16/79\nPage\n3.3.1.2-1\n\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\n3.3.1.2\n\nTable Maintenance Process (STM_TABLE_MAIN)\n\nThe Table Maintenance (\'I\'M) Process module retrieves the current parameter\nvalue, limits, noise filter, annunciation enable/inhibit status, and constant\nvalue to be displayed and .updates these items when new values are entered via\nthe keyboard. Table Maintenance also controls Cheekpoint and enabling/inhibiting\nthe FDA process.\na.\n\nControl Interfflce - Table Maintenance is SCHEDULE\'d by the Table Maintenance Special1.st Function Control Segment when an item entry is entered.\nINVOCATION:\n\nSchedUle STM_TABLE_MAIN PRIORITY (PRIO_STM)\n\nb.\n\nInputs - Inputs to this module are specified in Table 3.3.1.2-1.\n\nc.\n\nPr,Qcess Descri:gtion - The control flows for this module are shown in\nFigure 3.3,1.2-1 through 3.3.1.2-13.\nThe Table Maint\xe2\x82\xacmance module interrogates the item entry to determine\nwhich type of processing to perform.\nIf a limit value, noise filter or annunciation enable/inhibit is to be\nchEmged, a parameter ID item input must first be entered. The associated\nvalue may then be entered. A parameter ID is valid if it has an entry\nin the PIT. If the parameter ID is invalid, a Class 5 error message is\nenabled. If the ID is valid, relevant infoI\'mation about that parameter\nis retrieved from the various SM tables and buffers and moved to the TM\ndisplay buffer. The Alarm Class 2 and Alarm Class 3 FDA information (limits,\nnoise filter and parameter annunciation inhibit indicator) is maintained\nin separate display fields. The current value, status, and limit set in\nuse of each entered parameter are updated cyclically after a parameter ID\nis entered. The ID is also made available for display. Control is then\nreturned to the control segment.\nIf a constant value is to be changed, a constant ID item input must first\nbe entered. The associated value may then be entered. A constant ID is\nvalid if it has an entry in the COT. If the constant ID is invalid, a\nClass 5 error message is enabled. If the ID is valid, the constant value\nand constant ID are made available for display.\nItem entry request are communicated to the TM process through an item\nentry table. When scheduled, TM process indexes through processing\neaeh non-zero entry. It is through this mechanism that multiple entries\nare processed.\nSubsequent. calls t.o TM can be requests to update various values or indicators for the requested parameter. If a request is made without a\nprevious parameter or constant ID being entered, processing stops and\na Glass 5 error message is enabled for display. It should be noted that\na paramet.er ID entry is valid at all times and indicates to TM that all\n. subsequent parametric entries (prior to the next valid ID entry) are for the\nrequested parameter or constant. Processing for each type of request is:\n"2\n,:.)\n\nI {(;>\n\nDate: 110/16/19\n\n~age\n\n3~3.1.2~2\n\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\n1.\n\nLimit ~alues - An existing limit value may be changed for any\nparameter that is processed by Fault Detection and Annunciation.\n(Each parameter may have up to three sets of Alarm Class 3 or 4\nlimits and one set of Class 2 limits.)\nIf a limit value is within valid range, the value is stored in\nthe target table (LIT for EU and A nalog and PIT for Discrete).\nAnalog limit values are converted .from engineering units to PCM\ncounts prior to storage. All the new limit values are moved\nto the TM display buffer before control is returned to the control segment. A Class 5 error message is output for an analog\nor EU limit value entry that is not within a valid range.\n\n2.\n\nNoise Filter - If the entered noise filter (max noise count) is\nnot within the valid range (1 to 15) a Class 5 error message is\nenabled. If the max noise count is valid for this parameter,\nthe max In\' count field in the PIT entry for this parameter is\nupdated and the current noise count associated with this param.eter is reinitialized. The new max noise count is then moved\nto the Table Maintenance display buffer.\n\n3.\n\nParameter Annunciation Status - The annunciation inhibit indicator\nin the PIT entry for this parameter is enabled or disabled according to the item entered.\n\n4.\n\nConstants Change - If an item entry is made to change a constant,\nthis process accepts the value change for the parameter specified\nand updates the current value of the parameter\'in the COT. This\nupdated value is then made available for display.\n\n5.\n\nFDA Enable/Inhibit - The FDA Enable/Inhibit Indicator in the CMT is\nenabled or disabled according to the item entered.\n\n6.\n\nCheckpoin~ - The checkpoint item entry causes the predefined set of\nSM checkpoint data to be stored to mass memory. If the operation\nis successful, the current time and a \'success\' indicator are dis- \xe2\x80\xa2\nplayed. If the operation is not successful, "fail" indicator is\ndisplayed.\n\nIf there are no errors in the\' last \\, request, TM display update fiag is\nset on signaling HI to generate a fresh display.\nd.\n\nOutputs - Outputs from this module are specified in Table 3.3.1.2-1.\n\nDate: : 10/16/79\nfage . 3. 3.1. 2- 3\n\nBOOK: OFT 8M Detailed Design Specification\n\nf.\n\nModule References -\n\nSection\n\nReference\n\n3.2.1.7\n3.2.1.8\n\nCALL\nCALL\n\nModule Type and Attributes\n~Cype\n\n:\n\nProgram\n\nAttributes:\ng.\n\nProcess\nForward Scaling\nBackward Scaling\n\ne.\n\n~remplate\n\nN/ A\n\nRefe:rences -\n\nSystems Services Common Compool\nTM Communication Compool\nSystems Services Display Presentation\nand Control Routine\nSystems Services Application Moding\n:0 INCLUDE TEMPLATE DNX BMS\nand Sequencing Routine\nSystems Services Annunciation Control\n:0 INCLUDE TEMPLATE CDL_ANNUN\nD INCLUDE \'l\'EMPLATE DMA MAC\nSystems Services Annunciation Routine\n:0 INCLUDE TEMPLATE SFS:FOR_SCALE\nForward Scaling\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE SBS_BACK_SCALE Backward Scaling\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE CSA SM CMT\nBasic SM Communication Compool\nD INCLUDE CSAPIT\nParameter Information Table\nD INCLUDE CSACDA\nCurrent Data Array\nLimit Sense Table (LIT)\nD INCLUDE CSALIT\nConstants Table Source Member.\nD INCLUDE CSCCO\'l\'SRC\nConta:Lns t[Cy--Macro-Flags------- . ---D INCLUDE IOMACS\nD INCLUDE MMUMACS\nContains MM Read/Write Macros\nD INCLUDE SUMMACS\nContains FCOS Checksum Generation Macros\nD INCLUDE riMAl\'IMACS\nSystems~:rerVices--err6ranriunCiation\nmacro replace statements\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE CVN MMUTILITY Contains SM common buffer\nSystem services portection macros\nD INCLUDE PROTMACS\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE CZl COMMON\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE CST TM CMT\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE DIS-PLAY\n\nh.\n\nError HandliE\xc2\xa3 - The di splay buffer is updated as long as the parameter display flag is turned ON. This flag is initially turned OFF by\nthe TM control unit and is turned ON by the TM module when the first\nparameter ID is entered by the crew. The class 0/3/4 Limit indicator\nhI a flag in the TM display buffer and is set ON or UFF by the \'I\'M\nmodule. The active Limit set (1,2, or 3) is entered into the display\nbuffer i f the class 0/3/4 Limit indicator is ON.\nThe analog, EU, or discrete data is updated, depending on the parameter\ntype.\nThe parameter type is an integer value in the display buffer. A value\nof 1 indicates an analog type, a 2 an EU type, and a 3 a discrete type.\nThe data that is updated are the parameter value, status and active\nLimit set indicator.\n\nd.\n\nOutputs - Outputs from this module are specified in Table 3.3.1. 3-1.\n\ne.\n\nModule References Process.\n\nReference\n\nForward Scaling\nf.\n\nSection\n3.2.1.7\n\nCALL\n\nModule Type and Attributes:\nType:\n\nProgram\n\nAttributes:\n\nN/A\n\n1\\ \'t"\n\n337\n\n:)\n\np\n\n,,\n\n(\',/\n\nDate:\nPage\n\n10/16/79\n3.3.1.3-2\n\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\ng.\n\nTemplate References:\nD\nD\nD\nD\n\nINCLUDE\nINCLUDE\nINCLUDE\nINCLUDE\n\nCSAPIT\nCSACDA\nTEMPLATE CST TM CMT\nTEMPLATE SFS FOR SCALE\n\n-\n\n-\n\nh.\n\nError Handling - SCMis\na Specialist Function controlled via item entries from the SCM display.\n\n3.3.2.1\n\nSCM Specialist Function Control Segment (SCS_SPEC)\n\nThe Su"bsystem Configuration Management Specialist Function Control Segment\nacts as the interface between the crew and the SCM process and controls execution\nof the SCM processes.\na.\n\nControl Interface - The SCM Control Segment is SCHEDULE\'d by the User\nInterface Sequence Request Processor (DMC_SEQ_REQ_PROC) upon user request.\nInvocation:\n\nSCHEDULE SCS SPEC PRIORITY(PRIO_SCS)\n\nb.\n\nInputs - Inputs to this module are spec:1.fied in Table 3.3.2.1-1.\n\nc.\n\nProcess Description - The control flow for this module is shown in\nFigure 3.3.2.1\xc2\xb7-1. The SCM Specialist Flllction calls the SCM Initialization/Cleanup module to initialize the SPEC controlled display variables. The SCM Display is presented and the current SCM list ID is\nenabled. The system then waits for selection of a new OPS, new SPEC,\nRESUME, or an item entry. If there is an item entry, the SCM process\nis scheduled to perform the process associated with that item entry.\n\nd.\n\nOutputs - Outputs from this module are specified in Table 3.3.2.1-1.\n\ne.\n\nModule Referenees - Process\n\nSection\n\nSCM Process\nSCM Initialization\nf.\n\n3.3.2.2\n3.3.2.3\n\nSCHEDULE\nCALL\n\nModule Type and termination is requested.\nTherefore, the \'SUCCESS/FAIL\' indicator associated with SCM MM\nwrite would not be visible to the user since the SPEC display\nis overlayed at termination before the Subsystem Configuration Management Specialist Function Control Segment\n\n10/16/79\n3.3.2.2-1\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\n3.3.2.2\n\nSubsystem Configuration Management Process (SCM_SDB_CONFIG_MAN)\n\nSubsystem Configuration Management (SCM) provides the capability to compare\nspecified analog, ED, and discrete parameters with predefined configurations as\ndefined in SCM lists. SCM is controlled by item entry from the SCM display.\na.\n\nControl Interface - The SCM module ,is SCHEDDLE\'d by the SCM\nControl Segment to process item entries.\n\nb.\n\nInputs - Inputs to this module are specified in Table 3.3.2.2-1.\n\nc.\n\nProcess DeBcription - The control flows for this module are\nshown in Figures 3.3.2.2~1 through 3.3.2.2-17. The SCM module\ndetermines which proceBs to perform based on the item entry.\nThere are five processes as follows:\n1.\n\nSelect list to be used - When a valid list is selected it is\nread from Mass Memory if it is not already core resident and\nthe new list ID is made available for display. If the list\nselected is invalid then an error message is enabled for display.\n\n2.\n\nExecute List Compare - When a comparison is requested (regardless of whether a list is selected), the discrepancy\nmessage buffer and downlist buffer are cleared. The acquisition of the SCM data values by basic data acquisition and\nthe Special Process data acquisition is independent of the\nSCM process. This data will reside in the CDA or SPINB and\nwill be pointed to directly out of the SCM list. ICC data\nis requested by ICC Data Acquisition (Figure 3.3.2.2-4). If\nthe ICC data is not acquired by some predetermined time\nthose values are marked as invalid. The acquired values are\ncompared with the predefined SCM list limits and discrepancies\nare noted and made available for display. Discrepancy\nmessages are also generated for parameters with invalid status\nindicators. The parameter IDs of each parameter that\ngenerates a discrepancy message are added to the downlist\nbuffer. Invalid status indicators, for values with I/O errors,\nand desired state, for discretes, are also made available for\ndisplay at this time. The process is terminated when ten (10)\ndiscrepancies are found or the list is completed. If no\ndiscrepancies are found, a single "all good" message is enabled\nfor display.\n\nOHJGJNAL PAGL\': is 1\'(0):,\n\n10/16/79\n3.3.2.2-2\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\n3.\n\nRequest display of a particular parameter and its \xc2\xb7lirriitsWhen a parameter ID is requested the current SCM list is\nsearched. If the ID is found its limits are made available\nfor display. If they are not found an error message is\nenabled for display.\n\n4.\n\nChange limits - If the parameter ID has been previously\nentered the new limits are moved into the SCM list replacing the old. In the case of a discrete, the new\ndesired state text is made available for display. If the\nparameter ID has not been entered, an error message is\nenabled for display.\n\n5.\n\nWrite current list to Mass Memory - The success/fail indicator is blanked and the list written to Mass Memory.\nThe SCM software ensures that the Mass Memory initialization copy of the SCM list is not overwritten. When the\nwrite is complete, FCOS reads the data back into main\nmemory, compares checksums of the write and read operation,\nthen returns a status in the write status field of the FCOS\nwrite macro. This status, field is interpreted by SCM and the\nsuccess/fail indicator is set and made available for display.\n\nd.\n\nOutputs - Outputs from this module are specified in Table 3.3.2.2-1.\n\ne.\n\nModule References - DMA MAC - A system software external procedure\ncalled when a class 5 error message is enabled by FMPT_CLASS5 macro.\n\nf.\n\nModule Type and Attributes\nType: Program\nAttributes: N/A\n\ng.\n\nTemplate References CSCSCMT - SCM TEXT DICTIONARY\nCSCSCAT - SCM ADDRESS TABLE (SCAT)\nTEMPLATE CSC_CMT_SCM - SCM DISPLAY PARAMETERS\nTEMPLATE CSZ_ICC_CMT - ICC INPUT BUFFERS AND FLAGS\nTEMPLATE CDL ANNUN - SYSTEM SERVICES ANNUNCIATION COMPOL\nDM#MACS - SYSTEM SERVICES ERROR ANNUNCIATION MACRO\nREPLACE STATEMENTS\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE CZ2_COMMON~CM ICC/UI FLAGS\n\nD\nD\nD\nD\nD\nD\n\nh.\n\nINCLUDE\nINCLUDE\nINCLUDE\nINCLUDE\nINCLUDE\nINCLUDE\n\nError Handling - None\n\n10/16/79\n3.3.2.2-3\nIBOOK: OFT SM Detailed\n\ni.\n\nDesig~1\n\nSpecification\n\nConstraints and\n\nAss~tions\n\n-\n\n1.\n\nItem entries made while the SCM program is busy with a\nprevious item entry are ignored by the SCM control segment.\n\n2.\n\nAny ICC data input errors caused all ICC parameters to be\nmarked invalid.\n\nREPRODuCIBnXry OF THE,\nORIGINAL PAGB IS POOR\n\nTAI!ILE 3.3.2.2-1\n\nfI\n\nMODULE DATA INVOCATION: CALL SCI CLNUP\nInputs - Inputs to this module are specified in Table 3.3.2.3-1.\n\nc.\n\nProcess Description - The control flow for this module is shown in\nFigure 3.3.2.3-1. The Initialization module blanks the variable data\nin the SCM display. This data includes the item entries, mass memory,\nwrite success indicator, and the discrepancy message text buffer. The\nlist ID is not blanked and is enabled whenever the display is up.\n\nd.\n\nOutputs - Outputs from this module are specified in Table 3.3.2.3-1.\n\ne.\n\nModule References - None\n\nf.\n\nModule Type and Attributes\nType:\n\nExternal Procedure\n\nAttributes:\n\nDefault (serially reusable with no protective mechanism).\n\nh.\n\nTemplate References\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE CSC SCM CMT\nError HandlinJi - None\n\ni.\n\nConstraints and Assumptions - None\n\ng.\n\nSCM DISPLAY PARAMETERS\n\n1\'; tS\n\nPOOI~\n\nTABLE\n\n3.3.2.3-1\n\nMODULE DATA U;T\n\nInitialization/Cleanup Process\n\n#\n\nITEM\n\nDESCRIPTOR\n\nACT\n\nSOURCE/DESTINATION\n\n1\n\nDisplay variable data\n\nE\n\nI/O\n\nCRT\n\n2\n\nDiscrepancy message\nbuffer\n\nHAL NAME\n\nREQT.\nSYMBOL\n\nMML\n\nCCI\nC)\nC)\n\n..\n\n:til:\nA.2.11\n\nCRT\n\n,\n\nCSCV_CMT_ M3SSyINE (r)\n\nI\n\nC)\n\n."\n\n-t\n\n(I)\n\n3:\n~\n\n....\n\nCD\n\ns:\xc2\xbb\nI\n\nCD\n\n=C\n\n_.\n\n(\'I)\n\nen\n\nI\n1\n\n:0J.\n\n!\n\n~\n\nI\n\nN\n\\.\n\nCCI\n\n=\n\n(I)\n\n\'C\nCD\n\nn\n\nI n\n\n...\nI\xc2\xbb\n\n==\n=\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n0\n\n~\n\n~\n\nW\n___\nW\'I>-\'\n. \'-\'\n\nW\nrG 1-\'\n\'-0\n\nI\n\n\'I,\n\n/\n\n\\\n\n10/16/79\n3.3.2.3-3\n\nEnter\n\nBlank\nDiscrepancy\nMessage Text\nBuffer\n\nBlank SCM\nDisplay\nVariable Data\nExcept For\nList ID\n\nReturn\n\nFigure 3.3.2.3-1. The control segment acts as the interface between the crew and the TFL\'\nprocess.\na.\n\nControl Interface - The CI Control Segment is SCHEDULE\'d by the User\nInterface Sequence Request Processor (DMC_SEQyEQ_PROC) upon user request.\nInvocation:\n\nSchedule SLS SPEC PRIORITY (PRIO_SLS)\n\nb.\n\nInputs - Inputs to this module are specified in Table 3.3.3.1-1.\n\nc.\n\nProcess Description - The control flow for this module is shown in\nFigures 3.3.3.1--1 through 3.3.3.1-3. The CI Specialist Function initializes flags, indicators and SPEC controlled disulay variables. When CI\nInitialization is completed, the GTS Cyclic Update Processor is scheduled\nto acquire the PCM BITE and update the display with the current downlink\nformatter selected. The CI display is then presented and the system\nwaits for selection of a new OPS, a new SPEC, RESUME or an item entry.\nIf the TFL active flag is off (TFL module inactive) for an item entry,\nthe CI specialist function sets the TFL active flag to ON and enters the\nformat ID into the TFL Compool. The TFL module is scheduled and it performs the task of validating the entered format ID. When an item number\n1 or 2 is entered with an item execute, then the 128 KBPS fixed and\nprogrammable formatters are respectively selected. When item 4 is entered\nwith an item execute, the TFL module is scheduled for the purpose of\nacquiring, executing, and verifying the format load. The TFL active\nflag is always turned off by the TFL module just ,before it terminates.\nWhen the control segment is terminated, the GTS cyclic update process is\ncancelled and the TFL termination flag iB turned on to signal the TFL\nprocess to terminate its proceBsing after completing any I/O operations.\n\nd.\n\nOutputs - Outputs from this nodule are specified in Table 3.3.3.1-1.\n\nREPROD UCIBILITY OF THE\nORIGINAL PAGI\'~ IS\n\npenn\n\n10/16/79\n3.3.3-2\n\nBOOK: OFTSM Detailed Design Specification\n\nModule References - Process\n\nReference\n\n3.3.3.3\n3.3.3.4\n\nSCHEDULE\nSCHEDULE\n\nDisplay\n\nA system software external\nprocedure called when the\nDISPLAY GRAMMAR macro is invoked.\n\nDNX BMS\n\nf.\n\nSection\n\nGTS Cyclic Update\nTFL Process\n\ne.\n\nA system software external\nprocedure called when various\nmoding and sequencing grammar macros are invoked.\n\nModule Type and Attributes\nType: Program\nAttributes: N/A\n\ng.\n\nTemplate References D INCLUDE TEMPLATE CZl COMMON\n\nSystems Services Common Compool\n\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE DISPLAY\n\nSystems Services Display Presentation and Control/Routine\n\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE DNX BMS\n\nSystems Services Application\nModing and Sequencer routine\n\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE CVL TFL COMPOOL\n\nTFL Display Compool\n\nD INCLUDE DAG#RAM\n\nCommon grammar macro set\n\nD INCLUDE DCG#RAM\n\nSpec Control Segment grammar\nmacro set\n\nD INCLUDE DDG#RAM\n\nAllows references to MCDS Keyboard inputs\n\nD INCLUDE ZPRIOTIM\n\nContains REPLACE names for baseline priorities phasing, and\nrates of scheduled processes\n\nD INCLUDE IOMACS\n\nI/O macros for FCOS\n\nD INCLUDE PMUMACS\n\nPMU Read/Write Control\n\n11/11/77\n3.3.3,...3\n\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Desigll Specification\n\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE VCY CYC UPD\n\nCyclic Update process\n\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE VTL TFL MODULE\n\nTF\'L Process\n\nh.\n\nError Handling - None\n\ni.\n\nConstraints and Assumptions - Specialist function termination is such\nthat the control segment signals the TFL process to terminate as soon\nas possible. However, the user does not get a \'FAIL\' indication on\nthe TFL display since the display will be overlayed before the TFL proceBS can indicate a fail.\n\nREPROD DCIBILlTY OF THE\nORIGINAL PAGE IS POOR\n\nTABLE 3.3.3.1-1 \xc2\xb7Communication Instrumentation Svecialist FunctiolVlODULE DATA LIST\nI\n\nITEM\n\n#\n\nDESCRIPTOR\n\nI\xc2\xb7\nI\n\nACT\n\nSOURCE/DESTINATION\n\nHAL NAME\n\n1\n\nMML\n\nREQT.\nSYMBOL\n\nall\n\n0\n0\n\n1\n\nItem Entry\n\nE\n\n"I/O\n\nCRT/VTF\n\n2\n\nC=rent 128 :CBPS\nFormatter\n\nA.2.11 (TFL COMPOOL)\n\no\n\nCRT. This module is described in the Vehicle Checkout (VCO) DDS, Section\n3.3.1.1.\n\n10/16/79\n3.3.3.4-1\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\n3.3.3.4\n\nTelemetry Format Load Process Module (VTIP_TFLYODULE)\n\nThe Telemetry Format Load (TFL) module verifies the user selected downlink\nformat rD, reads the verified selected downlink format from mass memory, transfers the format to the proper random access memory (RAM) in the PCM Master Unit;\nand verifies that the format was correctly loaded. This module is described in\nthe VCO DDS, Section 3.3.5.\n\n10/16n9\n3.3.4-1\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\n3.3.4\n\nAntenna Management Item Processor (SAM_ITEM)\n\nThe Antenna Management (AM) Item Processor serves as the link between the\nAntenna Management display and the cyclic Antenna Management module (see Section\n3.2.1. 22).\na.\n\nControl Interface - The AM Item Processor is CALL\'ed by Orbit/Doors\n(OPS2) Control Segment when an item entry is made to the Antenna Management display.\nInvocation:\n\nCALL SAM_ITEM(Keyboard Index)\n\nb.\n\nInputs - Inputs to this module are specified in Table 3.3.4-1.\n\nc.\n\nProcess Description - The control flow for this module is shown in\nFigure 3.3.4-1. The AM Item Processor takes an item entry from the AM\ndBplay as input.. This item entry is used as an index into the item\ntype array to determine the case number for that type of item entry.\nThe possible item types are Radar Range Estimate, Radar Self Test\nInitiate, Ku-Band Gimbal Motor Override, Ku-Band TDRS Select, SBand TDRS Select, Auto S-Band Antenna Select, and S-Band Site\nSelect.\nFor each item type, the AM Item Processor sets the corresponding item\nvariable to the appropriate item code. This item code is obtained by\nusing the input item entry as an index into the item code array. The\nitem codes are initialized in such a way that when an item code is moved\ninto an item variable the item variable is correctly set to indicate the\ninput item entry to the display, to downlist, and to the cyclic Antenna\nManagement Processor.\n\nd.\n\nOutEuts - Outputs from this module are specified in Table 3.3.4-1.\n\ne.\n\nModule References - None\n\nf.\n\nModule Type and Attributes\nType:\nExternal Procedure\nAttributes:\nDefault (serially reusable with no protective mechanism)\n\ng.\n\n. Template References D INCLUDE TEMPLATE CSM AM CMT\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE CZl COMMON\n\nh.\n\nError Handling _. None\n\ni.\n\nAntenna Management Display Parameters\nSystems Services Common COMPOOL\n\nConstraints and Assumptions - None\n,I\n\n\'1\n\nj.; l(1\n\n1\\\n\nTABLE\n\n3.3.4-1\n\n#-\n\nAnt"nna Management Antenna Management Item Processor\n\n1()/16/79\n3.3.5-1\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\n3.3.5\n\nPayload Bay Doors Item Processor (SBD_ITEM)\n\nThe Payload Bay Doors (PBD) Item Processor serves as the link between the\nPayload Bay Door display and the cyclic Payload Bay Door module (section 3.2.1.20).\na.\n\nControl Interface - The PED Item Processor is CALL\'ed by the Orbit/\nDoors (OPS2) Control Segment when an item entry is made to the PBD\ndi:splay.\nINVOCATION:\n\nCALL SBD_ITEM(DISPLAY INDICATOR)\n\nb.\n\nl!!:euts - Inputs to this module are specified in Table 3.3.5-1.\n\nc.\n\n\xc2\xa3Cocess Description- The control flow for this module is shown in\nFigure 3.3.5-1. The PBD Item Processor takes item entries made on\nthe PBD display, does validity checking on these entries and either\nsets appropriate i tem( s) for later use by the cyclic ,PBD module or\nenables an error message for output.\nFour item entry types are processed. If a power on/off item entry is\nentered, the power on/off item is set on and the other power item is\nset off. The \'POWER ON/OFF FLAG\' is then set on to alert the cyclic\nPBD module (SSB) that power on/off commands need to be set on or off.\nThe auto mode item entry is only valid if the PBD control switch or\nthe PBD Stop Item is in the "stop" position. Its entry results in\nreversing the setting of the auto mode item and setting the manual\nmode items off. All manual mode item entries are valid if either the\nPBD control switch or the PBD STOP ITEM is in the "stop" position or any\nmanual mode items are set on. Their entry results \'in setting the requested\nmanual mode item on and setting the auto mode item off. All bypass\nswitch item entries are valid when the Switch Bypass item is on. When\nthe Switch Bypass item is off, the only valid entry is the Switch Bypass Item itself, which will result in setting the Switch Bypass item\nand the Stop item to on. If the Switch Bypass item is on, a Switch\nBypass item entry will result in setting all bypass switch items off.\nValid entry of either the Open, Stop, or Close item (bypass switch\nitems) will result in setting the requested item on, and setting the\nother remaining two items off. The power off item is set on and all\nother auto or manual items are set off during Mode 202 initialization.\nIf an invalid entry is made, the FMP\'r CLASS5 macro is issued. This\n\'macro sets a bit in the Fault Message-Parameters Table (FMPT) to\nalert a cyclic User Interface (UI) program that annunciation is to be\nperformed.\n\nd.\n\nOutputs - Outputs from this module are specified in Table 3.3.4-1.\n\ne.\n\nModule References - None\n\nf.\n\nModule Type and Attributes\n\nR8PROD UCIBILITY Olj~ THE\nO:rnmNAL P AG ]1; IS poem\n\nType: External Procedure\nAttributes: Default (Serially reusable with no protective mechanism).\n\n10/16/79\n\n3.3.5-2\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\ng.\n\nTemplate References D\nD\nD\nD\nD\nD\n\nINCLUDE\nINCLUDE\nINCLUDE\nINCLUDE\nINCLUDE\nINCLUDE\n\nTEMPLATE\nTEMPLATE\nTEMPLATE\nTEMPLATE\nDDG#RM1\nDMA#MACS\n\nCDL ANNUN\nCZ1_COMMON\nCSB_PBD_CMT\nDMA MAC\n\nh.\n\nError Handling - None\n\ni.\n\nConstraints and Assumptions - None\n\nSystems Services Annunciation Compool\nSystems Services Common Compool\nPayload Bay Doors Display Parameters\nSystems Services Annunciation Routine\nAllow References to MCDS Keyboard Inputs\nSystems Services Error Annunciation Macro\nReplace Statements\n\nTAB LE\n\n#\n\n3.3.5-1\n\nMODULE DATA LIST\n\nPayload Bay Doors Ite!!!
