Both discret.e and analog\ncoimnands to the payload and pallet MOM\'s are supported.\n3.3.6.1\n\nPayload Control Specialist Function Control Segment (SPl_SPEC, SP2_SPEC,\nSP3_SPEC, SP4_SPEC)\n\nThe Payload Control Specialist Function Control Segment controls execution\nof the Payload Control Process. There are four Payload Control Specialist Function Control Segments each having the same functional processing as described\nbelow.\na.\n\nControl Interfaee - The Payload Control Specialist Function Control\nSegment is SCHEDULE\'d by the User Interface Sequence Request Proprocessor upon user request.\nInvocation:\n\nSCHEDULE\nSCHEDULE\nSCHEDULE\nSCHEDULE\n\nSPI SPEC\nSP2-SPEC\nSP3-SPEC\nSP4=SPEC\n\nPRIORITY(PRIOSPl);\nPRIORITY (PRIO- SP2 ) ;\nPRIORITY(PRIO-SP3);\nPRIORITY(PRIO=Sp4);\n\nb.\n\nInputs - Inputs to this module are specified in Table 3.3.6.1-1.\n\nc.\n\nProcess Description - The control flow for this module is shown in\nFigure 3.3.6.1-1. The Payload Control Specialist Function Control\nSegment calls the Payload Control Initialization/Cleanup module to\ninitialize flags, indicators and SPEC controlled display variables.\nIt then presents the Payload Control Process Display and waits for\nselection of a new OPS, new SPEC, RESUME or an item entry. If an\nitem entry is made the Payload Control module is called to process\nthe request.\n\nd.\n\nOutputs - Outputs from this module are specified in Table 3.3.6.1-1.\n\ne.\n\nModule References - Process\nPayload Control Process\nPayload Control Initialization/Cleanup\n\n~.\n\nModule Type and Attributes\nType:\n\nProgram\n\nAttributes:\n\nN/A\n\nSection\n\nReference\n\n3.3.6.2\n3.3.6.3\n\nCALL\nCAI,L\n\n10/16/19\n3":"3J:;\';\'2\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\ng.\n\nTemplate References\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE CZl COMMON\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE DIS PLAY\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE DNX BMS\nD INCLUDE\nD INCLUDE\nD INCLUDE\nD INCLUDE\nD INCLUDE\n\nTEMPLATE SPC ITEM\nTEMPLATE SIl CLNUP\nDAG#RAM\nDCG#RAM\nDDG#RAM\n\nSystem Services Common Compool\nUI Display Presentation & Control\nExternal Procedure\nUI Application Moding & Sequencing\nExternal Procedure\nPayload Control Process\nPayload Control Initialization/Cleanup\nCommon grammar macro set\nSPEC Control Segment grammar macro set\nAllows references to MCDS keyboard\ninputs\n\nh.\n\nError Handling - None\n\ni.\n\nConstraints and Assumptions - Payload Control Spec item numbers must\nbe consecutive.\n\nTABLE\n\n3.3.6.1-1\n\n#\n\nPayload Control Specialist Function\nControl Segment\n\nITEM\n\nDESCRIPTOR\n\nMODULE DATA LIST\n\nACT\n\nSOU RCE/DESTI NATION\n\nHAL NAME\n\n1\n\nItem entry\n\nE\n\nI\n\nCRT\n\nItem No.\n\nE\n\n0\n\nSPC\n\n4.\n\n\'-\'.\n\n--~\n\\..;".\n\n~\n\nQ\nQ\n\nSPl ITEM NO\nSP2-ITEM-NO\nSP3-ITEM-NO\nSP4=ITEMYO\n\n3\n\n...\n.... ,\n\nREQT.\nSYMBOL\n\nKEY\n\n2\n\nMML\n\n5.\n6.\n\nDisp.\n\nE\n\nI\n\nC\n\nSIl\n\no\n\n."\n\n.....\n\nfA\n\n3:\n\nSPl DISP\nSP2-DISP\nSP3 DISP\nSP4-DISP\n\nQ\n\nCD\n\nI\xc2\xbb\n\nScalar Data Item\n\nE\n\nDI Scalar value\n\n0\n\nSPC\n\nSPl ITEM S\nSP2-ITEM-S\nSP3-ITEM-S\nSP4=ITEM=S\n\nE\n\nUI\n\nITEM S\n\nE\n\nDEU #\n\nI\n\n0\n\nSPC\n\nDr DEU #\n\n(D\n\nQ.\nI\n\nI\n\nE\n\nI\n\nUI\n\nQ\n(D\n\nI\n\n(II\n\nSPl DEU\nSP2-DEU\nSPj-DEU\nSP4=DEU\n\nI\n7.\n\n..\n\n~\n\nCCI\n\n=\nen\n\n"C\n\nCD\n\n=\n=\nn\n\nn\n\nD_DEU_NUMBER\n\nI\xc2\xbb\n\n,\nco\n~\n\n.-2.\n\'\'\'\'\'\'\'\';\n\nW\n\n---;\n---\n\n0\\\nI\n\nI\n\nL_\n\n~-\'--\n\nI\n\nC"-\n\nv::\n\n10/16/79\n3.3.6-4\n\nProgram Payload\nControl SPEC\n\nCALL Payload\nControl\nInitialization/\nCleanup\nFig 3.3.6.3\n\nDISPLAY\nPayload\nControl Display\n\nDO UNTIL\n\xe2\x80\xa2 SPEC Resumed\n\xe2\x80\xa2 New OPS\n\xe2\x80\xa2 New SPEC *\n\nWAIT FOR\n.New DPS\n\xe2\x80\xa2 New SPEC\n\xe2\x80\xa2 Item Entry\n\xe2\x80\xa2 Resume\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\nIF\nitem\nEntry\n\nThen\n\n*\n\nItem No. =\nItem Entry\n+ Disp\n\xe2\x80\xa2 Scalar Data Value=\nU I Scalar Value\n\xe2\x80\xa2 DEU/=UI DEU#\n\nI\nCALL\nPayload\nControl Process\nFig 3.3.6.2\n\nClose Payload\nControl SPEC\n\nFigure 3.3.6.1-1. Payload Control Specialist Function Control Segment\n\nDate:\nPage:\n\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\n3.3.6.2\n\n10/16/19\n3.3.6.2-1\n\nPayload Control Process (SPC_ITEM)\n\nThe Payload Control Process outputs t\xc2\xb7he selected analog or discrete command\nto either the payload MDM or pallet MDM (PL MDM).\na.\n\nControl Interface - Payload Control is CALL\'d by the Payload Control\nSpecialist Function as a result of a valid item entry.\nInvocation:\n\nCAI,L SPC_ITEM (Item No, Data Item, DEU no);\n\nb.\n\nInputs - Inputs to this module are specified in Table 3.3.6.2-1.\n\nc.\n\nProcess Description - The control flow for this module is shown in\nFigures 3.3.6.2-1 through 3.3.6.2.;..3. When the item entered represents\na discrete command, the associated device address, reset mask and set\nmask are used to build appropriate commands. First, bits within the\nchannel indicated are commanded OFF with a RESET command utilizing the\nreset mask. Then, the set mask is used to command ON bits within the\nselected channel. In order to make the current status of selected device\navailable for display and/or downlist, the status of the MDM is read via\nMDM BITE test 4. This status is then set in the proper channel status\nmask.\nWhen the item entry represents an analog command, the associated device\naddress and scaling coefficients are isolated. The Backward Scaling\nmodule is called to convert the entered value to analog PCM count and a\ncommand is issued to output that analog. Values that are offscale are\nnot output and result in a Class 5 error message being outP~lt.\n\nd.\n\nOut~~\n\ne.\n\nModule References -\n\n- Outputs from this module are specified in Table 3.3.6.2-1.\nReference\n\n3.2.1.8\n\nCALL ( Call List)\n\nModule Type and Attributes\nType:\n\nExternal Procedure\n\nAttributes:\ng.\n\nSection\n\nBackward Payload Control Init/Cleanup\n\n1-\n\nPut\nResponse\nWord\nInto\nChannel\nStatus\nWord\nIn CST\n\nDate\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\n3.3.7 Mass Memory\n\n10/16/79\n\nPage\n\n3.3.7-1\n\nPatc~\n\nThe Mass Memory Patch function in 8M OP8 2 provides the capability to modify\nmass memory via the Mass Memory Read/Write SPEC or Uplink (Capability 2) for load\nblocks 6f 2048 half words or less.\n\nDate\n\n10/16/19\n\nPage\n\n3.3.7.1-1\n\nBOOK: OFT SIVI Detailed Design Specification\n\n3.3.7.1\n\nMass Memory READ/WRITE SPEC Control Segment\n\n(vMr\\U\\~!LSPEC)\n\nThe MM HEAD/WRITE (MM R/W) SPEC provides the user the ability to patch the\nmass memories through keyboard inputs at the MCDS. A load block is read into core\nfrom mass memory and portions of the load block (up to 39 words) may be displayed.\nThe changes may then be merged with the actual data and the load \'block written out\nto the mass memory. The checksum is also displayed, providing the user gre\'ater\nassurance of accuracy. Other displayed values keep the user informed of the status\nof his requeBt as well as any violations of allowable procedures.\na.\n\nControl Interface - The MM R/W SPEC function will be activated by\nUser Interface upon a user request for the SPEC. This SPEC iB\nvalid only in the SM 2 OPS Sequence.\n\nb.\n\n1El)uts - See Table 3.3.7.1-1.\n\nc.\n\nProcess Description (Figure 3.3.7.1-1) - Once activated, following\ninHialization of necessary flags, variables, and buffers, the MM R/W\nDisplay will be presented. The program will be in the "WAIT" state\nuntii an ITEM is entered. Receipt of Item entries will result in the\nCALLing of the MM Item Processor (Section 3.3.7.2).\nUpon SPEC termination (by user request), if the MM Message Processor\nis active, a WAIT is issued until it becomes inactive, whereupon\ncontrol is returned to the CALLing routine.\n\nd.\n\nOutputs - See Table 3.3.7.1-1.\n\ne.\n\nModule References - VMP ITEM PROC:\n\nf.\n\nModule Type and Attributes\n\nMM R/W SPEC Item Processor\n\nType: Program\nAttributes: N/A\ng.\n\nTemplate References\n\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE DNX BMS\n\nSystem Services Common Compool\nUI Display Presentation and Control\nand External Procedures\nUI Application Moding and Sequencing\n\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE VMP ITEM PHOC\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE CDF. This module is described in the Vehicle Checkout\n(VCO) DDS, Section 3.2.7.1.\n\nOF\'iTl\'jfl\n\nDate\nPage\n\n10/16/19\n\n3.3.7.3-1\n\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\n3.3.7.3\n\nMass Memory Message Processor (DMP_MM__MSG_PROC)\n\nThe Mass Memory Message Processor processes requests from the ground or onboard (via the MCDS MM. Spec function). It decodes the messages from the ground\nor MCDS and performs Mass Memory Read LOAD BLOCK, Merge :patch Data, and Write\nLOAD BLOCK operations. As such, the processor provides a mass memory load and\ndump capability. This module is described in the Vehicle Checkout (VCO), DDS,\nSection 3.7.2.2.\n\n1~EPRODUCr\\3H XL\'V\n.1>\n\n_1\n\n.\n\n".\n\n"\n\n\'C\'\n\nOInGH~[Al~ PAGb )"\n\n01i\' TB l\':\n})\')Ol{\n\n~\n\n.\'\n\n10/16/79\n3.3.8-1\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\n3.3.8 Remote Manipulator System\nThe Renlote Manipulator System (RMS) software provides inflight payload\nhandling to support deployment, retrieval, and stowage of payloads. The RMS\nsoftware monitors and controls the motion of the mechanical arm(s) by:\n1.\n\nSelecting and :lnitializing the control modes\n\n2.\n\nComputing arm eommands\n\n3.\n\nDetermining operational arm status\n\n4.\n\nProviding RMS caution and warning signals\n\n5.\n\nPerforming fault detection, and\n\n6.\n\nAllowing mission tailoring through the use of I-LOAD and mission/\npayload-dependent parameters.\n\nAll parameters in the MCIU Input/Output (I/O) data blocks (compools) are\navailable for Downlist (DL). Therefore, these items shall not show DL as\na destination in the module data lists since they are all available for DL.\n\nREPRODUCIBILITY OF THE\nORIGINAL PAGE~ IS POOR\n\nDate 10/16/\'79\nRev\n\nBOOK:\n\n3.3.8.1\n\nPage\n\nOFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\n3.3.8.1-1\n\nRemote ManipUlator System (RMS) Specialist\nFunction Control Segment (RMC_SPEC)\n\nThe RME; Specialist Function Control Segment (RMC ) activates RMS\nprocessing and presents the RMS SPEC display (094) on the orbiter CRT.\na.\n\nControl Interface - The RMS Control Segment is SCHEDULE\'d by\nthe User Interface (UI) Program Sequence Request Processor\n(DMC). Control is given to RMC whenever any of the following\nkeyboard actions occur:\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\nSPEC 094 is entered\nSPEC 094 is resumed\nITEM entry/execute via SPEC 094 is received\nNew OPS is selected\nNew SPEC is selected\n\nInvocation:\n\nSCHEDULE RMC SPEC PRIORITY (PRIO_RMC)\n\nb.\n\nInputs - Inputs to this module are specified in Table 3.3.8.1-1.\n\nc.\n\nProcess Description - The control flow for this module is shown\nin Figure 3.3.8.1-1. Selection of the RMS Specialist\nFunction causes RMC to check if the RMS Executive (REX) is\nactive. I f it is, RMC presents the RMS SPEC display and waits\nfor keyboard input. I f REX is not active, the RMS initiali zation\nflag is set, the FCOS Timer Initiated I/O is scheduled, REX is\nSCHEDULE\'d (using the priority, frequency and phase offset\nspecified for HEX in SAM 10), and the EMS SPEC display is\npresented. Once SHCEDULE\'d, REX continues to execute until a\nnew OPS is selected (REX will continue cycling even when the\nRMS SPEC is deselected and RMC is rendered inactive).\nWhile active, HMC monitors for valid keyboard input. When an\nitem entry is received, pertinent keyboard data (the item\nnumber and the item data) is stored for the item entry processor\n(RUD), the item flag is set (causing REX to CALL RUD), and RMC\nWAITs for TIME__REX (.08) seconds. This WAIT insures that RUD\nwill process the currently stored data before HMC stores the\nnext keyboard data for RUD to process. Upon receipt of a new\nOPS, new SPEC, or a RESUME keyboard entry, RMC exits.\n\nd.\n\nOutput - Outputs from this module are specified in Table\n3.3.8.1-1.\n\ne.\n\nModule Reference Process\n\nSection\n\nReference\n\nRMS Executive\n\n3.3.8.4\n\nSCHEDULE\n\nBOOK:\n\nf.\n\nOFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\nDate 10/16/79\nRev\nPage 3. 3. 8.l~2\n\nModule Type and Attributes Type: Program\nAttributes: N/A\n\ng.\n\nTemplate References\n\n~\n\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE CRA TE\n\nWorking Compool\n\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE REXRMS\n\nRMS Executive\n\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE CZl COMMON\n\nSystem Services Common Compool\n\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE DIS PLAY\n\nDisplay Presentation and Control\n\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE DNX BMS\n\nApplication Moding and Sequencer\n\nD INCLUDE DAG#RAM\n\nCommon Grammer Macro Set\n\nD INCLUDE DCG#RAM\n\nSPEC Control Segment Grammer Macro Set\n\nD INCLUDE DDG#RAM\n\nAllows references to MCDS keyboard inputs\n\nD INCLUDE ZPRIOTIM\n\nContains REPLACE names for baseline\npriorities, phasing, and rates of\nSCHEDULE\'d processes\n\nD INCLUDE TIOMACS\n\nTimer Initiated I/O replaces\n\nD INCLUDE PREMACS\n\nPre~initialized\n\nI/O macros\n\nh.\n\nError Handling - Other than standard FCOS recovery, no error\nrecovery exists for this module.\n\ni.\n\nConstraints and Assumptions \xe2\x80\xa2\n\nItem entries are passed from DMC to RMC one at a time and\nRMC\xc2\xb7WAITs TIME REX (.08) seconds after each item entry.\nThus, if a multiple keyboard entry of 6 items was input,\neach separate item would require at least .08 seconds to\nprocess, resulting in at least .48 seconds to process the\ncomplete keyboard entry. If a new SPEC, new OPS or RESUME\nwere entered during this .48 second period, RMC would finish\nprocessing the item it was currently working on and the\nremaining items would not be processed.\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\nTimer Initiated I/O will control the reading of the MCIU\nfor RMS. A read will start and be completed just before\neach REX cycle begins. Reads will not occur in the\nmiddle of a cycle, even if REX cycle overruns.\n\nTABLE\n\n#\n\n3.3.8.1-1\n\nITEM\n\nDESCRIPTOR\n\nMODULE DATA LIST\n\nRMS Specialist Function Control Segment\n\nACT\n\nSOURCE/DESTINATION\n\n1\n\nHAL NAME\n\nI\n\n1\n\nKeyboard item number\n\nD.50\n\nR\n\nUI(DMC)\n\n2\n\nKeyboard item data\n\nD.50\n\nR\n\nUI(DMC)\n\n3\n\nKeyboard DEU nLLmber\n\nD.50\n\nR\n\nUI(DMC)\n\n4\n\nRMS SPEC initialization\nflag\n\nD.51\nA.2.32\n\nW\n\nREX\n\ni\n\nITEl-\'Um\nITEM_I\nTTEM_S\nDyEU_NUMBER\n\ni\n\nI\ni\n\nG:I\n\no\n\nREQT.\nSYMBOL\n\n:,: \xc2\xb71 L\n\n;\n\ni\nI\n\no\n\n..\n\n::II:\n\n..,\n\no\n\nI\n\n-4\n\nI\nI\n\nen\n\n==\n\n_.\n=~\n\nCRAB- RMS SPEC INIT\n-\n\nCD\n\nI\xc2\xbb\n\n5\n\n6\n\n\'-\n\n~\n\nItem number\n\n7\n\n~\n\nItem entry flag\n\nItem data\n\n8\n\nDElJ number\n\n9\n\nSIP start time\n\n10\n\nScheduling phase for REX\n\nD.52\nA.2.32\n\nW\n\nD.53\nA.2.32\nD.53\nA.2;32\n\nW\n\nRUD\n\nCRAV_I\'TEM_NO\n\nW\n\nRUD\n\nCRAV ITEM INTEGER\nCRAV-ITEM-SCALAR\n\nD.53\nA.2.32\n\nW\n\nD.54\n\nR\n\nZPRIOTIM\n\nZ\n\nPRASE REX\n\nPRIO- REX\n\nREX\n\nCRAB_ITEM_ENTRY\n\nCD\n\nI\n\n~\n\n_.\n=\nen\n\nCD\n\nRUD\n\nen\n\n=\n\nCRAV DEU NUM\n\n\'C\nCD\n\nSC (AlB)\n\n-\n\nCO)\n\nCZIV_A_TSIP\n\n11\n\nScheduling priority for\nREX\n\nZPRICTIM\nTEMPLATE\n\nZ\n\n12\n\nScheduling fre(J.uency of\nREX\n\nZPRIO\'l\'IM\nOT~LATE\n\nZ\n\nI\n\nTIME REX\n\nCO)\n\nI\xc2\xbb\n\nTE~PLATE\n\nCI\n\nI\n\n=\n\n-\n\n~.\\:6\nQ>;:d\n"""0\n\nZd\n\n?:C\n\nL\'O\n\n>-d\'5j\n\n>~\n\nQr\n\n8\'8\n\n_r--<\n(1).0\n>-d\':=j\n0;-3\n\n@::q\n8\n\n\'1:J\n\nt:J\n\nIlQ\n\nd-\n\n\'" \'"\n\n\'" \'"\n\nw\nw\nco\n\nr\n\nI\n\nw\n\nr\nI~\n\n~\n--:\n\n""\n\nTABLE 3.3.8.l-2\nDEVICE\n\nI/O SVC\nDEVICE\nID\n\nOP\n\nCODE\n\nSVC\nNO.\n\nI\n\nSYNC COMFAULT\nTYPE STATUS\n\nt - - - - - t - - - - - + - - - f - - + IMCIU\n\n57\n\n2\n\n40\n\nRS\n\nI\n\nICC\nTYPE\n\n1\n\nTIME\nTAG\n\n---Yes\n\nNo\n\nNo\n\nI\nWAIT\n\nI PROT.\n\n.\n\n--I\n\n1\n\nINPUT! RUD is CALL\'ed by the RMS Executive (REX)\nwhen RMC indicates that a valid entry haB been received from\n\nUr.\n\nInvocation:\n\nCALL RUD KYBD\n\nb.\n\nInp~ts-\n\nc.\n\nProcess Description - The control flow for this module is\nshown in Figure;3.3.8.2-1 through 3.3.8.2-8. RUD processes\nitem entries from the RMS Spec display. An arm is selected\nfor initialization via the PORT or STBD item entry. When a\nPOR\'r or STBD item iB executed, RUD updates the display with an\nasterisk to show the arm selected. Any saved data associated\nwith the arm selected is recalled to the display, and the old\ndisplay data not associated with the arm selected is blanked.\nA valid PL ID or EE item entry will be displayed and saved for\nrecall for the arm currently selected. \' When the MCIU I/O\nON/OFF item is executed, the MCIU I/O is turned on or off to\nindicate whether or not MCIU data acquisition is to be accompliE:hed. An astersik on the display denotes whether I/O is on\nor off. The runaway joint consistency check (CNTL ERR ENA/INH)\nand the Soft Stop Limits (SOFT STOP ENA/nm) are enabled or\ninhibited by their associated item entrie13. Asterisks denote\ntheir status. Valid Auto Sequence ID entries are displayed\nand assigned to their corresponding RMS auto sequence mode.\nRUD accepts and displays START PT item entries. This entry\ndesignates which prestored point in the selected auto sequence\nwill he used as the starting point. While the Resolved Position\nAlgorithm (RPO) is active, RUD rejects any OPR CMD MODE item\nentries (END POS, END ATT, PL INIT ID, and CMD CK). Accepted\nOPR CMD MODE data. is displayed. RUD SCHEDULE\'s RPO whenever a\nCMD CK item entry is accepted. If an illegal entry occurs,\nRUD enables the appropriate UI macro to generate annunciation\non the message line - (ILLEGAL ENTRY).\n\nInputs to this module are specified in Table 3.3.8.2-1.\n\nThere is no Spec cleanup processing.\nd.\n\nOutputs - Output from this module are specified in Table\n3.3.8.2-1.\n\nDate 10/16/79\nPage\n\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\ne.\n\nModule References Process\n\nSection\n\nReference\n\nResolved Position Algorithm\nf.\n\n3.3.8.2-2\n\n3.3.8.9\n\nSCHEDULE\n\nModule Type and Attributes Type: External Procedure\nAttributes: Default (serially reusable with no protective mechanism)\n\ng.\n\nTemplate References D\nD\nD\nD\nD\n\nINCLUDE\nINCLUDE\nINCLUDE\nINCLUDE\nINCLUDE\n\nTEMPLATE\nTEMPLATE\nTEMPLATE\nTEMPLATE\nDMA#MACS\n\nCRI LVC\nCRA TE\nCDL_ANNUN\nDMA MAC\n\nD INCLUDE ZPRIOTIM\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE CRF ASC\nh.\n\nLevel C Constants Compool\nWorking Compool\nSystem Service Annunciation Compool\nSystem Service Annunciation Routine\nSystem Service Error Annunciation\nMacro Replace Statements\nContains Replace Names for Baseline\nPriorities, Phasing, and rates of\nScheduled Processes\nPre-stored Auto Sequence Compool\n\nError Handling \xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\ni.\n\nRUD checks display entries in case of input errors. If a\ndisplay entry is incorrect, an ILLEGAL ENTRY message is\ndisplayed and the entry is not processed.\nStandard FCOS error recovery also exists for this module.\n\nConstraints and Assumptions - The user will not execute PORT/STBD\nitems while an OPR CMD check is in progress.\nIf the ARM and EE IDs are changed while RPO is rlmning, results\non the RMS control display may appear inconsistent.\n\nMODULE DATA LIST\n\nTABLE 3.3.8.2-1 RMS Item Processor\n\nITEM\n\n#\n1\n\nItem Number\n\n2\n\nDESCRIPTOR\n\nACT\n\nSOU RCEIDESTI NA TlON\n\nHAL NAME\n\nMML\n\nREQT.\nSYMBOL\n\n=\n\n~ fI""1I\n\n~\n\nvi IIUIIII\n\n0\n0\n\nA.2.32, D.53\n\nR\n\nRMC\n\nCRAV ITE.\'! ROLL). A bias value\nif? added and hand controller maximum deflection limit checking is applied\nto each component. If the resulting component value is within a prede-fined null deadband, then the component va1ue is set to zero. If any of\nthe HC component values are not within their respective null deadband\nlimits, then the HC NULL flag is turned OFF.\nIf an arm has been selected, joint rate processing is performed for\neach joint. First, the smoothing factors Kl and K2 are calculated.\nNext, the selected arm\'s payload dependent maximum joint rate limits\nare selected for use by the RMS software for the current cycle. The\nfiltered motor rates are computed using the smoothing factors Kl and\nK2, the unfiltered motor rate and the filtered motor rate from the\nlast pass. The filtered motor rates along with the joint gear ratios\nare then used to compute the joint rates. The filtered motor rates\nare then sto:::oed to be used 80S last pass rates in the next execution.\nIf an arm has been selected, joint position processing is performed\nfor each joint. The first five joints are limited io between -180\nand +180 and the sixth joint is limited from -4.50 to +450.\nNext, each new temperature thermistor reading for a valid arm is converted to degrees Fahrenheit for temperature limit checking in RIT and.\ndisplay in RDD. Each temperature, as calculated, is stored in an array\nof LED and ABE temperatures.\nAt this point, RYE exits.\nprocessing.\n\nThere is no SPEC initialization or cleanup\n\nd.\n\nOutputs - Outputs from this module are specified in Table 3.3.8.3-1.\n\ne.\n\nModule References - None\nRr~pn(r:}n\n\'( J\n\nElll\'l\'Y 01<\' TIJ)1;\n!." /\\ -( ~ fj; j S\n\nDa.te\nPage\n\nlO/16/\'T9\n\n3.3.8.3-2\n\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\nf.\n\nModule Type and Attributes Type: External Procedure\nAttributes,: Default (serially reusable with no protective mechanism)\n\ng.\n\nTemplate\nD\nD\nD\nD\n\nReferences~\n\nINCLUDE\nINCLUDE\nINCLUDE\nINCLUDE\n\nTEMPLATE\nTEMPLATE\nTEMPLATE\nTEMPLATE\n\nCRI_LVC\nCRA TE\nCRD CIL\nCRC-COT\n\nLevel C Constants Compool\nWorking Compool\nConstants and I-Load Compool\nRMS Constants Table\n\nh.\n\nError Handling Other than standard FCOS recovery, no error recovery\nexists for this module.\n\ni.\n\nConstraints and\n\nAssumption~\n\nThe TM SPEC input wrist roll range is reset to zero by RMSafter\nRMS takes the actual input value for use by the RMS softwa.re. It\nis assumed that the only values input for wrist roll range are one\nthrough six (1-6). Therefore, no validity checking is done.\n\nTABLE\n\n-\n\n3.3.8.3-1\n\nMODULE DATA LIST\n\nData Conversion Processor\n\n-------------------,-------------------r--------,------------------,-----------------------,------------------r--------~\n\n#\n\nITEM\n\nDESCRIPTOR\n\nACT\n\nSOURCE/DESTINATION\n\nI\n\nHAL NAME\n\nr-------t---------------------~--------------------+_--------~--------------------+_; I\n\nI\n\nMML\n\nREQT.\n\n1\n,\n\n1\n\n1\n\nHC(scaled HC components\n\nA.2.32\n\nI\n\nRC::)\n\nfRAIf_HC_COMP_SCALE\n\n2\n\nl,jCIU Frame ID Change\n\nA.2.32\n\nI\n\nRQC\n\nI - ,\n\nW--l\n\n~\n\nn\n\nE\n\nL\n\nH~\n\nW\n\nTABLE\n\n3.3.8.3-1 Data Conversion Processor (cont\'d)\n\n#\n\nITEM\n\nMODULE DATA LIST\n\nDESCRIPTOR\n\nACT\n\nSOURCE/DESTINATION\n\nHAL Fahrenheit Temperature Processing\n\nThen\n\nTD == ...,TD- Max\n\nDate\nPage\n\n10/16/79\n3.3.8.4-1\n\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\n3.3.8.4 RMS Executive (REX_RMSEXEC)\nThe RMS Executive (REX) provides I/O management and configuratipn control for\nthe RMS soft\'ware system.\na.\n\nControl Interface - The RMS Executive is SCHEDULE\'d by the RMS Specialist\nfunction Contro.lSegment (RMC) to execut~~ at 12. 5Hz. REX continues to\nexecute until a new OPS is selected.\nInvocation:\n\nSCHEDULE REX RMSEXEC AT PHAl3E REX PRIORITY\n(FRIO REX), REPEAT EVERY TIME-REX;\n(Refe;ence SAM 10)\n-\n\nb.\n\n1geuts - Inputs to this module are specified in Table 3.3.8.4-1.\n\nc.\n\nProcess Descrir;tion - The cont~ol flow for this module is shown in\nFigures 3.3.8.,-1 through 3.3.8.4-15. The RMS Executive controls\n6 \'basic functions:\n1.\n2.\n3.\n\n4.\n\n5.\n\n6.\n\nFirst pass initialization\nItem input processing\nMCIU input and error control\nConfiguration validation and control\nFunction sequencing\nMCIU output\n\nThe first time REX is entered\nzation is done.\n\n~fter\n\nbeing scheduled, first pass initiali-\n\nIttem input processing is done with a CALL to RMS Item Processor (RUD)\nwhen a keyboard input is received by RMS Specialist Function Control\nSegment (BMC).\nThte configuration item contains the curr~mt RMS sof\xc2\xb7tware configuration.\nConfiguration request is set when a different configuration is required\nor when one of the non-requested I!!onfigurations (SUSF\'END, TEMP, or IDLE)\nis required (even if the software is alr~3ady in that configuration).\nThe variable, configuration\' req,uest, is alw,ays initialized to NONE. It\nchl3.nges only when the operator requests !t new configuration or if any\ncondition exists that requires the SUSPEND, TEMP, or IDLE configuration.\nThe MCIU I/O flag which determines the I/O status (ON or OFF) on the\nRMB Control Display is tested. Whenever the I/O is OFF the RMS software\nis to be in the SUSPEND configuration.\nWhen I/O is ON, REX CALL\'s the Input Processing and Configuration Determination Module (RQC). RQC performs input error processing and performs\nconfiguration d.etermination.\n\n. l\'rY OF THE\nREPIWD UCIBI1J,\' ~,\nv\nORIGINAL PAG11; 18 POOR\n\nDate\nPage\n\n10/16/79\n\n3.3.8.4-2\n\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\nREX CALL\'s the Configuration Initialization Module (RXY) when the MeIU\ninput is valid and the requested configuration is different from the\ncurrent configuration, or the requested configuration is SUSPEND, SINGLE,\nMANUAL, or AUTO, and the requested configuration cannot be equal to NO~E.\nThe configuration\xc2\xb7 state is updated, configuration entry unique processing\nis performed,and standard reconfiguration initialization is also done.\nWhen MCIU input is valid and the software is not in the SUSPEND configuration, REX CALL\'s the Position Hold Checks Module (RWP), performs function\nsequencing, and WRITE\'s to the MCIU.\nFunction sequencing is accomplished via a dispatcher and a dispatcher\ntable for the current configuration. The dispatcher issues CALL\'s to\nthe modules required for the current configuration. The dispatcher\ntables are specified in Tables 3.3.8.4-2 through 3.3.8.4-6 and contain\nfrequency, phasing, and active/iriactive status for each module.\nREX cleanup processing consists of saving last pass flags.\nd.\n\nOutputs - Outputs from this module are specified in Table 3.3.8.4-1.\n\ne.\n\nModule References Process\nRMS Item Processor (RUD)\n\'I\'emperature Processor (RIT)\nDedicated Display (RDD)\nKinematic Data Generator (RKG)\nHealth Monitor (RHM)\nTotal Velocity (RTV)\nEncoder Function (RNC)\nHand Controller (RJS)\nResolved Rate Processor (RRP)\nAutomatic Sequence Processor (RAS)\nPosition Hold (RFP)\nSingle Joint Control (RSC)\nInput Processing and Configuration\nDetermination (RQC)\nConfiguration Initialization (RXY)\nPosition Hold Checks (RWP)\n\nf.\n\nModule Type and Attributes\nType: Program\nAttributes: Single direct drive positive/negative, auto sequence\nproceed/stop, capture/releas~ command, rigidize/derigidize command, EE\nauto/manual, arm select index and EE rig:i,dized/derigidized discretes\nare also integerized. Processing\n\n\\ \'.\n\nDate\nPage\n\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed\n\nDesi~ln\n\n10/16/79\n3.3.8.6-1\n\nSpeci\'fication\n\n3.3.8.6 Kinematic Data Generator\n\n(RKG_KINGEN)\n\nThe Kinematic Data Generator (RKG) computes the sines and cosines of the\narm joint angles, computes the R-matrices, and derives the point of resolution\n(POR) position and attitude from joint angle data.\na.\n\nControl Interface - RKG is CALL\'ed by the RMS Executive (REX) at\nl~~. 5 HZ.\nInvocation:\n\nCALL RKG KINGEN\n\nb.\n\nInputs - Inputs to this module are specified in Table 3.3.8.6-1.\n\nc.\n\nProcess Description - The control flow for this module is shown.\nin Figures 3.3.8.6-1 through 3.3.8.6-7. The HAL variable names\nand other symbols taken directly from the Level C FSSR are\ndocumented in the module data list under the Requirement Symbol\nheading. RKG computes the sine and cosine of each joint angle.\nA1so computed are the sines and cosines of the sum of the shoulder\npitch and elbow pitch and the sum of the shoulder pitch, elbow pitch,\nand wrist pitch. These sines and cosines are used in the computation\nof the following matrices.\nL\n\n2.\n\n3.\n\nPOR REF to as REF\nPOR REF to AM REF\nOS REF to AM REF\n\nAlso used in the computation of the above matrices are the arm\nswingout angle, EE REF to AM REF R-Matrix for the active arm,\nand the PL REF to EE REF R-Matrix for the selected payload.\nThe distance computations determine the following distances used\nin later computations: the distance from the wrist yaw joint\nto the end effector tip; the distance from the wrist pitch joint\nto the end effector tip, projected onto the X-Z plane of the arm\nreference frame, and the X-component (in the arm reference frame)\nof the vector from the shoulder yaw joint to the wrist yaw joint.\nThe distances calculated above, arm member lengths, and sine and\ncosines of the joint angles are used to compute the position\nof the point of resolution in the arm reference fraxlle. The\npoint of resolution position in the orbiter structural frame\nand in the orbiter body axis frame is computed using the attach\npoint for the active arm, the transpose of the OS to AM R-Matrix,\nthe point of resolution position in the AM reference frame computed above, and the vector from the end effector tip to the point\nof resolution for the selected payload.\nThe Euler angles defining the POR attitude in the as Reference frame\nare computed using the POR to OS R-Matrix.\nThere is no SPEC initialization or clean up processing.\n\n/-{\'7\'1\n\nDate\nOFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\nBOOK:\n\n10/16/79\n\nPage\n\n3. 3.8. 6-2\n\nd.\n\nOutputs - Outputs from this module are specified in Table 3.3.8.6-1.\n\ne.\n\nModule RefereGces - None\n\nf.\n\nModule Type and Attributes Type: External Procedure\nAttributes: Default (serially reusable with no protective mechanism).\n\ng.\n\nTemplate References D INCLUDE TEMPLATE CRA TE\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE CRD CIL\nD INCLUDE.TEMPLATE CRI LVC\n\nWorking Compool\nConstants and I-Load Compool\nLevel C Constants Compool\n\nh.\n\nError Handling - The inputs to the inverse trigonometric functions are\ntested to eliminate any out-of-range inputs that cause a run-time error\nmessage. Other than standard FCOS recovery, no error recovery exists\nfor this module.\n\ni.\n\nConstraints and Assumptions - The point of resolution and attitude\ncomputations assume that the arm has been swung out (swing out angle\nis a constant in computations).\nThe first payload subscript in the arrays V_EE_POR_SEL and\nPL_TO_EE_OP_SEL reference the no payload case. Therefore, the\nfirst vector and matrix, respectively, should be initialized\nto a (0,0,0) vector and a 3X3 identity matrix.\nIn order to protect the arcsin function from arguments outside of\nthe range [-l~\'l ] \' ABS (POR_TO_OS(2,l)) is restricted to be less than\n1.\n\nTABLE\n\nMODULE DATA LIST\n\n3.3.8.6-1 Kinematic Data Generator\n\n#\n\nITEM\n\nDESCRIPTOR\n\nACT\n\nSOURCE/DESTINATION\n\nHAL NAME\n\nMML\n\n=\n\n~~~~\'OL\n\n~\n\n1\n\nA:rrL Select This\nmodule allows an operator to operate a single joint of the RMS while the other\njoints hold their last commanded position.\na.\n\nControl Interface - RSC is CALL\'ed by theRMS Executive (REX) at 12.5 Hz.\nInvocation:\n\nCALL RSC SINCTL\n\nb.\n\nInput~\n\nc.\n\nProcess Description - The control flow for this module is shown in\nFigures 3.3.8.7-1 through 3.3.8.7-3. RSC performs first pass\ninitialization. If the selected joint is new, RSC resets the RSC\nposition hold flag, the ramp counter, and the past value of the arm\ndireetion. If the selected joint is unchanged, is now moving, and\nwas at rest last pass, the ramp counter is reset.\n\n- Inputs to this module are specified in Table 3.3.8.7-1.\n\nIf the joint is not commanded, and if the\noff and the arm is at rest, the RSC joint\njoint angle and RSC position hold flag is\nrate is set to zero. If the RSC position\nrate command is computed.\n\nRSC position hold flag is\nangle is set to the current\nset. Otherwise, the joint\nhold flag is on, the joint\n\nIf the joint is commanded, and if vernier scaling is desired, the\nvernier joint rates are used. If not, the coarse rates are selected.\nFor the commanded joint, the joint rate ie: set to the rate computed\nearl:ier. Joint dependent rate sign changes are done next. The RSC\nposition hold flag is reset and the joint rate is ramped up to the\nappropriate limit over several cycles. The joint rate is held until\nanother operator choice of either joint or direction is made. All other\njoints are held at the same positions as \'\\-Then the operated joint was\nselected. \'J:here is no SPEC initialization or clean up processing.\nd.\n\nOutput - Outputs for this module are specified in Table 3.3.8.7-1.\n\ne.\n\nModule References - None\n\nf.\n\nModule Type and Attributes Type: External Procedure\nAttributes: Default (serially reusable with no protective mechanism)\n\n10/16/19\n\n3.3.8.1- 2\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\ng.\n\nTemplate References D\nD\nD\nD\n\nINCLUDE\nINCLUDE\nINCLUDE\nINCLUDE\n\nTEMPLATE\nTEMPLATE\nTEMPLATE\nTEMPLATE\n\nCRA\nCRD\nCRI\nCRE\n\nTE\nCIL\nLVC\nMCO\n\nWorking Compool\nConstants and I-Load Compool\nLevel C Constants Compool\nOutput Compool\n\nh.\n\nError Handling - Other than standard FCOS recovery, no error recovery\nexists for this module.\n\ni.\n\nConstraints and.Assumptions - RSC overlays the position hold value\nfrom RFP for the selected joint to be commanded in single configuration.\n\nTABLE\n\n#\n1\n\n3.3.8.7-1\n\nSingle Joint Control\n\nITEM\n\nDESCRIPTOR\n\nMODULE DATA CMD(JNT\nSwitch Index)\n\nFigure 3.3.8.7-3.\n\nArm In Motion Processing\n\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\n3.3.8.8\n\nDate 10/16/79\nRev\nPage 3.3.8.8-1\n\nHand Controller (RJS_HANDCTL)\n\nThe Hand Controller (RJS) module converts hand controller deflections into\npoint of resolution (POR) rate commands, interprets rate hold requests and subsequent hand controller inputs, limits resultant POR rate commands and transforms\nthose commands from the coordinate system selected by the operator to the arm\nreference system.\na.\n\nControl Interface - RJS is CALL\'ed by the RMS Executive (REX) at 12.5 Hz.\nInvocation:\n\nCALL RJS HANDCTL\n\nb.\n\nInputs - Inputs to this module are specified in Table 3.3.8.8-1.\n\nc.\n\nProcess Description - The control flow for this module is shown in Figure\n3.3.8.8-1 through 3.3.8.8-5. When entered, RJS determines if there has\nbeen an operator request to select or deselect the rate hold ~o0e by\ncomparing the state of the rate hold push button for the current and\nprevious cycles. If its state has changed then the state of the rate\nhold processing is changed. A change in the state of payload capture\nalso changes the state of rate hold processing. Initially, the state\nof rate hold processing is OFF. RJS determines the appropriate set\nof limits to be applied to POR rate command resultants. RJS then converts\nhand controller deflections into POR rate commands using a normal set of\nscaling factors. If the rate hold mode is selected for the first time,\nthe EE rates at the time of selection are retained until the rate hold\nmode is de-selected. On all subsequent times that RJS processes in a rate\nhold mode, and the hand controllers are nulled., all inputs are treated\nas biases to the previously saved translation and rotation rate commands.\nThe POR rate commands in the rate hold mode are then computed as the sum\nof the retained rates and the biases. Whether or not in the rate hold\nmode, the commanded translational and rotational rate vectors are scaled\nsuch that its resultant magnitude is equal to the appropriate maximum\nrate. POR rate command.s are transformed from the selected reference\nsystem to the arm reference system.\n\nd.\n\nOutputs - Outputs from this module are specified in Table 3.3.8.8-1.\n\ne.\n\nModule References - None\n\nf.\n\nModule Type and Attributes Type:\n\nExternal Procedure\n\nAttributes:\ng.\n\nDefault (serially reusable with no protective mechanism)\n\nTemplate References D\nD\nD\nD\n\nINCLUDE TEMPLATE CRA_TE Working Compool\nINCLUDE TEMPLATE CRC COT RMS Constants Table\nINCLUDE TEMPLATE CRD CIL Constants and I-Load Compool\nINCLUDE TEMPLN1\'f\'~ CRE MCO OutPl,t data Compool\n\nh.\n\nError Handli_~ - Other than ,;tandard FCOS recovery, no error recovery\nexists for this module.\n\ni.\n\nConstraints and Assumptions - None\n\nTABLE\n\n3.3.8.8-1\n\n#\n\nHand POR Conversion\n\nDate\nPage\n\nOFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\nBOOK:\n\n3.3.8.9.\n\n10/16/79\n3.3.8.9-1\n\n1{eso1ved Position Algorithm (RPOyPOS)\n\nThe Resolved Position Algorithm (RPO) module determines the validity of a\ndesired po:Lnt of resolution (POR) position and attitude for a choser:. arm, end\neffector, and payload. The desired point of resolution may be either the end\neffector or some other point associated with a payload.\na.\n\nControl Interface - RPO is SCHEDULEld by the RMS Item Processor (RUD_KYBD)\non demand.\nInvocation:\n\nSCHEDULE RPO_PROS PRIORITY (PRIO_RPO)\n\nb.\n\nlpputs - Inputs to this module are spec:ified in Table 3.3.8.9-1.\n\nc.\n\nProcess Description - The control flow for this module is shown in\nFigures 3.3.8.9-1 through 3.3.8.9-9. The HAL variable nrunes and other\nsymbols taken directly from the Level C FSSR are documented in the\nmodule data list under the Requirement Symbol heading.\nRPO begins processing by copying the input data intoloc.al storage and\nthen setting up various vectors to be used in the subsequent reference\nframe calculations. Next the shoulder and wrist yaw angles are processed.\nBased on the occurrence of the wrist yaw singularity, a single or dual\npass flag is set. Next RPO computes elbow and shoulder pitch angles.\nIf the wrist singularity condition did not occur, then the wrist pitch\nis also calculated. At any point where the calculated angle exceeds\nthe soft stop limits, the fail flag is turned ON and second iteration\nis tested. If a second iteration occur~, the pitch inputs are modified\nand the second iteration controls are set to terminate after completion\nof the second iteration.\nBPO checks the fail flag and sets the operator command check index to\n\'GOOD\' or \'FAIL\' accordingly for CRT display and for output to the\nAutomatic Sequence Processor (RAS).\nAt this point RPO returns.\nprocessing.\n\nThere is no SPEC initialization or cleanup\n\nd.\n\n.Outputs - Outputs from this module\n\ne.\n\nModule References - None\n\nf.\n\nModule Type. and Attributes Type:\n\nProgram\n\nAttributes:\n\nN/A\n\n50 (/\n\narE~\n\nspecified in Table 3.3.8.9-1.\n\nDate 10/16/79\nBOOK:\n\nOFT SM Detailed Design Specification\ng.\n\nPage\n\n3.3.8.9-2\n\nTemplate References D\nD\nD\n\nINCLUDE TEMPLATE CRD CIL\nINCLUDE TEMPLATE CRA TE\nINCLUDE TEMPLATE CRI LVC\n\nConstants and I-Load Compool\nWorking Compool\nLevel C Constants Compool\n\nh.\n\nError Handling - Other than standard FCOS recovery, no error recovery\nexists for this module.\n\ni.\n\nConstraints and Assumptions - RPO checks to see if the arm can attain\nsome~combination of joint angles that will place the point of\nresolution (POR) at the coordinates input by the operator. The\n\'GOOD\' response indicates that the point is attainable by the\nhardware, not that the point is desirable or safe or avoids collision.\nSince RPO is not an exact inversion of the RKG major function, RPO\ncannot\nvalidate every point attainable by the arm. While RPO\nis active, the RMS Item Processor (RUD) inhibits the updating\nof the OPR CMD sequence data via an illegal entry message. The\nintegrity of the data processed by RPO and subsequently by the\nAutomatic Sequence Processor (RAS) is ensured by the blanking of\nthe OPR CMD CHECK INDEX prior to SCHEDULE\'ing RPO. RAS receives its\ndata directly from RPO only after a successful verification of a\nsequence. The \'FAIL\' or blank status of the OPR CMD CHECK INDEX\ninhibits execution of the data by RAS.\n\n3.3.8.9-1\n\nTABLE\n\nITEM\n\n#\n1\n\nReso:ved Position Algorithm\n\nMODULE DATA SP+SR CP,-SR SY SP+CR CP)\n\nI\nV_EE_POR(l) = V_EE_POR_SEL(PID:l)\nVyE]OR(2) = -VyE]OR_SEL(PID:2)\nV_EE_POR(3) = -V_EE_POR_SEL(PID:3)\n\n1\nPL_TOyE(l,l)= RAS is CALL\' ed by\n12.5 Hz.\nInvocation:\n\nthE~\n\nRMS Executive (REX) at\n\nCALL RASyUTOSEQ\n\nb.\n\nInputs - Inputs to this module are specified in Table 3.3.8.10-1.\n\nc.\n\nProcess Description - The control flow for this module is shown\nin \'Figures 3.3.8.10-1 through 3.3.8.10-15.\nRAS processing on the first auto configuration cycle consists of\nvalidation checks for an operator commanded sequence or a prestored auto sequence and initialization for the sequence when valid.\nOperator commanded sequence validation consists of verifying that\nthe Resolved Position Algorithm (RPO) deelared the sequence \'GOOD\'\nand that the arm and payload used by RPO are the ones currently in\nuse by the RMS software. If all checks are successful, the Auto\nSequence Ready light and Next Point Flag are turned ON.\nPre\xc2\xb7-stored auto sequence validation consj.sts of verifying that:\n\n1.\n\nThe arm specified in the sequence matches the arm selected,\n\n2.\n\nThe EE specified in the sequence matches the EE selected,\n\n3.\n\nIf the au toma tic sequence is designE!d for an unloaded arm,\nthen a payload is not captured,\n\n4.\n\nIf a payload is specified in the sequence, it matches the\nselected payload,\n\n5.\n\nThe current POR position and attitude meet the initial\ntolerance condition of the starting point in the sequence.\n\nIf all checks are successful, the Auto Sequence Ready light is\nturned ON, the desired EE position and attitude vectors are\ninitialized, and the transformation matrix (from orbiter structural\nframe to POR orientation) is computed.\nIf this is not the first time that the auto sequence module (RAS)\n\nis to be executed and the Waiting Flag is ON, the waiting mode\nis processed. If the sequence is invalid, RAS remains in the\nposition hold mode. But if the sequence is valid and the operator\nrequests a continuation of the automatic sequence, the progressing\nmode is entered.\n\nDate\nRev\nPage\n\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\n10/16/79\n3.3.8.10-2\n\nIf a new trajectory point is to be acquired, vectors are computed for the\ndesired position and attitude, translation and rotation rates for the\npoint of resolution are computed, and checks for either stopping or\ncontinning a trajectory are made.\nIf the operator requests the sequence to stop, the current mode is\ncancelled and the time mode is initialized. If a pause is requested,\nthe position and attitude errors are checked to determine if the point\nof resolution is within the washout region. If the point of resolution\nis within the washout region, the point of resolution rates are decreased\nsuch that the desired sequence point is achieved. When the point of\nresolution is not to stop at the point it is moving toward, RAS determines\nif it is within the fly-by region. When the point of resolution is\nwithin the fly-by region, the point has been reached and RAS proceeds\nto acquire the next point. Whenever the arm is stopped at a point in\nthe pre-stored auto sequence, the point number is output to the RMS\ncontrol display. When the arm is moving, the most recently passed point\nnumber is output to the display.\nWhen the arm has been stopped, the Auto Sequence in Progress light is\nturned OFF and if the last point in a pre-stored auto sequence has not\nbeen reached, then the Auto Sequence Ready light is turned ON to allow the\noperator to resume execution of that sequence.\nThere is no SPEC initialization or cleanup processing.\nd.\n\nOutput - Outputs from this module are specified in Table 3.3.8.10-1.\n\ne.\n\nModule References - None\n\nf.\n\nModule Type and Attributes Type:\n\nExternal Procedure\n\nAttributes:\ng.\n\nTemplate References D\nD\nD\nD\nD\n\nh.\n\nDefault (serially reusable with no protective mechanism)\n\nINCLUDE\nINCLUDE\nINCLUDE\nINCLUDE\nINCLUDE\n\nTEMPLATE\nTEMPLATE\nTEMPLATE\nTEMPLATE\nTEMPLATE\n\nCRA TE\nCRE MCO\nCRD-CIL\nCRC_COT\nCRF ASC\n\nWorking Compool\nOutput Compool\nConstants Compool\nRMS Constants Table\nPre-stored Auto Sequence Compool\n\nError Handling - Other than standard FCOS recovery, no error recovery\nexists for this module.\n\nBOOK:\n\ni.\n\nOFT 8M Detailed Design Specification\n\nDate\nRev\nPage\n\n10/16/79\n3.3.8.10-3\n\nConstraints and Assumptions \xe2\x80\xa2\n\nThe final point in a pre-stored auto sequence is always a\npause point.\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\nA valid pre-stored auto sequence wlll always have more than one\npoint.\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\nThere are no requirements for positive feedback to the crew\non the following errors:\nrequestE~d\n\n1.\n\nOperator command mode\ncheck is "FAIL".\n\nand operator command\n\n2.\n\nOperator command mode requested and a different arm,\nPL or EE is selected than the one used by Resolved\nPosition Algorithm (RPO).\n\n3.\n\nNo pre-stored auto sequence has been initialized for\nthe selected auto submode.\n\n4.\n\nAuto sequence is requested and the arm, EE, or payload\ndoes not match the ones specified in the pre-stored\nsequence.\n\n5.\n\nAuto sequence is requested and the initial tolerance\nconditions are not met.\n\n6.\n\nAuto sequence is requested and the auto sequence start\npoint from RMS control is out of the valid range of\npoint numbers.\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\nThe position and attitude specified for non-pause points may\nnot be achieved.\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\nThere is a possibility of collision between payload and orbiter/\nobstructions unless simulations of the auto sequences are performed and validated for the pay10ad(s) to be used prior to\nflights.\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\nA valid operator commanded sequence from RPO indicates that\nthe point is attainable by the hardware, not that the point\nis desirable, safe, avoids collision nor avoids reach limits.\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\nThe washout region is larger than the flyby region, which is\nlarger than the position hold region.\n\nTable 3.3.8.10-1\n\nAutomatic Sequence Flag-Off\nL-. _____\n\n-\n\n-\n\nIAuto Seq Last Point=\nPointer-l\n\nTI\n\nDate\nBOOK:\n\nOFT SM Software Design Specification\n\n3.3.8.11\n\nRev\nPage\n\n10/16/79\n3.3.8.11-1\n\nResolved Rate Processor (RRP_RRATE)\n\nRRP transforms end effector translation and rotation rate commands (in the\narm-reference system) into joint angle rate commands. RRP monitors for and\nresolves arm control law singularities and excessive joint rate commands.\na.\n\nControl Interface _. RRP is CALL\' eq. by the RMS Executive (REX) at 12.5 Hz.\nInvoca.tion - CALL RRP RRATE\n\nb.\n\nInputs.- Inputs to this module are specified in Table 3.3.8.11-1.\n\nc.\n\nProcess Description - The control flows for this module are shown in Figures\n3.3. 8 .11-1 through -3.3.8.11-7. The HAL variable names a:nd other symbols taken\ndirectly from the LevellC FSSR are documented in the module data list under\nthe Requirement SYTnbol heading.\nRRP first performs the shoulder yaw joint rate processing an(q. singularity\nchecking. If the magnitude of the "X" distance is less than 1 X 10- 8\n(approximately zero), the arm is in the shoulder singularity condition and\nis commanded away from the condition using a shoulder yaw joint rate command\nequal to the maximum joint rate or zero, dependent on the \xc2\xb7computed value of\nthe y-component of the wrist yaw velocity. Otherwise, the shoulder yaw joint\nrate command is computed for the non-singularity condition.\nRRP next performs wrist yaw and roll rate command processing and wrist singularity checking. If the absolute value of the cosine of the wrist yaw\njoint angle is lese; than the sine of the proximity tolerance angle, then\nthe arm is approaching the wrist singularity condition and the wrist singu~\nlarity flag in turned ON. If the absolute value .of the cosine of the wrist\nyaw joint angle computed value is less than 1 X 10- 8 , the arm is in the\nsingularity conditi.on. The arm is driven out of this condition by determining\nthe command which yields the largest rate independent of ~he rotation direction. The command is limited such that it does not exceed the maximum\nlimit f\'or the wrist yaw. The wrist roll rate is zero in the singularity\ncondition. If the arm is not in this s:tngularity condition, the wrist yaw\nand roll joint rate commands are computed.\nRRP then performs the end effector velocity value computations, pitch\njoint rate command processing and elbow singularity checking. If the absolute\nvalue of the difference of the elbow pitch angle and elbcw offset angles is\nless than the proximity tolerance, the arm is approaching the elbow singularity\ncondition ang the elbow singularity flag is turned ON. If the value is less\nthan 1 X 10- , the arm :is in the elbow singularity condition. The arm is\ndri ven from the condition with the shoulder yaw j oint rate command equal to\nthe computed value of the linear velocity along the arm segment from the\nelbow pitch joint to the wrist pitch joint. The elbow pitch and wrist pitch\nrate commands are then computed.\n\nBOOK:\n\nOFT SM Software Design Specification\n\nDate 10/16/79\nRev\n\nPage\n\n3.3.8.11-2\n\nAfter all the joint rate commands are computed, the. values are compared to\nthe maximum allowable joint rates. If any values are out of limits, the\nvalue that is out of limits by the greatest percentage is used to reduce all\njoint rate commands proportionally.\nThere is no SPEC initialization or cleanup processing.\nd.\n\nOutputs - Outputs from this module are specified in Table 3.3.8.11-1.\n\ne.\n\nModule References - None\n\nf.\n\nModule TYPe and Attributes Type:\n\nExternal Procedure\n\nAttributes:\ng.\n\nDefaul t (serially reusable with no protective mechanism).\n\nTemplate References\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE CRA TE\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE CRD CIL\n\nWorking Compool\nConstants and I-Load Compool\n\nh.\n\nError Handling - Other than standard FCOS recovery, no error recovery exist\nfor this module.\n\ni.\n\nConstraints and Assumptions - None.\n\nTABLE\n\n#\n\n3.3.8.ll-L\n\nResolved Rate Processor\n\nITEM\n\nDESCRIPTOR\n\n1\n\nCommanded EE\nTranslational Rate (AM)\nConnnanded EE\nRotational Rate (AM)\n\nA.2.32\n\nACT\n\nSOU RCE/DESTI It also computes the resultant\nof the actual and commanded POR translation rate components.\na.\n\nControl Interface - RTV is CALL\'ed by the RMS Executive (REX) at 12.5 Hz.\nInvocation:\n\nCALL RTV TOTVEL\n\nb.\n\nInputs - Inputs to this module are spedfied in Table 3.3.8.12-1\n\nc.\n\nProcess Description - The control flow for this module is shown in\nFigures 3.3.8.12-1 through 3.3.8.12-3. The HAL variable names and other\nsymbols taken directly from the Level C FSSR are documented in the\nmodule data list under the Requirement Symbol heading.\nRTV performs \'I\'ranslational and Rotational Rate Processing twice; once\neach for actual and commanded rates. ~~ranslational and Rotational\nRate Processing ca.lculate the point of resolution rate components\nin the AM reference frame, the resultant point of resolution\ntranslation rate, the point of resolution translation rate components\nin the selected reference frame, and the point of resolution rota:tion rate components in the selected reference frame. The reference\nframes for the translation and rotation vectors are determined by the\nselected translation index and the selected rotation index which are\nused to subscript an array of transformation matrices. After both the\nactual and commanded rates have been processed, RTV returns. There\nis no SPEC initialization or cleanup processing.\n\nd.\n\nQJJ,:tlluts - Outputs from this module are specified in Table 3.3.8.l2-l.\n\ne.\n\nModule References _ None\n\nf.\n\nModule Type and Attributes -\n\nREPRODUCIBILITY. OF\' T~lE\nORIGH\\1AL PAG11~ IS POOl?,\n\nType: External Procedure\nAttributes: Default (seria.lly reusable with no protective mechanism)\ng.\n\nTemplate References D INCLUDE TEMPLATE CRD CIL\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE CRA TE\n\nConstantB and I-Load Compool\nWorking Compool\n\nh.\n\nError Handling - Other than Btandard FCOS recovery, no error recovery\nexists for this module.\n\ni.\n\nConstraints and Assumptions - None\n\nTABLE\n\n#\n\n3.3.8.12-1\n\nTotal Velocity\n\nITEM\n\n1\n\nJoint angle rates\n\nDESCRIPTOR\n\nMODULE DATA LIST\n\nACT\n\nA.2.32\n\nI\n\nSOURCE/DESTINATION\n\ni\n\n!\n\nI\n\nRYE\n\n-\n\ndAL NAME:\n\nCRAV_JAR_ATL\n\nI\n!\n\nI\n\nREQT\nSYMBOL\n\nMIVi,-\n\nVY2R3310C-315C\n\nJOINT_RATES\n\nI:U\nQ\nQ\n\n=-=\n..\n\n..,\n....\nQ\n\n2\n\nJoint angle rate\ncommands\n\nA.2.32\n\nI\n\nRXY ,RRP,RFP,RSC\n\nCRAV_JAR_CMD\n\n\'\\ V92R3205C-2l0C\n\nJ"OINT_RATE_\nCMD\n\n(I)\n\n==\n\n_.\n~\n\n3\n\nSine of shoulder pitch\n-~\n\nA.2.32\n\nI\n\nRKG\n\nCRAV JA SIN$(2)\n\nV92H3341C\n\n4\n\nSine of wrist yaw angle\n\nA.2.32\n\nI\n\nRKG\n\nCRAV_JA_SIN$(5)\n\nV92H3344c\n\nS5\n\n5\n\nCosine of shoulder pitch\nangle\n\nA.2.32\n\nI\n\nRKG\n\nCRAV JA COS$(2)\n- -\n\nV92H3351C\n\n2\n\n6\n\nCosine of wrist yaw\nangle\n\nA.2.32\n\nI\n\nRKG\n\nCRAVjA_COS$(5)\n\nV92H3354c\n\nb5\n\n~\'\'\\t\n\nCD\n\nI\xc2\xbb\n\n--\n\nCD\n\nCI.\n\n~\n\nen\n_.\n=\nCD\n\n:::I\n\n(I)\n\nr "\n\nr \'\\\n\\...1\\\n\nS2\n\nT\n\nSine of th:, sum of the\nshoulder p~tch and elbow\npitch angles\n\nA.2.32\n\nI\n\nRKG\n\nCRAVjA_Sn!23\n\nV98u3347C\n_\n\n~23\n\n8\n\nCosine of the sum of the\nshoulder pitch and elbow\npitch angles\n\nA.2.32\n\nI\n\nRKG\n\nCRAV_JA30S23\n\nV98U3356c\n\n23\n\nSine of the sum of the\nshoulder pitch, elbow\npitch, and wrist pitch\nangles\n\nA.2.32\n\nI\n\nRKG\n\nCRAV JA SIN234\n- -\n\nV92H3348C\n\nCosine of the SUIIl of the\nshoulder pitch, elbow\npitch, and wrist pitch\nangles\n\nA. 2. 32\n\nI\n\nRKG\n\nCRAV JA COS234\n- -\n\nV92H3358C\n\nC234\n\n11\n\nDistance from the wrist\nyaw joint to the endeffector tip\n\nA.2.32\n\nI\n\nRKG\n\nCRAV L WY EET\n- - RFP is CALL\'ed by the RMS Executive (REX) at 12.5 Hz.\nInvoeation - CALL RFP\n\npas\n\nHOLD\n\nb.\n\n.Inputs - Inputs to this module are specified in Table 3.3.8.13-1.\n\nc.\n\nPrOCE~SS Description - The control flow for this module is shown in Figure\n\xc2\xb73.3.13.13-1. RFP calculates the joint angle errors by subtracting the actual\njoint angles from the joint angle commands. The joint angle errors are then\nconverted to joint angle rate commands by multiplying the joint angle errors\nby their corresponding conversion factors. If any of the computed joint\nangle rate commands exceeds its respective limits, it is reduced to its maximum limit. There is no SPEC initialization or cleanup processing.\n\nd.\n\nOutp\':ts - Outputs from this module are spE!cified in Table 3.3.8.13-1.\n\ne.\n\nModQLe Reference - None\n\nf.\n\nModQLe Type and Attributes Type:\n\nExternal Procedure\n\nAttributes:\ng.\n\nDefault (serially reusable with no protective mechanism).\n\nTemplate References. D INCLUDE TEMPLATE CRA_TE Working Compool\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE CRD CIL Constants and I-Load Compool\n\nh.\n\nError Handling - Other than standard FCOS recovery, no error recovery exists\nfor this module.\n\ni.\n\nConstraints and Assumptions - None\n\nTABLE\n\n3.3.8.13-1.\n\nPosition Hold\n\nMODULE DATA LIST\n\nCIO\n\n#\n\nITEM\n\nDESCRIPTOR\n\nACT\n\nSOU RCE/DESTI NATION\n\nHAL NAME\n\no\no\n;:lI:::\n\nMML\n\n..\n\n1\n\nJoint Angles\n\n2\n\nCommanded Joint Angles\n\nA.2.32\n\nA.2.32\n\nI\n\nI\n\nRYE\n\nRWP\n\nCRAV JA ATL\n\nCRAV_JA_CMD\n\nV92H3300C-305C\n\no\n..,\n\nV92H3235C-24oc\n\n3:\n\n~\nV)\n\n-\n\n~\n\nCD\n\n3\n\nMaximum Joint Rate\nLimits\n\nA.2.32\n\nI\n\n4\n\nJoint Angle Conversion\nFactor\n\nA.2.33\n\nZ\n\nJoint Rate Commands\n\nA.2.32\n\nRYE\n\n_.\n\nI\xc2\xbb\n\n=-\n\nCRAV_JNT_RATE_LIM\n\nCD\n\nCRDK_RFP_JNT_CF\n\n~\n\nCD\n\n5\n\n0\n\nRNC, RRM, DL, RTV\n\nCRAV_JAR3 MD\n\nen\n\nV92R3205C-2l0C\n\nct:I\n\n==\nen\n\n6\n\nJoint Angle Error\n\nE\n\nL\n\n\'C\n\nRFPYELTAJA\n\nCD\n\nn\n\n,---"\n\n~\n\nn\n\n~;"\'\\;\n\nI\xc2\xbb\n\n\\.).\n\nCI\n\n==\n\n,\nwe-\'\n\n.0\n\nw-""\n\n.r\'\n00 a-,\n\n. -....\n,...-.J\n\nw\xc2\xb7\'"\nI\n\'0\n\nI\n\\\n\nDate 10/16/19\nPage 3.3.8.13-3\n\nBOOK: OFT 8M Detailed Des:lgn 8pec:lf:lcation\n\nENTER\n\n)\nDELTA_JOINT_ANGLE\n\n>-\n\nDO FOR I =\nEach Joint\n\n=\n\nJOIN1~NGLE_CMDI\n\n-\n\nJOIN\'I~ANGLESI\n\nJOINT_RATE_CMDI =\n(JOINT._CFJHFI )\n(DELTA.-JOINT,....ANGLE)\n\nRETURN\n\n)\n\nIF ABS (JOINT_RATE_ CMDi )\n>JRL _ MAXI\n\n\\\nI\n\nTHEN\n\n. Figure 3.3.8.13-1. Position Hold\n\nJOINT_RATE_CMDI =\nJRLftXI (SIGN\n(JOINTy.ATE_CMDI \xc2\xbb)\n\nDate\n\n10/16/79\n\nRev\nBOOK:\n\nOFT SM Detailed Design Specifications\n\n3.3.8.14 Health Monitor\n\nPage\n\n3.3.8.14-1\n\n(RHM_HLTH_MON)\n\nThe Health Monitor audits the state of various hardware discretes\nand software flags in order to determine inconsistencies or problems in\nthe hardware based on these inputs. Should a discrepency be found, RHM\nsets the appropriate flag or discrete required for annunciation. Annunciation of faults to the operator is done via the caution and warning\nlights on trIe RMS dedicated display p?-nel.\na.\n\nControl Interface - RHM is CALL\'ed by the RMS Executive (REX)\nt 12.5 Hz.\nInvocation:\n\nCALL RHM HLTH MON\n\nb.\n\nInput - Inputs to this module are specified in Table 3.3.8.14-1.\n\nc.\n\nProcess Descri~ - The control flow for this module is shown\nin Figures 3.3.8.14-1 through 3.3.8.14-8. This module is a\nseries of software checks designed to detect irregularities in\nthe arm hardware.\nThe derigidize check monitors for an inadvertant (uncommanded)\nderigidization of the EE. Warning discretes are turned on\nafter a given number of cycles to annunciate the condition to\nthe operator and the check is not performed again until the\nwarning discrete is turned OFF.\nThe release check monitors for an uncommanded release of the\npayload. Warning discretes are turned ON after a given number\nof cycles to annunciate the condition to the operator and the\ncheck is not performed again until the warning discrete is\nturned OFF.\nThe joint angle (JA) limit processing monitors each JA to\ndetect the joint\'s approach to its limits. When a joint\nexceeds one of its caution limits for a given number of cycles,\nin either the positive or negative directions, a reach limit\nflag is turned ON. The reach limit caution discrete is OFF\nwhen all joints are within their caution limits.\nIf the soft-stop limits are enabled then it is determined if\na soft-stop condition exists. If a JA is outside its reach\nlimit, then the joint angle is checked to see if it is outside\nits software limit. When the JA is detected outside its\nrespective software limits, the software stop condition is\nannunciated and the joint rate commands are zeroed.\n\nDate\nBOOK:\n\nOFT SM Detailed Design Specifications\n\n10/16/79\n\nRev\nPage\n\n3.3.8.14-2\n\nThe singularity caution discrete is turned on when any of the\nthree singularity conditions has been detected for a given\nnumber of cycles.\nThe RHM alarm flag is OFF except when a fault condition is\nbeing annunciated for the first time. There is no SPEC\ninitialization or cleanup processing.\nd.\n\nOutputs - Outputs for this module are specified in Table\n3.3.8,14-1.\n\ne.\n\nModule Type and Attributes Type: External procedure\nAttributes: Default (serially reusable with no protective\nmechanism) .\n\nf.\n\nTemplate References D INCLUDE TEMPLATE RVM CONEN\n\nConsistency and Encoder check (RVM)\n\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE CRA TE\n\nWorking Compool\n\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE CRD CIL\n\nConstants and I-load Compoo1\n\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE CRE MCO\n\nOutput Compool\n\ng.\n\nError Handling - Other than standard FCOS recovery, no error\nrecovery exists for this module.\n\nh.\n\nConstraints and Assumptions - It is assumed that the software\nstop limits for each joint are outside the reach limits for\nthe joints.\n\n~-\n\nTABLE\n\nI\nI\n\n#\n\nITEM\n\nI\nI\n1\n\nMODULE DATA LIST\n\n3.3.8.14-1 Health. Check\n\nOff\n\nDate\nPage\n\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\n3.3.8.15\n\n~perature\n\n10/16/79\n3.3.8.15-\xc2\xb71\n\nProcessor (RIT_TID1P)\n\nThe Temperature Processor monitors temperature data derived from sensors\nlocated in the RMS arm components to detect and annunciate out-of-limit conditions\nand determines the temperature which is out-of-limits by the largest amount\n( critical temperature).\na.\n\nControl Interface - RIT is CALL\'ed by the RMS Executive (REX) at 12.5 Hz.\nInvocation:\n\nCALL RIT TEMP\n\nb.\n\nInputs - Inputs to this module are specified in Table 3.3.8.15-1.\n\nc.\n\nprocess DescriEtion - The control flow for this module is shown in\nFigures 3.3.8.15-1 through 3.3.8.15-3. JUT begins processing by\ninitializing the RIT Alarm Flag. Arm index is next initialized, and\nHigh/Low Limits set to LED or ABE limits. The out-of-limits delta\nvalue for a given temperature is also initialized.\nA check is then made to determine whether the temperature value is outof-limits. If the temperature is out-of\xc2\xb7-limits, the delta out-of-limits\namount is saved. If the same temperature ID value is out of limits on\ntwo consecutive checks (not two consecutive cycles), the following\nparameters are turned on: RIT alarm flag; temperature caution flag;\ntemperature caution discrete; arm temperature annunciation. If the\ncurrent delta out-of-limits temperature value is greater than the\nworst case delta temperature value for a given arm, the new value is\nsaved and the critical temperature index is set to the proper temperature value in the RDD temperature buffer.\nThere is no SPEC initialization or cleanup processing.\n\nd.\n\nOutputs - Outputs from this module are specified in Table 3.3.8.15-1.\n\ne.\n\nModule References - None\n\nf.\n\nModule TYpe and Attributes Type:\n\nExternal Procedure\n\nAttributes:\ng.\n\nDefault (serially reusable \'with no protective mechanism)\n\nTemElate References D INCLUDE TEMPLATE CRA TE\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE CRE MCO\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE CRC COT\n\nWorking Compool\nOutput Compool\nRMS Constants Table\n\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\nDate\nPage\n\n10/16/79\n1/15/79\n3.3.8.15-2\n\nh.\n\nError Handling - Other than standard FCOS recovery, no error recovery\nexists for this module\n\ni.\n\nConstraints and Assumptions\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\nWhen RIT has processed 24 temperatures, they are assumed to be\n24 unique temperatures (i.e., no temperature is processed more\nthan once and no temperature is missed).\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\nThe upper and lower temp limits do not overlap.\n\nTABLE\n\n#\n1\n\nMODULE DATA LIST\n\n3.3.8.15-1 Temperature Processor\n\nITEM\n\nDESCRIPTOR\n\nACT\n\nSOU RCE/DESTI NATION\n\nHAL NAME\n\nI\n\nRIT_WORST_CASE_DELT_TEMP\n\nTemperature\n\nE\n\nL\n\n2\n\nSensor ID\n\n.~.2.32\n\nI\n\n3\n\nHi Limit\n\nS\n\nL\n\nLo limit\n\n3:\n\nL\n\nDelta Temp\n\n3:\n\nL\n\nRIT_DELTA_TEMP\n\n6\n\nArm Index\n\n=-=\n\nRIT_LO_LH4\n\n5\n\no\n\nRIT_HI_LIM\n\n4\n\nQ\n\n-I\n\nI\n\nWorst Case Delta\n\n1:11:3\n\nREQT.\nSYMBOL\n\nM~\\I!l\n\nI\n\nRCD\n\no\n\n\\\n\n""I\n\nCRAV_SENS01LID\n\n-t\n\n(I)\n\n~\n\n=~\n\nCD\n\nC\xc2\xbb\n\n3:\n\nRITJRM~NDEX\n\nL\n\nCD\n\n~\n\n, CD\n\nU\\\n\nD0\n\nen\n\n7\n\nRIT Temp\n\n8\n\nHi .Temp Limit\n\nCOlli~ter\n\nA.2.32\n\nI\n\nRCD\n\nA.2.37\n\nR\n\nSTM\n\nce\'\n\n1\n\nCRAV_RIT_TEMP_CTR\nCRSS _HI_TEMP_LIM\n\nV96T6790C\nv96T6800c\nV96.,:,6824c\nV96T6834c\n\n-\n\n796c\n804c,\n830C,\n838c\n\nV96T6808C\nV96T6817C\nV96T6841C\nV96T6850C\n\n-\n\n814C,\n821C,\n847C,\n854c\n\ni =\nen\n\'C\n\nI\n\nCD\nC\'J\n\nC\'J\n\n9\n\nLo Temp Limit\n\n.L2.37\n\nTerep Caution\n(PORT/STBD)\n\n,1..2.34\n\n11\n\nRIT Alarm Flag\n\n.\\.2.32\n\n12\n\nCritical Temp Index\n\n13\n\nTherm Temp\n\n10\n\nR\n\nw\n\nSTM\n\nCRSS_10_TEMPyD!\n\nV72X2931J,\nV72X2925J\n\nMCIU\n\nCREB_PS_TEMP_CAUT_ACT\n\n0\n\nRDD\n\n0\n\nRDD,DL\n\nCRAV_CRIT_TEMP_INDEX\n\nV92U3700C - Temp Data Processing\n\n\\\n/\'\n\n/\n\nDate\n10/16/79\nPage No. 3.3.8.15-7\n\n[J-\n\n= Sensor\n\nI~\nTHE~\n\n1~\n\nLa Limit\n\nDelta Temp\n\nI\n\n=\n=\n\n=\n\nI\nI\n\nArm Index\n\n=\n\n2\n\nIndex\n\n=\n\nTemp Index\n\n=\n\nTemp\n\n1\n\n-\n\n)-\n\nIF J < 13\n\nHi Limit\n\nArm Index\n\nI\n\n~\n\nHi Temp Limi t\n\nLa Temp Llmlt (J)\n\n,~\n\nTherm Counter = Therm\nCounter + 1\n\nI\n\nREPRODUCll3ILITY OF THE\nORIGINAL\n\nFigure 3 3.8.15-3. Temp Index Processing\n\nPAGI<~\n\nIS POOR\n\n1J\n\nJ\n\nDate\nDOOK:\n\nOFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\n3.3.16\n\n10/16/79\n\nPage\n\n3.3.8.16-1\n\nMCIU Encoder (RNC...;..ENCODE)\n\nThe MCIU Encoder (RNC) module sets the joint currents in order to\ndrive the selected arm joint motors; calculates, scales, and biases the\nselected arm joint motor speeds relative to the motor speed threshold;\nconverts scalar quantities to various fixed point formats for output to the\nMCIU; performs test word processing; and packs the fault word for downlist.\na.\n\nControl lriterfaces - RNC is CALL\' ed by the EMS Executive (REX) at\n\n12.5Hz.\nInvocation:\n\nCALL RNC ENCODE\n\nb.\n\n~puts\n\nc.\n\nProcess Description - The control flow for this module is shown\nin Figure 3.3.8.16-1 through 3.3.8.16-10.\n\n- Input s to this module are spec:i.fied in Table 3.3.8.16-1.\n\nThe MCIU Encoder performs the following seven (7) basic functions:\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\xe2\x80\xa2\nII\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\nInitialization\nJoint motor speed calculations\nMaximum current attenuation\nRate demand identification\nFormat conversions\nTest word processing\nTest word packing\n\nIU~PRODUClBn JTY(, OF Ttm\nORIGIN AL PAG I~ lu POOR\n\nTwo items are l.nitialized upon entry into RNC. ASI, used to\nsubscript arm dependent arrays, is set equal to the arm select\nindex when either the port or starboard arm is selected. Port is\nthe default when no arm is selected. The second initialization\nsets each joint current to its respective arm joint attenuation\nlimit for the selected arm.\nNext, each old joint motor speed is caleulated for the selected\narm using the joint rate commands and the constants for the joint\ngear ratios. Next, the old motor speed and two previous motor\nspeeds are saved. RNC then compares the absolute value of these\ncalculated speeds against an arm dependent threshold speed.\nInside the thresho.ld region, a constant scale factor is applied.\nHowever, outside this region, arm dependent scaling and biasing\nfa,ctors are applied to the calculated joint motor speeds.\nRNC next monitors conditions requiring maximum current attenuation.\nAB long as maximum torque is not required and there is no software\nstop condition, then when payload capture has been commanded or\nwhen the arm has been commanded rigidized and the end-effector is\nnot rigidized, RNC resets the joint currents for all joints to\nthe maximum current attenuation (i. e., minimum current).\n\nDate\nBOOK:\n\nOFT System Software Design Specification\n\nlO/16/79\n\nPage\n\n3.3.8.16-2\n\nThen RNC saves the two previous rate demand identifiers and increments\nthe current rate demand identifier. If the current identifier is\ngreater than 127, it is set to one (1).\nFive fixed point formats are used to output data for use by the\nMCID. The scaled motor speed is rounded up in magnitude and\nconverted to a signed, twelve (12) bit, fixed point word. The\nrange of these words in two\'s complement notation is from -2048\nto 2047. A second format is used to convert the joint current\nlimits (range from 0 to 15) into an unsigned, four (4) bit, fixed\npoint word. The first and second formats are used for each joint\nof the selected arm.\nThe third format converts two outputs from RDD, the actual and\ncommanded end-effector resultant translation rates (range from 0\nto 255+256), for output on the two-element analog meter. Both of\nthese outputs are converted to unsigned, eight (8) bit, fixed\npoint words. The fourth format converts three data fields into\nfour decimal digits for output on the D & C panel. Each data\nfield is rounded, leading zeroes are suppressed and packed into\nthree four (4) bit and two two (2) bit words as unsigned, fixed\npoint words. The decimal field is converted to a two (2) bit,\nunsigned, fixed point word. The fifth format converts the current\nrate demand identifier into a seven (7) bit, unsigned fixed word.\nNext, RNC sends to the MCID, for two consecutive cycles, one of\ntwo alternating bit patterns. Finally, the fault word is Packed\nfor downlist. At this point, RNC exits. There is no SPEC initialization or cleanup processing.\nd.\n\nOutputs - Outputs from this module are specified in Table 3.3.8.16-1.\n\ne.\n\nModule References - None\n\nf.\n\nModule Type and Attributes Type: External Procedure\nAttributes: Default (serially reusable with no protective mechanism).\n\ng.\n\nTemplate References D INCLUDE TEMPLATE CRD_CIL\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE CRE~CO\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE CRA TE\n\nConstants Compool\nOutput Compool\nWorking Compool\n\n\\.\n\nDate\nPage\nBOOK:\n\n10/16/79\n3.3.8.16-2.1\n\nOFT System Software Design Specification\nh.\n\nError Handling. - Other than standard FGOS recovery, no error\nrecovery exists for this module.\n\ni.\n\nConstraints and Assumptions - The use of the word liround" in this\nmodule means the addition of 0.5 to the quantity to be rounded and\nthe subsequent truncation of any franctional quantity, yielding a\nrounded integer. On the other hand, "rounded up in magnitude" is\nused in this module to mean the following:\nN rounded up in magnitude\neN + SIGNUM (N) 0.5)\n\n= the\n\ninteger portion of\n\nBy this means positive numbers become more positive and negative\nnumbers become more negative.\n\nTABLE\n\n3.3.8.16-1 MCIU Encoder\n\nITEM\n\nMODULE DATA LIST\n\nDESCRIPTOR\n\nI:,~\n\n1\n\nMaximum\n\n2\n\nSoftware stop flag\n\nA.2.34\n\n3\n\nCapture/release command\n\nA.2.32\n\nI\n\nRCD\n\n4\n\nRigidize/derigidize\ncommand\n\nA.2.32\n\nI\n\n5\n\n~~\n\nA,2.32\n\nI\n\nRCD\n\nH/\\L NAME\n\nI\n\nRCD\n\ntor~ue\n\nflag\n\nSOU RCE/DESTI NATION\n\nA.2.32\n\nselect index\n\nI\nI\n\nCRAB MAX TORQUE\n\nI CREE_SOFTWARE_STOP\n\nI\n\nCRAV_CAP_REL_CMD\n\n\\f:j\\"1 A1tpat1\n\nIF SUBBIT(15)\n(INCNT) = ON\n\nINCNT ::\nINCNT +1\n\n>-\n\nE\n\n\'---\n\n]\n\nFigure 3.3.8.16-9.\n\nTest Word Processing\n\n10/16/79\n3.3.8.16-16\n\nPacked Faults :::\nErrjnt CAT\nEncod Ck Flag CAT\nEE Derigid Warn CAT\nEE ReId Warn\nBIT\nI\n2\n3\n4\n5\n6\n7\n8\n9\n10\n\n~v\n\n~i\nI ,,\'I<\n\n,-.\n\nt~..... ~ ..,..:t)I\n\n11\n\n12\n13\n14\n15\n16\n\nFigure 3.3.8.16-10.\n\nPARAMETER\n0\n0\nErrjnt 1\nErrjnt 2\nErrjnt 3\nErrjnt 4\nErrjnt 5\nErrjnt 6\nEncod Ck Flag I\nEncod Ck Flag 2\nEncod Ck Flag 3\nEncod Ck Flag 4\nEncod Ck Flag 5\nEncod Ck Flag 6\nEE Derigid Warn\nEE ReId \'Warn\n\nFault Processing\n\nDate:\n\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\n3.3.8.17\n\nPage:\n\n10/16/79\n3.3.8.17-1\n\nDedicated Display (RDD_DDISP)\n\nThe Dedicated Display module (RDD) obtains selected data from the working\ndata compool and scales it into the proper units to drive the tvlO EE translation\nrate meters and the three digital readout monitors on the RMS dedicated display\npaneL\na.\n\nControl Interface - RDD is CALL\'ed by the RMS Executive (REX) at\n12.5 Hz.\nInvocation:\n\nCALL RDD DDISP\n\nb.\n\nInputs - Inputs to this module are specified in Table 3.3.8.17-L\n\nc.\n\nProcess Description - The control flow for this module is shown in\nFigures 3.3.8.17-\xc2\xb71 through 3.3.8.17-8. RDD processing consists of\':\nAlarm proc.eBsing\nAnalog parameter processing\nDigital parameter processing\nData field processing\nAnnunciation processing\n\nREPHODUCInILITY OF THE\nORIGINAL PAGE IS POOR\n\nAla:rm processing turns ON the master alarm discrete if either the RIT\nalarm flag, the HHM alarm flag, or the RVJY1 alarm flag is ON; otherwise,\nRDD turns the maBter alarm discrete OFF.\nAnalog processing determines the greater of the commanded and actual\nPOR resultant translation rates and uses it to select the appropriate\nmeter scale and to turn the X10 discrete ON or OFF. The resultant\ntranslation rates are then scaled and limited to the maximum value that\nean be displayed on the analog meters.\nIf no arm has been selected and the parameter switch on the RMS panel\nis not set to PORT or STBD temperature, the three digital displays\nare blanked. Otherwise, digital parameter processing is performed.\nBased on the position of the parameter switch, the data values are obtained from the working data compool and the sign and decimal indicators\nare set. If critical temperature is seleeted on the parameter switch,\na ta.ble is used to determine the ABE or LED temperature corresponding\nto the critical temperature. If no critical temperature exists for\nthe selected arm, all three displays are blanked.\nData field processing ensures that the sign of each display value is\ncorrect and scales each value depending on its deeimal placement. There\nis no SPEC initialization or cleanup processing.\n\n10/16/79\n3.3.8.17-2\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\nAnnunciation processing checks each annunciation flag. If it is ON\non the current pass and was OFF on the last pass, a UI annunciation\nmacro is issued. The annunciation flag is then saved for the next pass.\nd.\n\nOutputs - Outputs from this module are specified in Table 3.3.8.17-1.\n\ne.\n\nModule References - None\n\nf.\n\nModule Type and Attributes Type: External Procedure\nAttributes: Default (serially reusable with no protective mechanism).\n\ng.\n\nTemplate References Data Field Processing\n\nj,\n\ntJj\n\no\no\n\n;:>::\n\n~\n\nt-3\n\nUl\n~\n\nt::I\nCD\nct\n\np:>\n1-\'-\n\ni-\'\nCD\n\n%Name\n\n;::u\n\nCopy Annunciation\nTables To Local Table\nMap\n\nt::I\nCD\n\nI)l\n\n1-\'-\n\nIJtl\n\nt::i\n\n(J)\n\ncd\nCD\n\n()\n\n1-\'H:>\n\n1-\'()\n\n~\n\n"\n\n\\r\'I\n\nIF Annunciation Flag .=\n\n-\n\nDO FOR I = Each}-1on And Last Pass\nAnnunciation\nAnnunciation FlagT\nFlag\n~\n\n. I\n\n= Off\n\nTHEN ~ssue DI Annunciation\nMacro To Enable\nnnunciation Of AlarmI\n\n~\n1-\'o\n::::;\n\nLast Pass Annunciation\nFlagI = Annunciation\nFlag\nI\nAnnunciation Flag = Off\nI\n\n\'l::It::I\n\nP\' p:>\nIJtl ct\nCD CD\n\nw\nW\n\nCJ\n\nf-\'\n\n~\n\nI\ni-\'\n\nFigure\n\n3.3.8.17-8. Annunciation Processing\n\nW\n\ni--\'\n\n0\n-....\ni-\'\n\na,\n\n-~\n~\n\n\\0\n\nDate\n\n10/16/79\n\nPage\n\n3.3.8.18-1\n\nBOOK: OFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\n3.3.8.18\n\nInput Processing and Configuration Determination\n\nCRQC_IPCD)\n\nThe Input Processing and Configuration Determination Module\nvalidates MeIU input data and performs configuration determination.\na.\n\nControl Interface - RQC is CALL\'ed by the RMS Executive (REX)\nat 12.5 Hz.\nInvocation:\n\nCALL RQC_IPCD\n\nb.\n\nlliputs - Inputs to thos module are specified in Table 3.3.8.18-1.\n\nc.\n\nProcess Desc!..!:etion - The control flow for this module is shown in\nFigures 3.3.8.18-1 through 3.3.8.18-5.\n\'l\'he :rCOS transaction error flag and/or the Test Word Echo read test.\ndetermine whether or not a good read has occurred. Whenever a good\nread is determined, the I/O error count is zeroed, the MCIU Frame ID\nChange is calculated Cor set to a 1 if i t is the first pass after I/O\nhas been turned on), and the MCIU Frame ID Change is saved. (The Test\nlflord Echo read test is not performed if i t is the first pass since I/O\nhas been turned on.)\nWhenever FCOS and/or the Test Word Echo read test indicates a read\nerror, the I/O error counter is incremented. If only one I/O error\nhas occurred, no further processing is done. If two I/O errors have\noccurred, Suspend Configuration is requested.\nWhenever there are no I/O read errors, and the MCIU Frame ID has\nchanged (new data has been received), the MCIU Decoder (RCD) is\ncalled to process the data in the input compool, the Data Conversion\nProcessor (RYE) is also called to process the input data, and further\nconfiguration determination is performed.\nThe TEMPERATURE configuration is requested when no arm is selected\non the RMS D&C panel.\nWhen an arm is selected. one of the fo11owing conditions could require\nthat the software be in the IDLE configuration: l} safing is the progress, 21 all brakes are on, 3) the arm selected is not the same one\nsE\'lected on the last pass, 4) the previous configuration was SUSPEND,\nor 5) the mode switch setting changed. A request for IDLE due to any\none of these conditions also requires that the RHM first time flag\nbe set for Health Monitor initialization.\nWhen an arm is selected, and the above conditions are all false, the\nsoftware stop flag is tested. If the software stop flag is set, the\nIDLE configuration is requested.\n\nDate\n\n10/16/79\n\nRev\nBOOK:\n\nOFT SM Detailed Design Specification\n\nPage\n\n3.3.8.18-2\n\nAn operator request for a new configuration is indicated by\nthe control mode enter discrete being ON. The previous value\nof this discrete must be OFF for the request to be processed.\nWhen the arm is at rest (no joint movement) the mode switch\nsetting is used to determine which configuration is desired.\nSingle is the only valid mode switch setting when the software\nstop flag is on. Other validity checks are performed as\nfollows:\nAutomatic Mode (auto sequence or operator commanded) - The\nauto seq/proceed stop switch must be in the null position.\nManual Mode (orbiter unloaded, end effector, payload, or\norbiter loaded) - The hand controllers must be in the null\nposition.\n\xc2\xa7ingle Mode - The single/direct drive switch must be in the\nnull position.\nIf the checks indicate that the requested mode is valid, that\nconfiguration is requested. A mode switch setting of TEST is\na request for IDLE configuration.\nd.\n\nOutputs - Outputs from this module are specified in Table\n\n3.3.8.18-1.\ne.\n\nModule References Process\n\nSection\n\nDecoder Function (RCD)\nData Conversion Processor (RYE)\nf.\n\nReference\n\n3.3.8.5\n3.3.8.3\n\nCALL\nCALL\n\nModule Type and Attributes Type: External Procedure\nAttributes: Default (serially reusable with no protective mechanism)\n\ng.\n\nTemplate References Initialization is done for the\nfollowing modes:\nPU 1TY OF THE\n1.\n\n2.\n3.\n\n4.\n5.\n6.\n\nH,EPnODU C C),"\nj,~),\nORIGINAL Ii\\ .\n\nSUSPEND\nTEMP\nIDLE\nSINGLE\nMANUAL\nAUTO\n\n,.J\n\nTe\'\n\nPOOR\n\n10\n\nThe configuration state is updated. Configuration entry uni~ue processing\nis performed which consists of 1) setting dispatcher pointer to correct\ntable, 2) setting reference identifiers, 3) setting operating mode matrix flag (which controls status lights), 4) setting other flags and\ninputs and 5) blanking or allowing fields to be displayed on CRT. Stan-\xc2\xb7\ndard reconfiguration initialization is also done.\nd.\n\nOutputs - Outputs from this module are specified in Table 3.3.8.19-1.\n\ne.\n\nModule References - None\n\nf.\n\nModule\n\n~ype\n\nand Attributes\n\nType: External Procedure\nAttributes: Default (serially reusable with no protective mechanism)\ng.\n\nTemplate\n\nReferenc~\n\nD INCLUDE TE1~LATE eRA TE\nD INCLUDE TEMPLATE CRE MCO\nD INCLUDE BMODMACS\n\nWorking Compool\nOutput Compool\nSVC Restore Macro\n\nh.\n\nError Handli~ - Other than standard FCOS recovery, no error recovery\nexists for this module.\n\ni.\n\nConstraints and Assumptions - None\n\nTABLE\n\n#\n\nMODULE DATA LIST\n\n3.3.8.19-1 Configuration Initialization\n\nITEM\n\nDESCRIPTOR\n\nACT\n\nSOU RCE/DESTI NATION\n\nHAL NAME\n\nI\n\nMML\n\n1\n\nConfiguration Requestl A.2.32\n\nI\n\n.
